revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 14:34:06.000000000', 'message': "Avoid using the interactive interpreter for a one-liner

There's no reason to jump into the interactive interpreter if you only
need to run a single line of code and ensure that it doesn't fail.

Change-Id: I6d593b97517460395ef31a84a986a73a36b82078
"}, {'created': '2015-06-05 14:34:48.000000000', 'message': "Avoid using the interactive interpreter for a one-liner

There's no reason to jump into the interactive interpreter if you only
need to run a single line of code and ensure that it doesn't fail.

Change-Id: I6d593b97517460395ef31a84a986a73a36b82078
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid using the interactive interpreter for a one-liner

There's no reason to jump into the interactive interpreter if you only
need to run a single line of code and ensure that it doesn't fail.

Change-Id: I6d593b97517460395ef31a84a986a73a36b82078

commit_message:
Get upstream CI job working

This commit unwedges the upstream CI job. It does this by both
upping the ODL_BOOT_WAIT and also by ensuring features are
installed in a manner which allows ODL to work on VMs running
in both the HP and RAX clouds. We will also enable debug logs
by default now as well to make debugging easier.

Change-Id: Ibade3f37c53f273a64413bef57061d6eea45d195
Closes-Bug: #1450603
Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>

commit_message:
Add native types for keystone paste configuration

so that pipeline configuration can be updated from
Puppet for keystone.

Change-Id: I6bcbddca5dcfd625a325917174339f7be5206827
(cherry picked from commit 1699792a23b86d6b50ca21d7e57871d71b6a29c6)

commit_message:
Allow update_port_status to take network param

Allow the update_port_status function to take a network as
an optional parameter to skip calling get_network again if
the caller has already done so.

Closes-Bug: #1463656
Change-Id: I994f3abdb1b0ad3b2766f409b206ad4a8b2309b6

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:07:27.000000000', 'message': "Swift proxy won't start if using proxy:ceilometer

The Swift ceilometer middleware needs to be able to
write its log file in the /var/log/ceilometer
directory. Not all distributions set permissions
on this directory such that the swift user/group
can write into the ceilometer log directory. This
can cause the swift-proxy to fail to startup due
to permissions issues.

This patch updates the swift::proxy::ceilometer so
that we create an empty /var/log/ceilometer/swift-proxy-server.log
file with proper permissions before starting the swift-proxy
service.

Change-Id: If7b88bf51046317171f6fa85bb8c01390fa26a37
(cherry picked from commit 499386a89d2b5059445c887ff383655610f3fcb9)
"}]
commit_message:
Swift proxy won't start if using proxy:ceilometer

The Swift ceilometer middleware needs to be able to
write its log file in the /var/log/ceilometer
directory. Not all distributions set permissions
on this directory such that the swift user/group
can write into the ceilometer log directory. This
can cause the swift-proxy to fail to startup due
to permissions issues.

This patch updates the swift::proxy::ceilometer so
that we create an empty /var/log/ceilometer/swift-proxy-server.log
file with proper permissions before starting the swift-proxy
service.

Change-Id: If7b88bf51046317171f6fa85bb8c01390fa26a37
(cherry picked from commit 499386a89d2b5059445c887ff383655610f3fcb9)

[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:08:03.000000000', 'message': "Add base `swift` class name to call

When the ring server manifest `swift::ringserver` is called
the client throws and error with missing class. The module
`swift::ringserver` appears to refer to an incorrect class of
`Class['ringbuilder']` which should be `Class['swift::ringbuilder']`.

Change-Id: I9ddb12d2614440fe245aaaa10b7b17781a742f37
Implements: Add swift base class name to class call
Closes-Bug: 1414900
(cherry picked from commit 88541bdef61665c752e31961706f395a53f53506)
"}]
commit_message:
Add base `swift` class name to call

When the ring server manifest `swift::ringserver` is called
the client throws and error with missing class. The module
`swift::ringserver` appears to refer to an incorrect class of
`Class['ringbuilder']` which should be `Class['swift::ringbuilder']`.

Change-Id: I9ddb12d2614440fe245aaaa10b7b17781a742f37
Implements: Add swift base class name to class call
Closes-Bug: 1414900
(cherry picked from commit 88541bdef61665c752e31961706f395a53f53506)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:12:18.000000000', 'message': "read_affinity requires affinity sorting_method

proxy-server.conf read_affinity setting has no
effect unless sorting_method is set to 'affinity'

Change-Id: Ife0a30158289ea1dd44c1e93f058538c45c3a9c8
(cherry picked from commit e04486fe46452978839b1c11a67d7fee59697106)
"}]
commit_message:
read_affinity requires affinity sorting_method

proxy-server.conf read_affinity setting has no
effect unless sorting_method is set to 'affinity'

Change-Id: Ife0a30158289ea1dd44c1e93f058538c45c3a9c8
(cherry picked from commit e04486fe46452978839b1c11a67d7fee59697106)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:06:48.000000000', 'message': 'Add seed parameter to ringbuilder::rebalance.

This patch adds an optional seed parameter to the
swift::ringbuilder::rebalance definition. The seed
parameter can be useful if you want to (manually)
generate rings on independant servers and ensure that
the partition assignments are the same.

Change-Id: I840b8fe0125ed25e84f7681fada1b1102e48f32b
(cherry picked from commit b8b443416de65f59dfc2dcfa23bfa7222906f55e)
'}]
commit_message:
Add seed parameter to ringbuilder::rebalance.

This patch adds an optional seed parameter to the
swift::ringbuilder::rebalance definition. The seed
parameter can be useful if you want to (manually)
generate rings on independant servers and ensure that
the partition assignments are the same.

Change-Id: I840b8fe0125ed25e84f7681fada1b1102e48f32b
(cherry picked from commit b8b443416de65f59dfc2dcfa23bfa7222906f55e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-01 20:32:43.000000000', 'message': "Fix is_public munge

Commit 031609b57284cf13877ce727c2e4672831a3dbe2 changed the way
is_public was munged. However, when testing it it looks like it
was always seen as an empty string after this, so all created
images were private. Changing the way the 'if' block is done fixes
it.

Change-Id: If2eb52a6d0d9be89c9323702616f62f8ecba5e02
"}]
commit_message:
Fix is_public munge

Commit 031609b57284cf13877ce727c2e4672831a3dbe2 changed the way
is_public was munged. However, when testing it it looks like it
was always seen as an empty string after this, so all created
images were private. Changing the way the 'if' block is done fixes
it.

Change-Id: If2eb52a6d0d9be89c9323702616f62f8ecba5e02

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:14:04.000000000', 'message': 'Handle both string and array for memcache param.

Evaluation Error: Left match operand must result in a String value. Got
an Array. at .../modules/swift/manifests/proxy/cache.pp:26:6

Please note that Puppet syntax, while it defines a regex type, does NOT
permit regex type arguments to be passed to functions (as literals or
assigned to variables).

Change-Id: Ia230720e2cafb5b03404cea1ba54dd3b0ced6af3
Closes-Bug: #1449272
Signed-off-by: Robin H. Johnson <robbat2@gentoo.org>
(cherry picked from commit ef9f9a4194237b3cd00446f42d1b407d203cbfd5)
'}]
commit_message:
Handle both string and array for memcache param.

Evaluation Error: Left match operand must result in a String value. Got
an Array. at .../modules/swift/manifests/proxy/cache.pp:26:6

Please note that Puppet syntax, while it defines a regex type, does NOT
permit regex type arguments to be passed to functions (as literals or
assigned to variables).

Change-Id: Ia230720e2cafb5b03404cea1ba54dd3b0ced6af3
Closes-Bug: #1449272
Signed-off-by: Robin H. Johnson <robbat2@gentoo.org>
(cherry picked from commit ef9f9a4194237b3cd00446f42d1b407d203cbfd5)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:15:27.000000000', 'message': 'Fix concat file mode

The concat module passes the file permissions straight through to a file
resource, so for this to work in future parser then the mode has to be a
quoted string.

Change-Id: Iddfa6416e68127f874ce38edcdf1e208def2473f
(cherry picked from commit 3ceea9fa89cfe9c26c79146479a97c2519c332f7)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix concat file mode

The concat module passes the file permissions straight through to a file
resource, so for this to work in future parser then the mode has to be a
quoted string.

Change-Id: Iddfa6416e68127f874ce38edcdf1e208def2473f
(cherry picked from commit 3ceea9fa89cfe9c26c79146479a97c2519c332f7)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:15:56.000000000', 'message': 'mount.pp: fix lint issue

Make sure ::selinux fact is a boolean to support all
versions of Facter.

Change-Id: I173fd7b916456a96642458ef52f2af1edfa58841
(cherry picked from commit 49fd248002605b80a51a35d254fdfca0736502e5)
'}]
commit_message:
mount.pp: fix lint issue

Make sure ::selinux fact is a boolean to support all
versions of Facter.

Change-Id: I173fd7b916456a96642458ef52f2af1edfa58841
(cherry picked from commit 49fd248002605b80a51a35d254fdfca0736502e5)

(2 comments)

Hi Puneet, I am not sure if this test has it's right place in CLI.
Please have a look to http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tempest/field_guide/cli.html

CLI test should be simple and only be a smoke test for the python client libs."}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2014-08-20 13:36:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

On my fresh devstack :

cloud@jordan-devstack:/opt/stack/tempest$ neutron agent-list
+--------------------------------------+--------------------+-----------------+-------+----------------+---------------------------+
| id                                   | agent_type         | host            | alive | admin_state_up | binary                    |
+--------------------------------------+--------------------+-----------------+-------+----------------+---------------------------+
| bfee997a-57fb-4154-a2f1-1648a52f7caf | DHCP agent         | jordan-devstack | :-)   | True           | neutron-dhcp-agent        |


+--------------------------------------+--------------------+-----------------+-------+----------------+---------------------------+


cloud@jordan-devstack:/opt/stack/tempest$ neutron net-list-on-dhcp-agent bfee997a-57fb-4154-a2f1-1648a52f7caf

It's empty. Because the dhcp-agent is scheduled once the first VM is booted. If you've never booted a VM, your test PASS but the following warning is printed :

WARNING  [tempest.cli.output_parser] skipping invalid table line:"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-09-06 21:52:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

[{'created': '2015-05-25 15:29:14.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Python 3 issues

* Replace basestring with six.string_types
* Replace unicode with six.text_type
* Replace 123L with 123: "123L" is a syntax error on Python 3
* Replace "raise a, b, c" with "six.reraise(a, b, c)"
* Replace it.next() with next(it). next(it) works on Python 2 and
  Python 3. The next() method of iterators was renamed to __next__() in
  Python 3.
* Replace dict.itervalues() with six.itervalues(dict)

This patch was generated by the sixer tool using the basestring,
itervalues, long, next and raise operations:
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/sixer

Manual changes:

* cinder/volume/drivers/san/hp/hp_3par_iscsi.py:
  replace "isinstance(value, str) or isinstance(value, unicode)"
  with "isinstance(value, six.string_types)"
* reformat code to respect the 80 columns constraint
* cinder/tests/unit/test_cmd.py: use "tpgs = iter([tpg])" instead of
  using a magic mock for tpgs

For more information on Python 3, see:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

Change-Id: I82dc89b4a65c5bc5d08117ed5d18bf503975e4c4

commit_message:
Fix Python 3 issues

* Replace basestring with six.string_types
* Replace unicode with six.text_type
* Replace 123L with 123: "123L" is a syntax error on Python 3
* Replace "raise a, b, c" with "six.reraise(a, b, c)"
* Replace it.next() with next(it). next(it) works on Python 2 and
  Python 3. The next() method of iterators was renamed to __next__() in
  Python 3.
* Replace dict.itervalues() with six.itervalues(dict)
* hp_3par_common: bump version to 2.0.42
* hp_3par_iscsi: bump version to 2.0.17

This patch was generated by the sixer tool using the basestring,
itervalues, long, next and raise operations:
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/sixer

Manual changes:

* cinder/volume/drivers/san/hp/hp_3par_iscsi.py:
  replace "isinstance(value, str) or isinstance(value, unicode)"
  with "isinstance(value, six.string_types)"
* reformat code to respect the 80 columns constraint
* cinder/tests/unit/test_cmd.py: use "tpgs = iter([tpg])" instead of
  using a magic mock for tpgs

For more information on Python 3, see:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

Change-Id: I82dc89b4a65c5bc5d08117ed5d18bf503975e4c4

commit_message:
Add unit tests for parsing timestamps

this is part of a greater effort to move away from python_dateutil
to oslo.utils or datetime. but at a minimum we should include tests
on valid and invalid times so that if/when we switch over, we can
be sure we are not regressing.

Change-Id: I571969ec9fc377298e76182e47c6d20a6fa4cce0

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-09 17:52:25.000000000', 'message': "Iterate over copy of sys.modules keys in Python2/3

Iterate over a copy of sys.modules keys in both Python 2.x and
Python 3.x.  In Python 3.x, keys() is not a copy, and therefore
items can't be popped from it while iterating.

Change-Id: I98c3d7695bbfe3a6a4f23990af45a07dc147f22f
Closes-Bug: #1463503
"}]
commit_message:
Iterate over copy of sys.modules keys in Python2/3

Iterate over a copy of sys.modules keys in both Python 2.x and
Python 3.x.  In Python 3.x, keys() is not a copy, and therefore
items can't be popped from it while iterating.

Change-Id: I98c3d7695bbfe3a6a4f23990af45a07dc147f22f
Closes-Bug: #1463503

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9498, 'date': '2015-06-10 18:17:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9498, 'date': '2015-06-10 18:20:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9498, 'date': '2015-06-10 18:22:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi Sahdev. Thanks for your feedback. I modified this patch based on our discussion yesterday, and moved the fix from Heat-Translator to the installer scripts.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 18:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-heat-translator-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/33/183333/4/check/gate-heat-translator-pep8/8593faa/ : SUCCESS in 43s
- gate-heat-translator-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/33/183333/4/check/gate-heat-translator-docs/624727e//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 50s
- gate-heat-translator-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/33/183333/4/check/gate-heat-translator-python27/cfffdb8/ : SUCCESS in 1m 01s
- gate-heat-translator-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/33/183333/4/check/gate-heat-translator-python34/7d17d79/ : SUCCESS in 1m 08s'}, {'account_id': 9591, 'date': '2015-06-10 18:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Looks good, may need some more tweaking. 
I want to summarize the discussion here so it's clear.  The original problem arose when multiple software are installed on the same server using apt-get or yum:  we may get an error like "cannot get lock".  Our initial solution was to insert additional dependency to make it works.  However, this will only take care of apt-get and yum;  in the future, there could be other commands with similar problem and we cannot solve it for the general case.  Since the problem is a well known limitation with apt-get and yum, it should be up to the users to understand synchronization requirement for their scripts and handle it appropriately. In this case, the user can add the dependency in the template, or handle within the script.  The solution we opt for is the latter:  all the scripts to install software using apt-get or yum are modified to check and retry if they fail because of the lock.  
We will document this in the release note or elsewhere and point to the scripts as example.'}, {'account_id': 9498, 'date': '2015-06-10 18:55:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-14 22:25:34.000000000', 'message': "Inject dependency between 'create' SoftwareDeployment resources

Due to Linux's limitation of apt-get and yum utilities that cannot
run multiple sessions in parallel, SoftwareDeployment resources
that install some package, are deployed to the same server, and do
not have any dependency between them need to become dependent so
that the above limitation does not impact the deployment of the
translated HOT template.

Even thought for two independenct resources the direction of
injected dependency can be random, we use name comparison to make
the resource with bigger name dependent on the one with smaller
name. This is simply to avoid tests failing.

Change-Id: Iea19fe27acffda7c54db801b728a66ea427e8662
Closes-Bug: #1455251

commit_message:
Installer scripts should not run simultaneously on the same server

Due to Linux's limitation of apt-get and yum utilities that cannot
run multiple sessions in parallel, SoftwareDeployment resources
that install some package, are deployed to the same server, and do
not have any dependency between them could fail installing those
packages. We update the scripts to verify no other install session
is in progress before attemting an install. This needs to be done
in any future installer script that makes use of such utilities.

Change-Id: Iea19fe27acffda7c54db801b728a66ea427e8662
Closes-Bug: #1455251
Closes-Bug: #1463595

[{'created': '2015-06-10 01:21:02.000000000', 'message': "Document the mock attribute for mockpatch

When using mockpatch.Patch/PatchObject you need access to the
mock in order to verify that it's getting called (e.g.,
assert_called_once_with), but this attribute wasn't documented so
nobody can tell how to do it.

While adding the attribute, other issues with the docs are
corrected.

Change-Id: I7df083998adcee710cf1c5b87a1b8f091e7ad522
"}]
commit_message:
Document the mock attribute for mockpatch

When using mockpatch.Patch/PatchObject you need access to the
mock in order to verify that it's getting called (e.g.,
assert_called_once_with), but this attribute wasn't documented so
nobody can tell how to do it.

While adding the attribute, other issues with the docs are
corrected.

Change-Id: I7df083998adcee710cf1c5b87a1b8f091e7ad522

commit_message:
[glossary] Follow the docs conventions

* change Image Service to Image service
* change Identity Service to Identity or Identity service

follow the Documentaion conventions:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Conventions

Change-Id: Idde7a0881b60984fe92ff76b1d82af6185638779

commit_message:
Updates the Cloudbase-Init download url

The Windows image creation sample contains a download url for
Cloudbase-Init that needs to point to latest stable release.

Change-Id: I63ff09e364c056abf0ae66d065343a420a46c169
Closes-Bug: #1464045

commit_message:
Convert ch_objectstorage.xml to RST

-Initial conversion of ch_objectstorage.xml to RST.
-Converted section objectstorage-characteristics.xml
to RST and added objectstorage.png to local figures dir.

Implements: blueprint reorganise-user-guides

commit_message:
Provide better V2 configs in devstack

To be able to run Kilo with the cluster REST API with ZOOM backend,
devstack must be able to set the REST API port correctly as well as
instruct the agent to use ZOOM in the midonet plugin configuration
file.

Change-Id: I6c769deb22d5262037191b8354ee7a861b845991
Implements: MNP-139

commit_message:
Copy environment before decrypting

This is to prevent the decrypted values from being written to the
database.

Change-Id: Iab8d4d737e3fd839a12d8782367ff0b731f93fe7
Closes-Bug: #1463929
Co-Authored-By: Thomas Herve <therve@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add experimental cue-dsvm-rally job

This job will deploy cue-dsvm and run rally task from rally-jobs/cue.yaml

Added new job template gate-{name}-integrate-dsvm-rally. This job
temaplte is useful for projects which are not integrated into
devstack yet, and custom builder should be used.

Remainig jobs will be moved to this tempalte in the next patchset.

Change-Id: Ic02b03b941516fabd4c27f787ca2ec33e3a474d1

[{'created': '2014-10-30 13:22:08.000000000', 'message': 'virt: convert disk mount API to use nova.virt.image.model

Conver the nova.virt.disk.mount classes to use the
nova.virt.image.model classes instead of manually
passing a filename and image format as parameters.

Related-Bug: #1257674

commit_message:
virt: convert disk mount API to use nova.virt.image.model

Convert the nova.virt.disk.mount classes to use the
nova.virt.image.model classes instead of manually
passing a filename and image format as parameters.

Related-Bug: #1257674
Change-Id: Ibabcf48c95185ba443ef7575590eae6a63e0f8e5

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-04 21:56:22.000000000', 'message': 'Use an OrderedDict for fake data

Apparently json.dumps randomly outputs the keys of a dict under
Python 3. This can cause unit tests to fail when comparing
json.dumps output. Hopefully using an OrderedDict resovlves it.

Change-Id: I0182c9d8aaecf28db24b59ef3039a9c873ee2b5c
'}, {'created': '2015-06-04 22:54:04.000000000', 'message': 'Use sort_keys=True to pass tests

Apparently json.dumps randomly outputs the keys of a dict under
Python 3. This can cause unit tests to fail when comparing
json.dumps output. Using sort_keys=True when encoding the object
is the proper way to solve it.

Change-Id: I0182c9d8aaecf28db24b59ef3039a9c873ee2b5c
'}, {'created': '2015-06-05 14:50:56.000000000', 'message': 'Use sort_keys=True to pass tests

Apparently json.dumps randomly outputs the keys of a dict under
Python 3. This can cause unit tests to fail when comparing
json.dumps output. Using sort_keys=True when encoding the object
is the proper way to solve it.

Change-Id: I0182c9d8aaecf28db24b59ef3039a9c873ee2b5c
'}, {'created': '2015-06-10 17:45:08.000000000', 'message': 'Compare message data outside of assert_called_with

The sort order of message data in a dictionary is sometimes inconsistent
between what is passed in the system under test and what is created in
the test method for comparison. Instead of having assert_called_with do
the comparison, test that it is called with anything at all, and then
breakdown what was sent in the call and check the dictionary contents
independently. This will fix the spurious test failures under Python
3.4.

Change-Id: I0182c9d8aaecf28db24b59ef3039a9c873ee2b5c
'}]
commit_message:
Compare message data outside of assert_called_with

The sort order of message data in a dictionary is sometimes inconsistent
between what is passed in the system under test and what is created in
the test method for comparison. Instead of having assert_called_with do
the comparison, test that it is called with anything at all, and then
breakdown what was sent in the call and check the dictionary contents
independently. This will fix the spurious test failures under Python
3.4.

Change-Id: I0182c9d8aaecf28db24b59ef3039a9c873ee2b5c

commit_message:
Rename clustering to cluster service

This patch renames the 'clustering' service to 'cluster' service and
makes it appear in the profile module.

Change-Id: Iea0f0041ec4860ef0226cad4d28e5f63bacbe69c

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-03 11:38:20.000000000', 'message': 'Raise min version of stevedore to 1.5.0

stevedore 1.5.0 provides a new feature for building documentation from a
plugin set in sphinx. We would like to use this in the docs for some of
the Oslo libraries like oslo.messaging.

Change-Id: Ie715f98fe0d3cba8b2f4f6235e7c2b6f79be7ea0
'}]
commit_message:
Raise min version of stevedore to 1.5.0

stevedore 1.5.0 provides a new feature for building documentation from a
plugin set in sphinx. We would like to use this in the docs for some of
the Oslo libraries like oslo.messaging.

Change-Id: Ie715f98fe0d3cba8b2f4f6235e7c2b6f79be7ea0

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-04 19:05:15.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Better mocking for self.[admin_]clients in Scenario tests

self.clients and self.admin_clients are mocked out in all sorts of fun
and interesting ways in the Scenario test cases, but rarely is it done
the same way twice. Many of the tests fail to distinguish between a
call to self.clients and a call to self.admin_clients, and all (or

commit_message:
Better mocking for self.[admin_]clients in Scenario tests

self.clients and self.admin_clients are mocked out in all sorts of fun
and interesting ways in the Scenario test cases, but rarely is it done
the same way twice. Many of the tests fail to distinguish between a
call to self.clients and a call to self.admin_clients, and all (or
nearly all) don't distinguish between clients -- that is, if a test
expects a call to self.clients("nova").foo, that would be satisfied by
self.clients("keystone").foo. This patch fixes those issues, and gives
us a consistent way to mock them going forward.

Change-Id: I98a532cedbe186c49bd5b6db903a72e7d1b6bcc7

commit_message:
Actually allow to pass TRACE_FAILONLY to ostestr

The comment below suggests to use TRACE_FAILONLY to fail quickly when
running unit tests, while tox 2.0 does not allow to pass envvars from
the cli caller unless they are explicitly mentioned in passenv=
directive.

Change-Id: I6861498e7609b0c21fad844009420ea9734e2352

- check-tempest-dsvm-docker http://logs.openstack.org/20/132020/9/check/check-tempest-dsvm-docker/0ec9def : FAILURE in 21m 17s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2014-12-09 15:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2014-12-11 09:54:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-12-11 13:52:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

I think we've seen from the hardware.py object models that it's best to just use the nova.objects framework from the start for modeling domain objects. I believe these models should be in nova/objects/.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-12-11 13:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

@Jay this is a different scenario. These objects are only ever used in these locally called APIs. Nothing goes in the database, nothing goes in the RPC message system or REST AP. There are no upgrade API/data model stability requirements at play here. So Nova objects adds no value.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-12-11 15:19:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

What does it hurt? I feel like the hardware.py models were a good example of a set of things we didn't really expect to send over RPC or persist, and yet we did and had to backpedal. Making these novaobjects is nearly trivial, right? If they're really not sent over RPC, we don't have any real overhead that I know of, and if we ever do, we'll know where we stand immediately.

In the future, if we have conductor nodes triggering image cache cleanups to make the compute nodes more stateless (something we've discussed) then it's easy to imagine we might send some  of this over RPC right?

I really think it's trivial, but I'll be glad to make the code changes if you like."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-12-11 15:23:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Nova object is really pointless & adds overhead because it introduces a versioning system for which there is absolutely  no need. This is just creating extra work for overselves. We don't need to add a Nova object every time we have a purely internal API that just needs a non-scalar argument passed to it. That way lies madness"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-12-11 15:39:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

The usage of nova/virt/disk APIs should really be thought of as equivalent to calling any 3rd party python module. Obviously we'd never use NovaObject for calling 3rd party APIs, or even oslo APIs as there's no problem that needs solving in that respect. This is the same scenario - in fact we could arguably split the nova/virt/disk code off to be in an olso module - there's no need for it to be in Nova code tree long term. So making it use NovaObject would make such a split harder."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-12-12 01:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: -Code-Review

OK, I'm removing my -1 then. I do believe that it's safer to just use nova.objects now, but I'm not going to get in the way of this. I do think Dan points out a potential reason why in the future this information might be transmitted between a nova-compute and a nova-conductor, though.

Also, your point that this code is "equivalent to calling any 3rd party python module" actually I think proves my point: 3rd party Python libraries, including Oslo, use versioned interfaces: the interface version is the library's release version.

If they don't have any versioning, then they risk causing breakages when things change. If you would put these object models into an oslo library and consume that library from Nova (thereby making the objects part of the library's interface), then you must necessarily add some level of versioning to your Oslo library (even a coarse versioning system such as library semver releases) otherwise the calling code can be broken too easily by any change to the object models in the library.

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-12-12 14:39:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: -Code-Review

Honestly, I don't see what the overhead is. If we're not sending it over RPC ever, we could just put a note in the code and avoid writing backport routines until we're sending it over the wire. That makes it pretty much not any different than a regular object, IMHO. It seems like a lot more work to reparent things later if we decide to."}, {'account_id': 8802, 'date': '2014-12-12 14:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-12-15 16:51:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

Hi Dan,

Sorry if you've answered this before. You'll have to forgive my bad memory. But, could you explain how these image models relate to the nova.objects.ImageMeta classes that you submitted in this patch series?

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/76234/

Thanks!

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2015-05-20 15:22:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

They have absolutely no relationship whatsoever :-)

Currently the nova/virt/disk/* module methods accept a filename, and sometimes a use_qcow2 parameter. This is sufficient for libvirt to use plain files, or qcow2 files, but it means none of the nova/virt/disk/* APIs are usable with more advanced storage such as NBD, where you have to pass things like hostnames, passwords, usernames too. Instead of adding extra optional method parameters for hostnames, and the like, the classes in these commits just encapsulate the set of parameters needed to identify each type of storage (file, qcow2, nbd, etc), so we can pass a single parameter into the APIs to say where the image is to be found. The nova/virt/disk/* don't need nova.objects support as this code is exclusively run locally by the virt driver code."}, {'account_id': 8802, 'date': '2015-05-20 17:06:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2015-05-21 14:42:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-10-30 13:22:08.000000000', 'message': 'virt: introduce model for describing local image metadata

It is not sufficient to just pass a filename into the
libguestfs APIs. There needs to be various pieces of
metadata passed in order to support network based images.
This introduces a simple data model to describe images
when passing info from virt drivers to the VFS APIs.

Related-Bug: #1257674
Change-Id: I5f86d91aa2bcef2385d5d16022a9bd4ea7b0485e

commit_message:
virt: introduce model for describing local image metadata

It is not sufficient to just pass a filename into the
libguestfs APIs. There needs to be various pieces of
metadata passed in order to support network based images.
This introduces a simple data model to describe images
when passing info from virt drivers to the VFS APIs.

These classes are only intended to contain identifying
attributes for the various storage backends used as
images. They are not intended to hold any functional
logic, as that will remain in the libvirt driver private
image backend classes. This separates generic description
of storage backends, from driver specific implementation
details.

Related-Bug: #1257674
Change-Id: I5f86d91aa2bcef2385d5d16022a9bd4ea7b0485e

commit_message:
Switch to os-testr to control testr

It's a nice wrapper spinned out recently from tempest-lib that should
cover all our needs that we currently fulfill with pretty_tox.sh.

Change-Id: I2268ed45ab628fe5dcab657d6287594847ab587c

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow

commit_message:
Use bdmv2 format when instance is boot from volume

Currently boot from volume uses bdmv1 format. In this blueprint
bdmv2 format will be used for block device mapping instead bdmv1
format if V2 extension api is supported else bdmv1 format will
be used. Unit tests have been added.

implements bp horizon-block-device-mapping-v2
Change-Id: I3a6b89d690966080c85b629e0b2b7f2a790a0aaf

commit_message:
policy: cleanup deprecation code to handle old extension:xxx rules

It served and warned users for enough time (since Icehouse) to be sure
everyone was notified about the need to update their policy file.

Change-Id: I240b935741e49fbf65c0b95715af04af4b2a73e7

'}, {'created': '2015-06-10 15:57:32.000000000', 'message': 'Bump SQLAlchemy upper bound.

SQLAlchemy 1.0.x should just work. So move the cap to 1.1 as suggested
by Mike Bayer, the SQLAlchemy maintainer.

commit_message:
Bump SQLAlchemy upper bound.

SQLAlchemy 1.0.x should just work. So move the cap to 1.1 as suggested
by Mike Bayer, the SQLAlchemy maintainer.

"I would note that capping under 1.1 might be a good idea.   Each 1.x,
1.y, etc. is where we might make bigger changes."  - Michael Bayer

Change-Id: I0f9ac55122f04c9acd11e382219dfd562035faea

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-25 01:42:28.000000000', 'message': 'Replace locks and replace with fasteners library provides ones

The fasteners library (extracted from this library and a couple other
variations) provides the interprocess lock logic and the reader writer
lock logic so we can remove the local version and we can just use it
from that library instead.

Depends-On: I1e22d52b7186fac97fef30748e40cbd49c5f10b4

Change-Id: I98565b22e68358efe28fea62f74f8ebfcc438ff7

variations) provides the interprocess lock logic and the reader writer
lock logic so we can remove the local version and we can just use it
from that library instead.

commit_message:
Replace locks and replace with fasteners library provides ones

The fasteners library (extracted from this library and a couple other
variations) provides the interprocess lock logic and the reader writer
lock logic so we can remove the local version and we can just use it
from that library instead.

The tests that were ensuring the internals of this file lock have
now moved to the repo where that library is (for the time being),
currently travis is testing that repo against py2.6, py2.7 and py3.4.

https://github.com/harlowja/fasteners/tree/master/fasteners/tests

Docs also exist at:

http://fasteners.readthedocs.org/en/latest/

Change-Id: I98565b22e68358efe28fea62f74f8ebfcc438ff7

commit_message:
Decrease time of rally verify job

Let's use regex 'tempest.api.compute.servers.test_servers' instead of
whole compute set.

Change-Id: I641f5d03b8e67a56d09fd0cba4632ff803e793c1

Remove identity_api from AuthInfo dependencies

The identity_api dependency isn't used by AuthInfo. Somebody must
have done the thing I had noted as a TODO.

commit_message:
Add ironicclient version caching

Implement client-side version caching to the ironicclient so that
each conversation between ironic and the client need not
renegotiate which version to use.

Change-Id: Icb29fdc92ecd54e388b7c16899070572458308da

subject: Fix formatting of maintainers section in docs

commit_message:
Fix formatting of maintainers section in docs

* Fix notes formating
* Unify email styles always use @
* Better formatting of contact information

Change-Id: I3d529308fdce83122e3bbebdb30ccaa261fecd49

commit_message:
Use a lru cache to limit the size of the internal file cache

Instead of having an unbounded internal file cache which will
eventually absorb all memory of the running/containing python
process have the size of that cache be limited by an optionally
provided size (and have eviction be based on how recent a cached
entry was used).

Fixes bug 1458248

Change-Id: I5e59efc4edd51b05cfb1e67d3e7014e378e352aa

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-08 15:50:52.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce Arpinger for testing ARPs

This patches splits Pinger class into base and actual implementation of
Pinger. Arpinger uses most of Pinger and just defines command used for
pinging destination.

Change-Id: I90ae32c2f52f1debfb11ae2a08b2828ee2be04cc
'}, {'created': '2015-06-09 14:58:25.000000000', 'message': 'Break Pinger class to functions

As the class served only for storing parameters that can be passed as
actual function parameters, there is no reason for class.

Change-Id: I90ae32c2f52f1debfb11ae2a08b2828ee2be04cc
'}, {'created': '2015-06-09 16:14:15.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce Arpinger for testing ARPs

The arpinger is gonna be used in the next changeset introducing
connection testers.

Change-Id: I90ae32c2f52f1debfb11ae2a08b2828ee2be04cc
'}, {'created': '2015-06-09 17:05:36.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce functions using arping executable

connection testers.

commit_message:
Introduce functions using arping executable

The arpinger is gonna be used in the next changeset introducing
connection testers.

Change-Id: I90ae32c2f52f1debfb11ae2a08b2828ee2be04cc

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

(12 comments)

Prad, this is a great start but I think a guide for best practices needs to provide more information than you've got here on how to actually follow the advice.

That is the advice given is good, but it is insufficiently actionable for a new ceilometer deployer: it assumes they already know more than they likely do.

Another way to put it is that even if they _do_ know all these statements assume they know, we still don't want to impose upon them to have to dredge all that stuff out of their memory: We want to make things easier on them by providing examples and more explicit guidance."}, {'account_id': 6924, 'date': '2015-06-02 17:13:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

@Cdent: understand where your coming from and largely agree with your comments. This is the initial draft and i'm working on some example etc that should probably fit right into your comments. 

But Its a slippery slope on how deep we want to go into details. Explicitly showing where to change with in ceilometer config is perfectly valid to include. But for example, replica set config or mongodb ttl settings is out of scope imo. If configuring external tool is best practice, we just mention it here. Its upto the operator to dive into it.

I would rather keep this document, best practices for ceilometer and not show best practices for every library it interacts with."}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2015-06-02 20:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6924, 'date': '2015-06-02 22:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-02 22:33:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

commit_message:
Move mistral resources in-tree

This change relocates the mistral resources from the contrib area into the main
resource tree. It was originally added to contrib/ because of the project's
incubation status, and more specifically because the client is not in the
global-requirements.txt file. However, when this was discussed at the summit in
Vancouver, the decision was to move the resources to main tree but skip
registration if the client is not installed. This will save users from the
trouble of installing it as a plugin.

Change-Id: I6eeef5fa2b080df610e52620d2b935450d8d49e3

commit_message:
Split direct and indirect glance image url's

Split out direct and indirect url's so that direct url's can show the cli and
indirect url's take the user to the webiste where they can be downloaded.

Change-Id: Iaf0b91f33ee7eaab0e93a8cd526e63b1d2a698a7

subject: Update projects with correct repos
messages:
[{'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2015-06-09 01:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-09 01:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-governance-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/21/189521/1/check/gate-governance-docs/d005ca8//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 57s'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-06-09 07:42:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think we can safely say this list will always align with the git.openstack.org locations, as moving repos to the openstack namespace is a separate step.

Also this is going in the wrong direction, IMHO the repos listed should be moved out of 'stackforge' and into 'openstack'"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2015-06-09 12:21:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1 Code-Review-1

Right, agreed with Joe.  The move to openstack/ is a separate step and generally this one has to happen first.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2015-06-09 12:22:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Regarding the script issue in the commit message, I would just add a fallback to stackforge if the repo isn't found in openstack yet."}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2015-06-09 15:39:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

What is taking so long?  Most of these projects were added as openstack/* over two months ago (2-Apr-2015) and yet they still live in stackforge/*

I'm unclear why not put their correct location when they actually move.  Easiest enough to add a patch to update them when that occurs."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-06-09 18:37:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Historically it was up to each PTL to push the infra patch to rename the git repos.

Perhaps we can use "Depends-On:" and make sure an infra patch is up when a project requests to be added to openstack.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-06-09 18:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

most of these are being moved'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2015-06-10 22:02:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@JoeGordon

Thanks for the pointers.  I'll go ahead and abandon this patch then.

It would be nice if the changes for projects were made dependent on the infrastructure changes.  To keep the data closer to reality."}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2015-06-10 22:02:12.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-09 01:16:12.000000000', 'message': "Update projects with correct repos

Some projects were being listed as being in the 'openstack/' namespace
when they are actually in the 'stackforge/' namespace.

This causes problems for programs parsing this data as the projects do
not actually exist at the stated location.

Change-Id: I65f388892ef0bf2fd1f85fd5ed898717577d052d
"}]
commit_message:
Update projects with correct repos

Some projects were being listed as being in the 'openstack/' namespace
when they are actually in the 'stackforge/' namespace.

This causes problems for programs parsing this data as the projects do
not actually exist at the stated location.

Change-Id: I65f388892ef0bf2fd1f85fd5ed898717577d052d

commit_message:
Glance Format Switchover

Switch format over to disk_format and container_format in glance images.
Update the website to support the new format. Also add license info in
since it was all in the same place.

Change-Id: Ib54a09a9b4f7a245c8654efebcdaa83705f1359c

commit_message:
Bump python-glanceclient

The current minimum python-glanceclient still has the old pbr
version requirements, need to bump it up to use pbr>=0.11,<2.0.

Change-Id: I332c12a60705770cd819f4ef3ef73bc24a209fa1

subject: Use lower default value for sha512_crypt rounds
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 1916, 'name': 'Guang Yee', 'email': 'gyee@suse.com', 'username': 'guang-yee'}, {'_account_id': 2903, 'name': 'Morgan Fainberg', 'email': 'morgan.fainberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'mdrnstm'}, {'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 5803, 'name': 'Attila Fazekas', 'email': 'afazekas@redhat.com', 'username': 'afazekas'}, {'_account_id': 6486, 'name': 'Brant Knudson', 'email': 'blk@acm.org', 'username': 'blk-u'}, {'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 7191, 'name': 'Jamie Lennox', 'email': 'jamielennox@gmail.com', 'username': 'jamielennox'}, {'_account_id': 7725, 'name': 'David Stanek', 'email': 'dstanek@dstanek.com', 'username': 'dstanek'}, {'_account_id': 13063, 'name': 'WEI CHEN', 'email': 'dave.jungler@gmail.com', 'username': 'wei.d.chen'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2015-03-18 05:01:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2015-03-18 05:07:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

While I appreciate that the sample config was included here for proposal please separate the sample config change out to a dependant patch:

see http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-February/055815.html for rationale as to why this is being requested.

I am open to changing the default rounds, as long as we show justification for the right number (or keeping the low number we have) if it's not "Default" as defined in this patch set.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2015-03-18 05:14:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2015-03-18 05:15:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Morgan -- dropped sample config change.  this was mostly about floating the idea of why the rounds number is what it is, and if it was considered or just ended up like that'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2015-03-18 05:30:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Typically choosing one charter longer password makes  http://www.openwall.com/john/ stuff more expensive than the increased round number.

sha-512 uses 64 bit integers so it is not too fast even on a GPU (opencl, 40000 rounds).
Nvidia GTX 750 ~560 passwd try/sec .
Nvidia GTX 550 ~360 passwd try/sec .

http://xkcd.com/936/
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Password_strength

A good password helps lot more than having keystone to waste lot of cpu cycles on every authentication.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2015-03-18 05:37:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

>>> import passlib.hash
>>> passlib.hash.sha512_crypt.default_rounds
60000'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2015-03-18 05:56:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I recommend to use 5000 rounds since it was good for almost all Linux distro to manage user passwords.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-18 06:13:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

I can see the point in lowering this number - but honestly I don't know what we would want to default to here (other than not handling passwords at all).

I was concerned that changing the defaults would mean future password matches would fail, however it appears that passlib encodes the number of rounds into the output so it will not cause failures."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-20 02:33:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

I support finding the right number. I, however, would like to see some work done to fight the right one. Guessing seems to be wrong, the default seems to be wrong, and the stupidly low number seems to be wrong.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2015-03-23 01:05:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@morgan

a quick review of [1] shows the glibc default of 5000 has been there since the start, although there is no rationale I can see attached to that.

upstream say they attempt to keep to a 300ms target and modify the default periodically.  thus choosing some period of time and dividing down the default provided by passlib might work.  

[1] https://sourceware.org/git/?p=glibc.git;a=commit;f=crypt/sha512-crypt.c;h=c3266dc0d85ed519ff40d1738aadf7b1280af3ba'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2015-03-23 13:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I propose 8472 :), http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species_8472 .

It is slower than the glibc default (*1.69), faster than the current one (*4.72). Since it is an unusual number, probably no-one has pre calculated hash table for this value.

@Ianw: The passlib upstream seams little bit too paranoid, many many system on the internet or on the desktops still uses much-much faster hash than the glibc default sha2. 
(For ex.: ntlm, md5, sha1 (without extra rounds, just 32bit so GPU is a fast guesser))'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2015-03-24 23:57:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@afazekas : i like the idea of fuzzing the number.  I still think we should leverage that upstream is trying to keep their default to 300ms & periodically re-evaluating that.

So, if we could agree, say, 30ms was more appropriate response time for keystone, we could divide the default by 10 and be pretty sure we're close."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2015-03-25 06:38:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

ianw: passlib upstream does not keeps the 300ms, it is 60ms @100000 @i7-3770 already. (I have relative new cpu instruction set, it could be little faster with even newer instructions (~10-20%), but glibc/nspr does not use them.).

The pam and glibc upstream did not changed the default 5000,
however it is configurable in /etc/pam.d/passwd or /etc/pam.d/system-auth.

For me ~3..5ms is acceptable on @i7-3770 .'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2015-05-26 21:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

We (dolphm, dstanek) on a Keystone performance environment and bumped this number from 40000 to 10000 and noticed a significant increase in performance.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2015-05-26 22:00:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Lowering the rounds to a value of 10,000 decreased time spent in Python by 30%. At least from the environment we were testing against.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2015-06-01 18:30:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2015-06-01 18:30:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

i'm in favor of reducing this at the moment, but this might be favoring performance over security a bit *too* much for a default value."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2015-06-01 18:31:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

of course, i post a review just as Morgan posts an updated patchset.'}, {'account_id': 7725, 'date': '2015-06-01 18:31:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2015-06-01 18:32:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-01 19:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

This seems like buy in from everyone'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2015-06-03 06:59:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I am also cool with the change. I don't even think its so much of a security tradeoff. Let's be real here, Keystone's identity management is rather weak. No password polices, no password lockout, no account lifecycle management, no password recoveries, no PII encryption, etc, etc. We seem to keep tell folks, instead of make Keystone a better identity managements system, lets recommend people to use/integrate with a 3rd party IdP. After all, why reinventing the wheel?! Yeah, didn't Sony also told Apple not to reinvent the Walkman, uh I mean iPod. :)

If we are heading down that path, then it really doesn't matter whether its 40000 or 10000 rounds because we all know that it is not the elephant in the room.

So yay! Lets toast to the 30% perf improvement."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2015-06-03 10:59:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I agree that we could clarify the 30% part a little more. According to the monitoring that was being used when we tested this, we were spending 105 ms in Python with crypt_strength=40000 (the default), and 71.4 ms in Python with crypt_strength bumped to 10000. So, we decreased time spent in Python by about 30 - 32%.'}, {'account_id': 7725, 'date': '2015-06-09 13:19:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

[{'created': '2015-03-18 05:01:29.000000000', 'message': "Use default value for sha512_crypt rounds

Change Ia7c359df0d2f846a16b9fb98937f2995e9791010 rasied the issue of
hashes taking too long.  Upon investigation the default hasn't changed
since the original commit Idd5d09dc114cbb0cbd63e23e4178bb74d081c789
which doesn't give rationale for the rounds chosen.

passlib says the default is

 Passlibs default_rounds values are retuned periodically, starting
 with a rough estimate of what an average system is capable of, and
 then setting all hash.default_rounds values to take ~300ms on such a
 system. [1]

So one proposal, as here, is to use the default value by passlib as
the default.  But as you can see from the regenerated sample config
this is actually 1000000, greater than the existing value.  Both
values are way over the glibc default of 5000 [2].

Interested in ideas if we should change this; change devstack defaults
or just leave everything alone.

[1] https://pythonhosted.org/passlib/password_hash_api.html#avgsys
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/?p=glibc.git;a=blob;f=crypt/sha512-crypt.c;h=9c581abb00eb93ba6b0571c08e01fc65f1b1cd05;hb=HEAD#l87

Change-Id: I4bd7ef633070159b81c5e5d6d75275d63f976d28

"}, {'created': '2015-03-19 23:16:55.000000000', 'message': "Use lower default value for sha512_crypt rounds

Change Ia7c359df0d2f846a16b9fb98937f2995e9791010 rasied the issue of
hashes taking too long.  Upon investigation the default hasn't changed
since the original commit Idd5d09dc114cbb0cbd63e23e4178bb74d081c789

passlib's default comes with the rationale:

 Passlibs default_rounds values are retuned periodically, starting
 with a rough estimate of what an average system is capable of, and
 then setting all hash.default_rounds values to take ~300ms on such a
 system. [1]

Presumably at the time of creation passlib defined the default as
40000 and that was copied here.  It is now 100000, and grows to keep
their 300ms target.

Both values exceed the glibc default of 5000 [2] which seems sensible
to use here.

[1] https://pythonhosted.org/passlib/password_hash_api.html#avgsys
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/?p=glibc.git;a=blob;f=crypt/sha512-crypt.c;h=9c581abb00eb93ba6b0571c08e01fc65f1b1cd05;hb=HEAD#l87

Change-Id: I4bd7ef633070159b81c5e5d6d75275d63f976d28
"}, {'created': '2015-06-01 18:30:12.000000000', 'message': "Use lower default value for sha512_crypt rounds

Change Ia7c359df0d2f846a16b9fb98937f2995e9791010 rasied the issue of
hashes taking too long.  Upon investigation the default hasn't changed
since the original commit Idd5d09dc114cbb0cbd63e23e4178bb74d081c789

passlib's default comes with the rationale:

 Passlibs default_rounds values are retuned periodically, starting
 with a rough estimate of what an average system is capable of, and
 then setting all hash.default_rounds values to take ~300ms on such a
 system. [1]

Presumably at the time of creation passlib defined the default as
40000 and that was copied here.  It is now 100000, and grows to keep
their 300ms target.

Both values exceed the glibc default of 5000 [2]. Based upon benchmarks
the reduction from 40000 to 10000 resulted in a net savings of ~30%. The
10000 round mark still exceeds the glibc default.

[1] https://pythonhosted.org/passlib/password_hash_api.html#avgsys
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/?p=glibc.git;a=blob;f=crypt/sha512-crypt.c;h=9c581abb00eb93ba6b0571c08e01fc65f1b1cd05;hb=HEAD#l87

Change-Id: I4bd7ef633070159b81c5e5d6d75275d63f976d28

commit_message:
Use lower default value for sha512_crypt rounds

Change Ia7c359df0d2f846a16b9fb98937f2995e9791010 rasied the issue of
hashes taking too long.  Upon investigation the default hasn't changed
since the original commit Idd5d09dc114cbb0cbd63e23e4178bb74d081c789

passlib's default comes with the rationale:

 Passlibs default_rounds values are retuned periodically, starting
 with a rough estimate of what an average system is capable of, and
 then setting all hash.default_rounds values to take ~300ms on such a
 system. [1]

Presumably at the time of creation passlib defined the default as
40000 and that was copied here.  It is now 100000, and grows to keep
their 300ms target.

Both values exceed the glibc default of 5000 [2]. Based upon benchmarks
the reduction from 40000 to 10000 resulted in a net savings of ~30%. The
10000 round mark still exceeds the glibc default.

[1] https://pythonhosted.org/passlib/password_hash_api.html#avgsys
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/?p=glibc.git;a=blob;f=crypt/sha512-crypt.c;h=9c581abb00eb93ba6b0571c08e01fc65f1b1cd05;hb=HEAD#l87

Change-Id: I4bd7ef633070159b81c5e5d6d75275d63f976d28

commit_message:
Revert "Defer segment lookup in NetworkContext object"

This reverts commit e61865807c4c8ff959a7746fe3e17f1ae574c9d0.

This patch likely violated the idea of a NetworkContext
being a snapshot of the network at the time it was created.
This needs a different approach.

Change-Id: I20b132a0181d35b0517330fb7fbf293c3e979d0e

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 19:28:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed Inconsistent Request Id in Log Messages

Two different request Ids were showing up in log messages.
Now there is one consistent request Id that is also the one reflected in error messages.

Change-Id: Iec1c9fe52f03e0668d5fafdccd593b77b2bc8290
Closes-Bug: 1462069
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed Inconsistent Request Id in Log Messages

Two different request Ids were showing up in log messages.
Now there is one consistent request Id that is also the one reflected in error messages.

Change-Id: Iec1c9fe52f03e0668d5fafdccd593b77b2bc8290
Closes-Bug: 1462069

'}, {'created': '2015-04-07 12:57:53.000000000', 'message': 'Handle SIGHUP: neutron-server (multiprocess) and metadata agent

All launchers implemented in common.service require each service to
implement reset method because it is called in case a process
recieves a SIGHUP.

This change adds the reset method to neutron.service.RpcWorker and
neutron.wsgi.WorkerService which are used to wrap rpc and api
workers correspondingly.

Now neutron-server running in multiprocess mode (api_workers > 0 and
rpc_workers > 0) and metadata agent don't die on receiving SIGHUP and support
reloading policy_path and logging options in config.

Other changes made in the scope of this patch that need to be mentioned:

* Don't empty self._servers list in RpcWorker's stop method

  When a service is restarted all services are gracefully shutdowned,
  resetted and started again (see openstack.common.service code).
  As graceful shutdown implies calling service.stop() and then
  service.wait() we don't want to clean self._servers list because
  it would the be impossible to wait for them to stop processing
  requests and cleaning up their resources.
  Otherwise, this would lead to problems with rpc after starting
  the rpc server again.

* Create a duplicate socket each time WorkerService starts

  When api worker is stopped it kills the eventlet wsgi server
  which internally closes the wsgi server socket object. This server
  socket object becomes not usable which leads to "Bad file
  descriptor" errors on service restart.

Partial-Bug: #1276694
Change-Id: I75b00946b7cae891c6eb192e853118e7d49e4a24
'}, {'created': '2015-04-09 12:56:13.000000000', 'message': 'Handle SIGHUP: neutron-server (multiprocess) and metadata agent

Change-Id: I75b00946b7cae891c6eb192e853118e7d49e4a24
'}, {'created': '2015-04-14 12:39:47.000000000', 'message': 'Handle SIGHUP: neutron-server (multiprocess) and metadata agent

All launchers implemented in common.service require each service to
implement reset method because it is called in case a process
receives a SIGHUP.

This change adds the reset method to neutron.service.RpcWorker and
neutron.wsgi.WorkerService which are used to wrap rpc and api
workers correspondingly.

Now neutron-server running in multiprocess mode (api_workers > 0 and
rpc_workers > 0) and metadata agent don't die on receiving SIGHUP and support
reloading policy_path and logging options in config.

Note that reset is called only in case a service is running in daemon mode.

Other changes made in the scope of this patch that need to be mentioned:

* Don't empty self._servers list in RpcWorker's stop method

  When a service is restarted all services are gracefully shutdowned,
  resetted and started again (see openstack.common.service code).
  As graceful shutdown implies calling service.stop() and then
  service.wait() we don't want to clean self._servers list because
  it would be impossible to wait for them to stop processing
  requests and cleaning up their resources.
  Otherwise, this would lead to problems with rpc after starting
  the rpc server again.

* Create a duplicate socket each time WorkerService starts

  When api worker is stopped it kills the eventlet wsgi server
  which internally closes the wsgi server socket object. This server
  socket object becomes not usable which leads to "Bad file
  descriptor" errors on service restart.

Partial-Bug: #1276694
Change-Id: I75b00946b7cae891c6eb192e853118e7d49e4a24

  the rpc server again.

* Create a duplicate socket each time WorkerService starts

  When api worker is stopped it kills the eventlet wsgi server
  which internally closes the wsgi server socket object. This server

commit_message:
Handle SIGHUP: neutron-server (multiprocess) and metadata agent

All launchers implemented in common.service require each service to
implement reset method because it is called in case a process
receives a SIGHUP.

This change adds the reset method to neutron.service.RpcWorker and
neutron.wsgi.WorkerService which are used to wrap rpc and api
workers correspondingly.

Now neutron-server running in multiprocess mode (api_workers > 0 and
rpc_workers > 0) and metadata agent don't die on receiving SIGHUP and support
reloading policy_path and logging options in config.

Note that reset is called only in case a service is running in daemon mode.

Other changes made in the scope of this patch that need to be mentioned:

* Don't empty self._servers list in RpcWorker's stop method

  When a service is restarted all services are gracefully shutdowned,
  resetted and started again (see openstack.common.service code).
  As graceful shutdown implies calling service.stop() and then
  service.wait() we don't want to clean self._servers list because
  it would be impossible to wait for them to stop processing
  requests and cleaning up their resources.
  Otherwise, this would lead to problems with rpc after starting
  the rpc server again.

* Create a duplicate socket each time WorkerService starts

  When api worker is stopped it kills the eventlet wsgi server
  which internally closes the wsgi server socket object. This server
  socket object becomes not usable which leads to "Bad file
  descriptor" errors on service restart.

Added functional and unit tests.

DocImpact
Partial-Bug: #1276694
Change-Id: I75b00946b7cae891c6eb192e853118e7d49e4a24

commit_message:
Enable spoofchk control for SR-IOV ports

Allow user to control setting of MAC spoof checking for the SR-IOV ports.

Blueprint: sriov-spoofchk
Change-Id: I1be979641fe114b8a069bcc192936761a6bb2238

Fixed A10 v2 driver to correctly handle HM deletion

Added tests for above
Added logging to listeners tests (part of greater "fix tests" task)

commit_message:
Encase helper-functions spec in IIFE

Immediately Invoked Function Expression (IIFE).
This spec needs to be enclosed and jshint globals removed.

Change-Id: I5860a6a92bf1ab685d57b7f834a9ea495d196ecc
Closes-bug: #1458993

commit_message:
Updated for Falcon 0.2 and clean-up

Upgraded to Falcon 0.2
Converted from stevedore to simport
Converted from monasca to monasca_api
Removed events. Events api is in monasca-events-api
Removed references to elastic search
Removed support for message format translations
Removed unused and dead code
Removed author tags

Change-Id: I5034ea256372d22b9f824e301c379da81f82b4e2

This mostly rearranges arguments to fall in line with how the others are
listed, and also gets rid of additional versions.

Since message does things differently, one of its tests was adjusted to
use the more direct verify2 method.

Change-Id: Ie41d506c64be4afa3b4d09eb34c739d82c28cf80

commit_message:
Refactor verify_delete in proxy tests

This mostly rearranges arguments to fall in line with how the others are
listed, and also gets rid of additional versions.

Since message does things differently, one of its tests was adjusted to
use the more direct verify2 method.

Change-Id: Ie41d506c64be4afa3b4d09eb34c739d82c28cf80

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-09 17:50:40.000000000', 'message': "Set primary interface on OVS bonds

This change sets one of the member interfaces of a bond as the primary
interface, which results in that interface being the active slave.
This change adds a step to the apply method in impl_ifcfg which runs
'ovs-appctl bond/set-active-slave <bond> <iface>' after bringing up
the bond interfaces. This step ensures that the bonds work correctly
without LACP switch support. If a member interface on the bond is set
as primary, that interface will be used.

Change-Id: Ic9b4e8c68b788b98a19ea33a76c9210a80deabeb
Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2015-06-09 18:08:03.000000000', 'message': 'Automate selection of active bond slave


This change selects an interface to be the active slave in a bond
with active/passive characteristics. If one of the interfaces is
marked as primary, it will be the active slave. If none of the
interfaces are marked, the interface with the lowest alphanumeric
value will be chosen. For instance em2 comes before em3.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic9b4e8c68b788b98a19ea33a76c9210a80deabeb
'}, {'created': '2015-06-09 18:17:49.000000000', 'message': 'Automate selection of active bond slave

This change selects an interface to be the active slave in a bond
with active/passive characteristics. If one of the interfaces is
marked as primary, it will be the active slave. If none of the
interfaces are marked, the interface with the lowest alphanumeric
value will be chosen. For instance em2 comes before em3.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic9b4e8c68b788b98a19ea33a76c9210a80deabeb
'}]
commit_message:
Automate selection of active bond slave

This change selects an interface to be the active slave in a bond
with active/passive characteristics. If one of the interfaces is
marked as primary, it will be the active slave. If none of the
interfaces are marked, the interface with the lowest alphanumeric
value will be chosen. For instance em2 comes before em3.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic9b4e8c68b788b98a19ea33a76c9210a80deabeb

subject: Set primary interface on OVS bonds

interface, which results in that interface being the active slave.
This change adds a step to the apply method in impl_ifcfg which runs
'ovs-appctl bond/set-active-slave <bond> <iface>' after bringing up
the bond interfaces. This step ensures that the bonds work correctly
without LACP switch support. If a member interface on the bond is set
as primary, that interface will be used. If no interface is marked as
primary, then the interface with the lowest alphanumeric value is set
as primary (em2 comes before em3, etc.).

Change-Id: I795bb3b8ef977f9276bfec062b197c473393942e

commit_message:
Set primary interface on OVS bonds

This change sets one of the member interfaces of a bond as the primary
interface, which results in that interface being the active slave.
This change adds a step to the apply method in impl_ifcfg which runs
'ovs-appctl bond/set-active-slave <bond> <iface>' after bringing up
the bond interfaces. This step ensures that the bonds work correctly
without LACP switch support. If a member interface on the bond is set
as primary, that interface will be used.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I795bb3b8ef977f9276bfec062b197c473393942e

commit_message:
Unified the position of modal's buttons

In some only confirm modals, the 'cancel' button in the
right, 'action' button in the left. However most of modals,
the position of button  is opposite. This patch unified
the position of button.

Change-Id: Ib0cf3f42581c1eda3a2213c612bb387c17cc567d
Closes-bug:#1453048

commit_message:
Allow Horizon to access multiple regions

This patch introduces the capability for Horizon to access
multiple regions.

This only takes effect if horizon_available_regions is defined,
otherwise the current default comment is applied to the
local_settings file.

Usage is described via comments in the role defaults and in the
etc/openstack_deploy/user_variables.yml file.

Change-Id: Ia8c0b8be67fd0f479c492d9919b542806f9b204f

Thank for your inline response, I was reading the conditional wrong. Apologies.

My thoughts were that we could assert both el7 and el6 and test for the appropriate package name. 

I am still coming up to speed on what constitutes appropriate test coverage in the modules, so I will change my vote to a +1 based on the substance of the patch and let the person doing the +2 make the call on testing.

Thank you!'}, {'account_id': 7984, 'date': '2015-06-05 14:43:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Add cookiecutter-generated files for project

Use cookiecutter (https://git.openstack.org/openstack-dev/cookiecutter)
to generate config for tox so we can generate docs, run pep8, etc.
Also move CONTRIBUTING.rst to the root of the repository in keeping
with what seems to be the standard location. This move allows us to
easily generate the docs. Also include a tiny fix to allow pep8 to
run cleanly.

Change-Id: Ifbfc6d85c7b02bf4ab989974b491a3a1ae6f0900

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 01:00:20.000000000', 'message': 'Move the heat_keystoneclient_v2 contrib package

As discussed in the Vancouver summit, the only known user of the
heat_keystoneclient_v2 contrib package is Rackspace, so it was agreed to
merge it with contrib/rackspace package.

Change-Id: I8a069275d5ea3f3913b6f8ae8c6fc48b69861551
'}]
commit_message:
Move the heat_keystoneclient_v2 contrib package

As discussed in the Vancouver summit, the only known user of the
heat_keystoneclient_v2 contrib package is Rackspace, so it was agreed to
merge it with contrib/rackspace package.

[{'created': '2015-06-10 13:10:59.000000000', 'message': "Add explicit return to _get_property_value()

This doesn't change behaviour - it was implicitly returning None before -
but it makes the code a lot easier to read because it is now clear that we

commit_message:
Add explicit return to _get_property_value()

This doesn't change behaviour - it was implicitly returning None before -
but it makes the code a lot easier to read because it is now clear that we
can return None if the property is not required, does not have a default,
and is not specified by the user.

Change-Id: I7b4a177fde0b3acf7ea55a44e9fc60e716c0f7b1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 15:54:13.000000000', 'message': "Improve formatting of rest_api_version_history

As this document will inevitably be referenced a lot by users who are
trying to figure out what version 2.12 means, this document should be
easy as possible to navigate.

* DON'T PUT THE TITLE IN ALL CAPITALS
* Make each microversion a subtitle, so they come up as links in the
  table of contents
* Differentiate prose versus code.

Change-Id: Ic342025815b92db3d427b44fadfe906937f32520
"}]
commit_message:
Improve formatting of rest_api_version_history

As this document will inevitably be referenced a lot by users who are
trying to figure out what version 2.12 means, this document should be
easy as possible to navigate.

* DON'T PUT THE TITLE IN ALL CAPITALS
* Make each microversion a subtitle, so they come up as links in the
  table of contents
* Differentiate prose versus code.

Change-Id: Ic342025815b92db3d427b44fadfe906937f32520

[{'created': '2015-06-10 15:54:13.000000000', 'message': "Link to microversion history in docs

Make the API microversion history more accessible by adding it to nova's
doc landing page.

Making sure it is easy to discover what the difference between each
microversion is fundamental piece of the microversion puzzle, so lets
not require end users to have to look through git.

rename api_microversions.rst to api_microversion_dev.rst to clarify that
it is about development and versus history.

Change-Id: I270944bf9739b113a43b932948fdbf83e449603b
"}]
commit_message:
Link to microversion history in docs

Make the API microversion history more accessible by adding it to nova's
doc landing page.

Making sure it is easy to discover what the difference between each
microversion is fundamental piece of the microversion puzzle, so lets
not require end users to have to look through git.

rename api_microversions.rst to api_microversion_dev.rst to clarify that
it is about development and versus history.

Change-Id: I270944bf9739b113a43b932948fdbf83e449603b

commit_message:
Add the column 'Shared' to firewall, policy and rules table

The current implementation of firewall resources table does not display the
'Shared' attribute and its value.This patch set adds a column to display
'Shared' atribute and its value.

Change-Id: Ic688126c658c5a3fa7f1859e2eef0d53afec7ce5
Closes-Bug: #1463658

[{'created': '2015-06-04 12:30:15.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unused instance_group_policy db calls

The following db api methods were added in 2013 with
501ff418df4c08e52a697772200aa08dd67a4a43 but never used.

instance_group_policies_add
instance_group_policy_delete
instance_group_policies_get

Change-Id: I22eb056b0631104ecce98d84f73b3e18e1d40430
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unused instance_group_policy db calls

The following db api methods were added in 2013 with
501ff418df4c08e52a697772200aa08dd67a4a43 but never used.

instance_group_policies_add
instance_group_policy_delete
instance_group_policies_get

Change-Id: I22eb056b0631104ecce98d84f73b3e18e1d40430

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-01 23:41:36.000000000', 'message': 'Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for quota_destroy_all_*

This patches remove the hard-code permission checks for db call
quota_destroy_all_by_project_and_user and quota_destroy_all_by_project.

For v2 API adds back-compatible checking. For v2.1 API, remove useless
project owner permission checks that should be done by policy.

And correct related unittest. For v2.1 API, the unittest should use
non-admin context. For v2 API, the unitest keep as before and add
non-admin context test to ensure the v2 back-comaptible.

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy

Change-Id: I68a1f1362318ae3d50793ed0d353bf609b01710c

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for quota_destroy_all_*

This patch removes the hard-code permission checks for db call
quota_destroy_all_by_project_and_user and quota_destroy_all_by_project.

For v2 API adds back-compatible checking. For v2.1 API, remove useless
project owner permission checks that should be done by policy.

And correct related unittest. For v2.1 API, the unittest should use
non-admin context. For v2 API, the unitest keep as before and add
non-admin context test to ensure the v2 back-comaptible.

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: I68a1f1362318ae3d50793ed0d353bf609b01710c

commit_message:
Clean up Fake_Url for unit test of flavor_access

Switch _prefix from "/v3" to "/v2/fake", can be shared by
v21 and v2

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api
Change-Id: Iee40bf103d7586e89d5d3573b72086c67eb5324c

commit_message:
Add a hacking rule for consistent HTTP501 message

There is raise_feature_not_supported() for returning a HTTP501
response with consistent error message, and this patch adds a rule
for enforcing to use the method on v2.1 API.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I06f254fd9c8d8b6aac4ed135c6c407f3a993431f

commit_message:
Remove auth token saving from iLO driver

After I12cfdc0a8a7740cadd768068b91c258e028ef385 iSCSI deploying
does not require Keystone token for ramdisk callback. This patch
removes token saving to virtual floppy image.

Change-Id: Ice85ae4bb84d2f7c53759264812e5fbc29ac510f
