revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 00:20:50.000000000', 'message': "Doc: Use --notest for creating venv

The docs were saying to use:
    tox -evenv -- echo 'done'

Which would create the virtualenv 'venv' but then error.

Update the docs to do:
    tox -evenv --notest

Change-Id: Ibe1dfd8748535c75040a8d8ef6d33d0791d022d1
"}]
commit_message:
Doc: Use --notest for creating venv

The docs were saying to use:
    tox -evenv -- echo 'done'

Which would create the virtualenv 'venv' but then error.

Update the docs to do:
    tox -evenv --notest

Change-Id: Ibe1dfd8748535c75040a8d8ef6d33d0791d022d1

Commit 9b224641295af3763d011816d6399565ac7b98de removed

commit_message:
Hyper-V: sets supports_migrate_to_same_host capability

Commit 9b224641295af3763d011816d6399565ac7b98de removed
CONF.allow_migrate_to_same_host and introduced the
supports_migrate_to_same_host capability in compute drivers.

This commit adds the capability to the Hyper-V driver.

Change-Id: Iadfe3a3870235705af458bb2d35d0569ba212291
Partial-Bug: #1364851

commit_message:
Switch keystone over to oslo_log versionutils

versionutils has graduated to oslo_log, let's switch our
references to that one and drop the oslo-incubator copy of
the module

Change-Id: Ib865fa31f1ace78d77951880ee8dfda9c2fd32e8

[{'created': '2015-06-10 12:12:28.000000000', 'message': "Make rsync output less verbose

Currently rsync output is very verbose. So drop the -v and -P flags.

(search grenade.sh for 'sending incremental file list')

-v, --verbose           increase verbosity
-P                      same as --partial --progress
--progress              show progress during transfer
--partial               keep partially transferred files

Change-Id: I0492329d7c39279ccc6877a87eb3853ae423a99c
"}]
commit_message:
Make rsync output less verbose

Currently rsync output is very verbose. So drop the -v and -P flags.

(search grenade.sh for 'sending incremental file list')

-v, --verbose           increase verbosity
-P                      same as --partial --progress
--progress              show progress during transfer
--partial               keep partially transferred files

Change-Id: I0492329d7c39279ccc6877a87eb3853ae423a99c

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

[{'created': '2015-06-10 11:00:59.000000000', 'message': "Move all_tenants and edit_managed attributes to designate Client

Initializing designate client with a pre-existing keystone session
won't work as designate expects keystone session to have the
'all_tenants' and 'edit_managed' attributes:

Example code:

    keystone_session = ksc_session.Session(
      auth=keystone_auth,
      verify=True,
      cert=my_cert
    )

than later:

    self._designate_client = designate_client(
      session=keystone_session,
      region_name=region_name
    )

with that code, wrap_api_call() will raise an exception:

  AttributeError: 'Session' object has no attribute 'all_tenants'

Same goes for 'edit_managed'.

This patch moves both attributes from Keystone session to designate
Client.

Closes-Bug: 1457821
Change-Id: I13d6c9ed46406fefc8cfa5de46811e4be009f1af
"}, {'created': '2015-06-10 11:06:49.000000000', 'message': "Move all_tenants and edit_managed attributes to designate Client

than later:

      session=keystone_session,

    )

Change-Id: I13d6c9ed46406fefc8cfa5de46811e4be009f1af
"}, {'created': '2015-06-10 12:19:20.000000000', 'message': "Move all_tenants and edit_managed attributes to designate Client

'all_tenants' and 'edit_managed' attributes:

Example code:

    keystone_session = ksc_session.Session(
      auth=keystone_auth,
      verify=True,
      cert=my_cert
    )

than later:

    self._designate_client = designate_client(
      session=keystone_session,
      region_name=region_name
    )

with that code, wrap_api_call() will raise an exception:

  AttributeError: 'Session' object has no attribute 'all_tenants'

Same goes for 'edit_managed'.

Closes-Bug: 1457821
Change-Id: I13d6c9ed46406fefc8cfa5de46811e4be009f1af

commit_message:
Move all_tenants and edit_managed attributes to designate Client

Initializing designate client with a pre-existing keystone session
won't work as designate expects keystone session to have the
'all_tenants' and 'edit_managed' attributes:

Example code:

    keystone_session = ksc_session.Session(
      auth=keystone_auth,
      verify=True,
      cert=my_cert
    )

than later:

    self._designate_client = designate_client(
      session=keystone_session,
      region_name=region_name
    )

with that code, wrap_api_call() will raise an exception:

  AttributeError: 'Session' object has no attribute 'all_tenants'

Same goes for 'edit_managed'.

This patch moves both attributes from Keystone session to designate
Client.

Closes-Bug: 1457821
Change-Id: I13d6c9ed46406fefc8cfa5de46811e4be009f1af

commit_message:
Added extra previllege to list all domains from all tenants

The user has to use the command "designate --all-tenants domain-list" to list all domains from all tenants.
When the above command is used "X-Auth-All-Projects" value is set to true and it is passed as a header to
designate.This will allow us to list all domains from all tenants.

Change-Id: I4cd4dd5427f5f35cdec95dbdf36c7386b60a2949
Fixes: bug #1418156

[{'created': '2015-06-08 18:55:10.000000000', 'message': "Map uuid db field to instance_uuid in BandwidthUsage object

The BandwidthUsage database model stores the instance relation as 'uuid'
but the BandwidthUsage Nova Object stores it as instance_uuid.  The
_from_db_object needs to handle this discrepancy.

This wasn't caught before because unit tests were passing back a
simulated db return which didn't match reality.

Change-Id: I9aeac709cbbf0f9ddfa6cf724d55af8fa3a962ee
Closes-Bug: 1463039
"}]
commit_message:
Map uuid db field to instance_uuid in BandwidthUsage object

The BandwidthUsage database model stores the instance relation as 'uuid'
but the BandwidthUsage Nova Object stores it as instance_uuid.  The
_from_db_object needs to handle this discrepancy.

This wasn't caught before because unit tests were passing back a
simulated db return which didn't match reality.

Change-Id: I9aeac709cbbf0f9ddfa6cf724d55af8fa3a962ee
Closes-Bug: 1463039

commit_message:
Add a bunch of profiling hacks

I'm sure someone will show me the right way to do this but it does expose
where the long times are:
* importing keystoneclient.session
* loading some extension plugins
* performing authentication (mostly REST round trip time)
* loading OSC command classes
* performing commands

Change-Id: Ibfde558b17e333989bf155c52b60f93f82cfe898

hi Sylvain,
have i addressed your questions re json formatting to your satisfaction.
if so can you re-review this patch.

i strongly believe the db migration required to allow upgrading existing deployment to a json format 
is a bad idea but would like your input. 

to do the migration you would have to update the value of all rows in the aggreate_metadata table where the key is "instance_type" to the same value in quotes warped in square brackets. (value => ["value"] e.g. m1.nano => ["m1.nano"])

this would require locking the table or perhaps just the column and opening a db cursor to update each row individually. it is certainly possible to do but I think a comma separated list is more appropriate.

i will likely have to rebase for this to merge correctly due to the time between submitting and now. as i am on vacation until Monday the 5th i will do this next week. if you have any feed back i can address it in the rebase if it is required.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2014-12-30 01:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

actually the db migration is much simpler but i think it is still not required.

pseudo migration operation no cursors required. 
 
UPDATE nova.aggregate_metadata 
SET value = (concat('["', value ,'"]') )
where key ='instance_type''}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2015-01-05 13:36:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2015-01-12 12:11:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Sylvain
i will rework this patch with the json decode as you suggested.

it should be available later today.

i will implement either passing a single value or a json array
and update the documentation to reflect this.
regards
sean'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2015-01-13 19:05:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-13 23:06:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

(2 comments)

This is much closer to a spec free blueprint then a bug.

A few in line issues. I am also not convinced this is the best way to do this. Instead of manually maintaining a list of flavors that contain SSDs what about making it possible to match flavor substrings (if your flavors have a useful naming scheme that says which have SSDs etc), or other solutions that don't require maintaining a full list of all flavors that have X.



This prevent operators form creating a single host aggregate for a group of related flavors.
For example a host aggregate for all flavors that support hugepages or a host aggregate for all flavors that support
ssds."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2015-01-23 12:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-01-23 13:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2015-01-24 15:19:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@joe Gordon
opening this bug originally came out of trying to apply the constraints 
imposed by vhost-user to the new hugepage implementation being added to nova. 
For clarity i call it a bug because i believe this is a large usability bug 
when hugepages are combined with vhost-user.

im not familiar enough to speak to the snabb implementation though i believe
it is also true for their implementation but the DPDK implementation requires a vm that uses dpdkvhost or dpdkvhostuser to use hugepage backed memory.
Incidentally the alternative hugepage proposal we originally put forward, 
which used a conf parameter on the compute node to either enable hugepages for all vms
on the node or not, did so for exactly this reason.

to address this requirement i opened this blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-allowed-mempage-sizes
to describe 2 ways to address this problem. while discussing this on the mailing list with Daniel Berrange 
he pointed out that is should be possible to satisfy this requirement by use host aggregates and flavour affinity.
Without this modification, he was right you can use the AggregateTypeAffinityFilter to ensure,
that a node with a switch that requires hugepages to be used will only ever be scheduled vms that requested hugepages. 

the issue that this bug tries to address is usability/scalability form an operator/deployer view point.
for example if you have 20 hosts that support hugepages and 5 flavours that request huge pages 
you need 5 host aggregates each containing 20 host one per flavour. 
with this proposal that becomes a single host aggregate with 5 flavours. 
if you install 5 more pods of 20 servers in your datacenter for hugepage dependent workload
you simply add those 100 server to a single aggregate instead of 5 in this example.

so while you could argue this is a new feature and your would be right,
from a usability point of view i believe it is a bug. 
sorry for the essay but i wanted to address your concerns as to why i chose
to take this approach. i will extend the commit message as you suggested on Monday.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2015-01-26 18:14:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-26 19:20:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-02-24 12:54:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-2

Support for multiple instance types already exists, though it's not well designed: add the host to multiple aggregates, each containing separate instance type metadata keys.

My problem with this patch is that it adds in JSON-ification of an aggregate metadata value just for instance_type. I'd prefer to have a long-term solution that doesn't impact the eventual ability of a user to search aggregates by metadata key/value, which this patch would interfere with, since the JSON string is an implementation detail and someone searching for aggregate list instance_type=m1.nano would need to know that the metadata was placed on the aggregate in a serialized form -- thus the implementation detail would leak out of the API.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2015-02-24 13:54:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Code-Review

@jay pipes

if i reverted to the initial implementation of this patch 
as a comma separated list would that resolve your concern or
is it rather that any list encoding would require the end user to be aware of and perhaps preform special logic in there client to process this metadata value.

the main advantage of the comma separated list is that for a single value the format is identical to the legacy form. for me it seams odd that there is no standardized way to represent a list in the api.

the only other way i think would be reasonably implementation agnostic, isto allow specification of a list of possible value  by repeating the metadata item once per value. this however would require several changes to accomplish including changes to the db table, horizon and api.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2015-02-25 23:50:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-07 10:06:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified-1

commit_message:
Add AggregateTypeAffinityFilter multi values support

This change allows the AggregateTypeAffinityFilter to function when
multiple instance_type names are set in the Aggregate Metadata.
This change implements and documents a new comma separated syntax for
the aggregate instance_type metadata attribute. The legacy syntax is
still supported when a single instace_type is specified.
e.g. 'm1.nano' or "m1.nano,m1.small"

DocImpact
Change-Id: I0618a300754d012db62df52faa12cc3cedfe2b65
Closes-bug: #1399204

commit_message:
Improve compute swap_volume logging

Even though this is a reasonably complicated bit of code that also can
get called by cinder when doing volume retyping, there is close to zero
logging at the moment.

Change-Id: Ie32ba7e8e262528494c5dfec4d7b49950f72ecb0

commit_message:
Allow cache_git.sh to handle additional projects adhoc

When testing external plugins it's extremely useful to be able to
cache additional repositories with cache_git.sh. This allows us to
just pass a whole set of additional items on the cli that will also
get cached.

Change-Id: I966c45efa9e8eb8868323de74f363eb1990e534e

commit_message:
Split the state machine runners off into own file

When using a state machine it is not always desired
to use the runner concept, so to ensure both concepts
are modular split runners off into there own module.

Change-Id: Iac8ce50b0a17468190f3f737663b5b094c324a55

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-02 19:21:23.000000000', 'message': "Modifying the heat deployer to use injected file to download DU

Problem:
We have noticed that occassionally the downloading of DU on the
VM will fail to download the entire file. This causes failure in
during docker load, which loads and makes the DU available to
be run on the VM.

Solution:
One way to address this issue is to check docker load for success,
and try the steps of downloading the DU and loading it, if it
has failed. Towards this we have developed a script which will
perform such checks. Heat provides the mechanism of 'get_file'
using which we inject this script into the VM.

This patch implements this solution.

As a consequence of this change, the heat deployer is simplied,
as we no longer need to customize the template in our code.
We just need to pass the correct parameters to the template.

Note that the location of the file to inject is currently specified
as a publicly available gist URL. We will change this to point to
the URL of the 'robust-du-handling' script once it is merged into
master.

Change-Id: I14c4729727b17ab7671c155a1ed32765af1e7b6b

commit_message:
Modifying the heat deployer to use injected file to download DU

Problem:
We have noticed that occassionally the downloading of DU on the
VM will fail to download the entire file. This causes failure
during docker load, which loads and makes the DU available to
be run on the VM.

Solution:
One way to address this issue is to check docker load for success,
and try the steps of downloading the DU and loading it again, if it
has failed. Towards this we have developed a script which will
perform such checks. We inject this script into the VM using the
mechanism of 'get_file' provided by Heat.

This patch implements this solution.

As a consequence of this change, the heat deployer is simplied,
as we no longer need to customize the template in our code.
We just need to pass the correct parameters to the template.

Change-Id: I14c4729727b17ab7671c155a1ed32765af1e7b6b

The hello world example in spec has been updated to provide a better example
of instance memory size.

[{'created': '2015-05-22 15:41:54.000000000', 'message': 'implement external plugin mechanism for grenade

Implement an external plugin mechanism for grenade in the spirit of
devstack plugins. This code is currently untested, however should be a
very reasonable base point to get projects working with out of tree
plugins.

Change-Id: I02a777077d40408766204b05ed284fe98efbce8e
'}, {'created': '2015-06-08 21:29:29.000000000', 'message': "implement external plugin mechanism for grenade

Implement an external plugin mechanism for grenade in the spirit of
devstack plugins. This assumes that external plugins will live in the
devstack/upgrade tree in their respective repository.

External plugins are enabled by adding

enable_grenade_plugin <name> <giturl> [branch]

to ``pluginrc`` at the top of the grenade directory. (``localrc``
could not be used due to timing issues on parsing)

a new ``devstack_localrc <base|target> ...`` is also added to grenade
that allows settings files to add content to base and target devstack
localrcs. This is quite critical for out of tree support, because for
upgrade testing there will often be a need to add services to the
localrc.

Partially tested on the existing Heat plugin implemented in
I0847004a8ac023a113cabaee46896abc823a01da, though that doesn't yet
fully pass due to conflicts in it's upgrade process.

Include documentation for out of tree best practices.

Change-Id: I02a777077d40408766204b05ed284fe98efbce8e

commit_message:
implement external plugin mechanism for grenade

Implement an external plugin mechanism for grenade in the spirit of
devstack plugins. This assumes that external plugins will live in the
devstack/upgrade tree in their respective repository.

External plugins are enabled by adding

enable_grenade_plugin <name> <giturl> [branch]

to ``pluginrc`` at the top of the grenade directory. (``localrc``
could not be used due to timing issues on parsing)

a new ``devstack_localrc <base|target> ...`` is also added to grenade
that allows settings files to add content to base and target devstack
localrcs. This is quite critical for out of tree support, because for
upgrade testing there will often be a need to add services to the
localrc.

Partially tested on the existing Heat plugin implemented in
I0847004a8ac023a113cabaee46896abc823a01da, though that doesn't yet
fully pass due to conflicts in it's upgrade process.

Include documentation for out of tree best practices.

Change-Id: I02a777077d40408766204b05ed284fe98efbce8e

code still using 'auth_url = http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0'. So
here using correct auth_url of nova in neutron.conf

commit_message:
Auth_url changes following auth_plugin in nova section

After the refact of nova authentication in neutron, it supports
three auth_plugin: password, v2password, v3password. Each
auth_plugin match a different auth_url. For example:
a) password
auth_plugin = password
auth_url = http://127.0.0.1:35357/
b) v2password
auth_plugin = v2password
auth_url = http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0
c) v3password
auth_plugin = v3password
auth_url = http://127.0.0.1:35357/v3

The auth_url should be set following the auth_plugin automatically.

Change-Id: Ia584a6c6a64fcaa92012c957da004ac029ca7db2
Closes-bug: #1459594
Closes-bug: #1461480

commit_message:
libvirt: make default_device_names DRY-er

Since we now have a reusable method to call to get the block_device_info
structure that most driver code is designed to work with, we don't need
to re-write it in the blockinfo code - we can just use it.

In addition to this - this fixes a (yet unreported) issue that libvirt
would not consider blank volumes in it's device assignments.

Related-bug: 1231874
Partial-bug: 1452224

Change-Id: I4b9a6fd1b08ff787fdd1226f533f4181fe44b7e9

commit_message:
Add and use raise_feature_not_supported()

In HTTPNotImplemented cases, each API passes its original message.
The meaning of these messages are almost the same but messages are
inconsistent.
This patch adds common raise_feature_not_supported() and replaces
these messages with the method for consistent message.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I23da9bf153cb92944c0f4e76d70ce72a4ff6b16f

Are you sure you want to do this? We don't do this in ironic and one concern is that someone will want to 'make things consistent' and add it to all the other ironic projects.

It seems like the doc only needs to be tested/tried if something changes in the doc, and that doesn't happen (in ironic) for every code change. (Well, it could/does but we ignore the doc stuff that is generated from the code for the most part anyway.)

I don't modify ipa enough to know whether doing this will be a pain or not for me. I know I could explicitly mention py27 & pep8 in the tox command but ..."}, {'account_id': 10380, 'date': '2015-06-10 16:38:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

After looking more into what will and won't fail gate, I'm inclined to agree with you Ruby. I had one gate failure due to a docstring having the incorrect indentation, but it looks like an edge case (multiple indentations in the example code in the doc string). I don't think catching that is worth the extra 15s per tox run. Thanks :)"}, {'account_id': 10380, 'date': '2015-06-10 16:38:15.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2015-06-10 17:31:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Josh. Ah, so that's why you saw something fail :-)"}]

commit_message:
Add docs tests to default tox envlist in IPA

If we're going to gate on it, it should be in the default list.

Change-Id: I333b0a1243f0e61f6957f161fea38351968816d0

commit_message:
Wait for a configured test router to become active

The router VM that is spawned during RUG startup may not be active until some
time after the test suite, causing tests to start before the thing is active.
This adds an assertion to the functional test setUp to wait for a configured
router to become active before continuing on with any tests.  The router to
wait on is now configured in test.conf.  run_functional.sh will attempt to find
the devstack created one, and error if there are multiples.  Users can specify
their own test router if running outside of the gate env.

Change-Id: I2b54ddfcce8dab446ac7418cca61320b370bc999

This change also adds the dogtag installation functions into the
contrib/devstack/lib/barbican scripts, and enables the installation of
dogtag in the extras.d script making the calling of the dogtag

commit_message:
service_enabled instead of environment variable for dogtag

This change also adds the dogtag installation functions into the
contrib/devstack/lib/barbican scripts, and enables the installation of
dogtag in the extras.d script making the calling of the dogtag
installation from the functional test pre-hook script not necessary.

Depends-on: I749539f387f163e829fdc8390b6bd16cf23c663b
Change-Id: I60ccfaaa43aa4aa68e99affb9837ecab48c36759

commit_message:
rabbit: Add logging on blocked connection

When the broker will block the connection for a server-side issue
like disk full, it notifies the client.

This change adds the callback methods when this occurs to inform
the deployer about the reason of this blocking.

Change-Id: I5164b9e1b720f022b45a5718258df036ba8808ed
Closes-bug: #1454449

commit_message:
Support identity_uri

This patch adds the ability to set a new identity_uri parameter.
It also deprecates the old auth_host, auth_port, auth_protocol,
and auth_admin_prefix parameters. Logic is in place so that
users of the deprecated settings should have a smooth upgrade
process and get deprecation warnings until they adopt the
new settings.

Change-Id: Id72991da18dd1f467a7683f8f450e157da64f969
Closes-Bug: #1391235
(cherry-picked from commit 2dff962a6505b890654f8a258638e746194ad35e)

commit_message:
Support identity_uri in provider

After https://review.openstack.org/152321 was merged, it was no
longer guaranteed that some now deprecated settings like auth_host
and auth_protocol would be present in glance-api.conf. This breaks
the Glance provider, which expects them to be present.

This patch adds support for identity_uri in provider, while
keeping backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: Ie8a2e45a4afea4828e02af36e64d65e7d4b7557e
(cherry picked from commit 9f44421ceb54f970986fd96d2e66faccba1909ec)

commit_message:
Add support for identity_uri.

This patch adds the ability to set a new keystone_identity_uri
parameter.  It also deprecates the old keystone_host, keystone_port,
keystone_protocol, and keystone_auth_admin_prefix parameters. Logic
is in place so that users of the deprecated settings should have a
smooth upgrade process and get deprecation warnings until they adopt
the new settings.

Change-Id: Ideefb4d824cbd5b4b83f9eb773a75e536e3458fb
(cherry-picked from commit 70faac7cfe4dafedea034dab81a32c758a524b61)

process and get deprecation warnings until they adopt the
new settings.

commit_message:
VMware: ensure that the adapter type is used

In the event that the boot was done and the adapter type was not
passed we should use the default adapter type on the image.

Change-Id: I3bf60e5ea225e394bca67edfd4b0302b80d28019
Closes-bug: #1439585

commit_message:
Add policy check for extension_info

This patch adds default policy enforcement for extension info. By
default the rule is empty, but operator can configure it if they
don't want normal user to see extension info.

Closes-Bug: #1415286
Change-Id: I6afcf6f9e2cedb86e899a360e1abb22ccc1f0a27
Co-authored-by: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>

This change simply makes sure that all containers and hosts have the
`apt-transport-https` package installed. this package is absolutly
required everywhere because we've changed all of the repo endpoints
to https and not all systems have this package installed on a base
kick. Furthermore an entry was added into the upgrade script to
ensure that upon upgrade everything will converge and remain
consistent.

Change-Id: I4b357ff7099a4c1c63c85ac9560aefc8d56709be

commit_message:
Updated upgrade and deployment processes for https

This change simply makes sure that all containers and hosts have the
`apt-transport-https` package installed. this package is absolutly
required everywhere because we've changed all of the repo endpoints
to https and not all systems have this package installed on a base
kick. Furthermore an entry was added into the upgrade script to
ensure that upon upgrade everything will converge and remain
consistent.

Change-Id: I4b357ff7099a4c1c63c85ac9560aefc8d56709be
Closes-Bug: #1463155
(cherry picked from commit 8bcaac5702f3ed29d74a3f49690cf2d6e3655828)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-07 08:36:31.000000000', 'message': 'Objects: update missing adapter types

The followiing adaptre types also need to be supported:
 - ide
 - lsiLogicsas
 - paraVirtual

Change-Id: Ibb93636d767862470ebd704e3e23ec04e8a1f1ff
'}, {'created': '2015-06-07 09:52:56.000000000', 'message': 'Objects: update missing adapter types

The followiing adaptre types also need to be supported:
 - ide
 - lsiLogicsas
 - paraVirtual

This is required for backwards compatibility due to:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/image_meta.py#L288

Change-Id: Ibb93636d767862470ebd704e3e23ec04e8a1f1ff
'}, {'created': '2015-06-07 11:16:16.000000000', 'message': 'Objects: update missing adapter types

The followiing adapter types need to be supported for
the VMware driver:

- "busLogic"
- "ide"
- "lsiLogicsas"
- "paraVirtual"

This is required for backwards compatibility due to:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/image_meta.py#L288

Which is also a bug. That should be hw_disk_bus.

Change-Id: Ibb93636d767862470ebd704e3e23ec04e8a1f1ff
'}, {'created': '2015-06-08 12:29:14.000000000', 'message': 'Objects: update missing adapter types

The vmware_adaptertype does not map 1:1 to the to either
hw_disk_bus or hw_scsi_model. So we need a combination of
both.

The vmware_adaptertype will drive which flags are set.

The settings are as follows:

+-----------------------------------------------+
|vmware_apdaptertype|hw_disk_bus|hw_scsi_model  |
+-----------------------------------------------+
| ide               | ide       |               |
| lsiLogic          | scsi      | lsilogic      |
| busLogic          | scsi      | buslogic      |
| lsiLogicsas       | scsi      | lsisas1068    |
| paraVirtual       | scsi      | vmpvscsi      |
+-------------------+-----------+---------------+

Change-Id: Ibb93636d767862470ebd704e3e23ec04e8a1f1ff
'}, {'created': '2015-06-08 13:08:03.000000000', 'message': 'Objects: update missing adapter types

The vmware_adaptertype does not map 1:1 to either the
hw_disk_bus or hw_scsi_model. So we need a combination of
both.

The vmware_adaptertype will drive which flags are set.

The settings are as follows:

+-----------------------------------------------+

commit_message:
Objects: update missing adapter types

The vmware_adaptertype does not map 1:1 to either the
hw_disk_bus or hw_scsi_model. So we need a combination of
both.

The vmware_adaptertype will drive which flags are set.

The settings are as follows:

+-----------------------------------------------+
|vmware_apdaptertype|hw_disk_bus|hw_scsi_model  |
+-----------------------------------------------+
| ide               | ide       |               |
| lsiLogic          | scsi      | lsilogic      |
| busLogic          | scsi      | buslogic      |
| lsiLogicsas       | scsi      | lsisas1068    |
| paraVirtual       | scsi      | vmpvscsi      |
+-------------------+-----------+---------------+

Change-Id: Ibb93636d767862470ebd704e3e23ec04e8a1f1ff

commit_message:
Show 'reserved' status in os-fixed-ips

Adds a new microversion to show the 'reserved' status on a FixedIP in
the os-fixed-ips extension.

Closes-Bug: #1249526

Implements blueprint show-reserved-status-in-os-fixed-ips-api

Change-Id: Iadaae393fce0c78dbdfd3b02958ddfd6276edb94

commit_message:
LBaaS: update device_driver for Kilo

Neutron LBaaS plugin has been pulled out from Neutron core so the
device_driver Python plugin is now neutron_lbaas_*.
This patch breaks Juno deployments.

Doc: http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/content/install_neutron-lbaas-agent.html

Change-Id: I00085a1f6d5431256146aa5e9d4b506f33cf95fe

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-01 16:53:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/36/169836/7/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/93d8e3e/ : SUCCESS in 3m 47s'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-02 20:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

I support the idea in general, but have some questions.'}, {'account_id': 10707, 'date': '2015-04-02 20:03:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Liberty Template alignment needed: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/openstack/nova-specs/master/specs/liberty-template.rst'}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2015-04-03 04:44:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)

I'm primarily an operator, so comments from that perspective.

Is there something else we could do to make detection of failed hosts faster and more reliable within nova?  It would be nice if the platform itself could handle this, rather than relying on external systems.

I understand that failure detection is hard, but this proposed solution feels a little too "bolt on" to me.'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-03 06:18:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Good points made, need to come back better after Easter and discuss the matters risen like:
*Why external tool vs. internal enhancement.
*Schema change
*Should one also control "host up".
*Python CLI out of this spec.
*Correct actions to states.
*Notification'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-05 02:44:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

Mike, I think that nova's job isn't really detection and enforcement of "downed" hosts.  There are existing systems (pacemaker, for instance) that can already handle that job nicely.

Given that such systems exist, it makes sense to have a way for them to tell nova that the host has gone down.'}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2015-04-06 15:48:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Ok, I guess I can see the argument both ways.  To me, to say that the core platform cannot detect its own failures and that deployers must build their own system for that, is a bit of a cop out.

But in any case, having _some_ mechanism to mark computes as dead is better than nothing.  I'm in favor of this once the schema questions are addressed."}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-07 11:13:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(7 comments)

Added comments for questions. For the generic question about why new API to have external tool for host monitoring was quite nicely answered already by Chris Friesen. One fact is also that host fault monitoring can be HW specific, complex and need to be configured. There is currently also ongoing project called Doctor in OPNFV. One outcome will be host fault monitoring and everything will be opensource. So if one do not currently use some existing external tool, there will be one and will be made to use this API.'}, {'account_id': 10707, 'date': '2015-04-07 15:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

Responded, CLI goes into python-openstack-client and/or python-nova-client'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-07 15:54:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-08 09:34:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-08 09:38:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

All comments to patch 7 taken into account.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-08 09:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/36/169836/8/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/ba2f80e//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 06s
- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/36/169836/8/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/8494611/ : SUCCESS in 2m 31s'}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2015-04-08 23:01:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

LGTM from operators' perspective."}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-10 09:25:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I need to give this more thought. I believe we need a devref document to look more generally at how to handle "host maintenance" operations. We have had too many quick fixes, and I don't want to pile on more.

It totally makes sense to have an API to tell openstack that the server is known to be dead, to spot waiting for any poll period or group system to notice the server is down.

However, I want to mark instances as "impacted by maintenance" independently of the VM power state. In this case, you probably want both, but I don't want that to be combined.

However, it is extremely dangerous to then assume the instances are not running, see discussions on "split brain" problems. We need to be clear about the requirements of a system that is detecting that VMs are "not running".'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-15 11:48:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(10 comments)

Here is the latest and mostly about the thing of having this spec for stating nova-compute is down. That should be quite clear and could done.

For the "split brain" the idea I had in mind was to have a sophisticated external tool to make sure host is fenced (down). For a Telco grade level of host fault handling there is opensource Doctor project in OPNFV to try to do that, but surely anybody already interested in this would have some own implementation in place. So is it that in deployment one would trust infra to have solution by some external tool or openstack to have better means. Should the tool actually be in openstack or should there now be just more changes to be able to have one. Should we have the good discussion about all the problematic issues separately over the "host faults" topic. Vancouver or even earlier to have it more prepared?'}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2015-04-15 13:16:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

Overly complicated, IMO.

Wouldn't it be simpler to just remove this particular bit of code in the evacuate() implementation?

 if self.servicegroup_api.service_is_up(service):
     LOG.error(_LE('Instance compute service state on %s '
                   'expected to be down, but it was up.'), inst_host)
     raise exception.ComputeServiceInUse(host=inst_host)

I mean, evacuate() is an admin-only API call anyway. If an admin calls evacuate(), why do we even check to see if the host is down to begin with? Who cares. We should just execute the evacuate() procedure immediately.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-16 20:43:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Code-Review

Jay: It's a bit risky to just allow an evacuate at any time.  It really puts the onus on the admin to not screw up since if the original VM is still running on shared storage or boot-from-volume it could result in having two running VMs touching the same virtual disk.

Plus it could confuse networking since they're both trying to use the same IP address(es).

Lastly, even if we did allow evacuate at any time I think we would still want the ability to mark a compute service as "down" so that we don't waste time trying to schedule new instances onto the service.  (Again making the distinction between administratively available (enabled/disabled) and operationally available (up/down).)'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-17 05:25:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(8 comments)

I'm concerned that this is a little hacky, and intended to be implemented just as the shortest path to making the current service signaling think something is down sooner.

We have a service disabled flag, with a reason, and there is already an API to do this. Why would we not use that to do what this is intending to do, by just setting the service to disabled, with a reason of "unreachable" or "hardware failure"?'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2015-04-29 14:59:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

> We have a service disabled flag, with a reason, and there is already an API to do this. Why would we not use that to do what this is intending to do, by just setting the service to disabled, with a reason of "unreachable" or "hardware failure"?

IIRC, "service disabled" and "service down" are not treated as the same thing.  The evacuate code is checking to see if the service is down.  I think it can be up and disabled, and that still prevents evacuation from happening until it's seen as down, as that's the only thing this code has for trying to guess if the host is down.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:00:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

You mean evacuate will schedule to disabled hosts? I don't think that's the case, but if so, it's a bug. Or is there some aspect other than scheduling that matters?"}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:01:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Hi Dan,

I think we need to make a clear distinction between "administratively enabled/disabled" (which is governed by the service enabled/disabled status) and "operationally up/down".  There are valid reasons for having both and tracking them both separately.

So we currently have a way to administratively enable/disable a service.  Essentially the *only* effect this has is to prevent the scheduler from putting placing new instances on that compute service.

(For example, if you are administratively "disabled" but operationally "up" you wouldn't want to allow evacuations because there could be VMs running still.  In that case you could do controlled migrations off the "disabled" service.)

This feature is intended to add the ability to allow an external entity to mark a service as operationally disabled.  This would then cause nova to treat the service as operationally "down", which would then allow immediate evacuation of instances from that compute service.  In this case the service returns itself to an operationally "up" state.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:05:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

> You mean evacuate will schedule to disabled hosts? I don't think that's the case, but if so, it's a bug. Or is there some aspect other than scheduling that matters?

evacuate will not allow you evacuate *from* a host that is disabled, but still seen as up (it's used as an indication that the host is still running, meaning the VM is probably running, so evacuate doesn't make sense).

If the "service is up" check from evacuate is removed, then my personal reason for caring about this spec would be addressed.  We could just say it's the responsibility of whatever / whomever is managing OpenStack to make sure the host is down first.  Nova's check is a hack and not definitive anyway, so I don't see it as a big problem to remove it.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:08:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Okay, I'd be in favor of allowing evacuate if the service is marked as down, especially because it may mean we can do some preemptive deletes of the things that are doomed.

I'm also not opposed to having a separate flag for downed, but I think it needs to be implemented as a real flag and not a hack against the existing time-based approach."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:08:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

By re-thinking on the spec, I think the root problem is that evacuate can't work if the service is still considered as up. Removing that check would ease a lot operators for a very little price to pay for us so I would rather tend to propose to just leave a call to /os-services for marking the service as disabled and giving a reason is enough, provided the check is removed."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:13:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

> Okay, I'd be in favor of allowing evacuate if the service is marked as down,

I meant "disabled" here.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:16:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

So, the point is, we could maybe consider that if the evacuate API call mention a force flag, then the check could just be bypassed ? That sounds a quick and clean approach and that doesn't require to extend the service model by considering more than just disabled."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:19:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Or make the force=yes flag only work if the service is disabled.

However, I think we'd want to couple that with firing off delete requests to the compute node in case it's still up, just for the best hope of not breaking things if it's still running, or limping along."}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:23:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

It seems like it'd be really easy to corrupt things by manually evacuating before the other service is really dead.  (I'm less worried about automated recovery systems since they're likely to have some sort of STONITH/fencing.)

Given that nova internally has the concept of "operationally up", it seems odd that we don't have a way to tell it "I have external knowledge that the compute service is actually down".

Allowing evacuate from an "up" compute service seems like a hack--better to allow nova to act on the information it has, and provide a way to give it more accurate information.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:26:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

It seems to me that the delete requests would be problematic.  Either you make them RPC casts (in which case you don't know when they're actually going to get processed), or else you make them RPC calls (in which case you delay the evacuate if the compute service is actually down)."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:28:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Yeah, they'd be casts in this case.

In any case where we allow an external service to override our notion of whether things are down, we run the risk of things still running. If that service isn't fencing the node, then the risk is there. And, of course, the risk is there with our current implementation. A simple network partition, stuck tcp connection, or any other number of mundane occurrences will convince nova that it's okay to do the evacuation. Firing the delete casts down the tube before we do it is at least trying to avoid disaster."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-04-29 15:29:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

I think the delay over saftey is good.

This whole evacuate plan just seems a bit too half baked right now.

XenServer had a nice way of registering in shared storage a timestamp from the hypervisor so you can tell if the hypervisor is till "seeing" the share storage to try and limit split brain issues, dunno of that would help here, but it just all feels very worrying.'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-04-30 09:07:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

So it would be not to do new API to mark nova-compute down. Use the existing API to disable service and have the disabled_reason for what happened. Then for evacuate to work one would introduce the "force" flag so evacuation would work if nova-compute "disabled" while might be still reported "up". And scheduling would work properly as "disabled" wouldn't allow scheduling.

Ok, this would have things to work. Anyhow if one would like the evacuate to happen while the HW would actually be soon back up, one would need to again "enable" nova-compute when rebooted. If one would have had API to mark nova-compute down, it would have come back to "up" by itself when HW back online, which would have been a neat feature. Then if really more permanent fault, one would have put nova-compute to "disabled". Also there would have been nicer control for "operationally up/down" and "administratively enabled/disabled".

Point to continue would be now nice to decide (or was the agreement already here to go for "force" flag on evacuate), continue to discuss here, IRC or Vancouver.'}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2015-04-30 10:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2015-04-30 13:00:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

(3 comments)

I agree with Chris' statement here that in the case of a disabled service a controlled migration would be better, and evacuate should not be allowed.  Disabled, by virtue of not being down, has an implication that the host is still running.  Evacuate is a last ditch effort with potential data loss and should only be run in an extreme case.  If the host is in a situation to allow that it should have its state set appropriately."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-04-30 14:22:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)

The problem with disabled and regular migration is this:

The tool supposedly has already determined that the node is dead, and or has already fenced it. Thus, a controlled migration is not possible. If it were, that's what we'd do, but in the case of a total failure (or network partition or ...) that's not possible.

The original goal of this was to accelerate the state transition to "down" when we *know* that to be the case. I'm fine with such acceleration, but only if we make it a proper flag and not just hack the updated_at value to make it work. Hence my suggestion of re-using our disable+reason function that we already have and making evacuate allow it (with a forced flag).

Regardless, just using disabled+migration does not at all address the problem this spec is concerned with.'}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2015-04-30 14:47:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2015-04-30 15:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

I don't think we're disagreeing on this, or at least not strongly."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-05-01 18:07:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

@RusselB:

You wrote: "If the "service is up" check from evacuate is removed, then my personal reason for caring about this spec would be addressed. We could just say it's the responsibility of whatever / whomever is managing OpenStack to make sure the host is down first. Nova's check is a hack and not definitive anyway, so I don't see it as a big problem to remove it."

That was *exactly* what I had originally suggested as a solution in patch set 8:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/169836/8/specs/liberty/approved/report-host-fault-to-update-server-state-immediately.rst

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-05-08 06:42:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

Sure one can tackle evacuate with removing the check, but it is then only that. Then there might still be VMs scheduled to host and this and that state remains to be incorrect.

For NFV you have VNFM (user) that talks to VIM (Openstack) and then you would have separately external monitoring system in infra. State information is read by VNFM from VIM.

If in infra you have external system to monitor hosts and you want fast automated correlation to faults, you probably add for example some metadata already to instances by VNFM, so this external system could do auto evacuation, migration,.. However VNFM is also interested its VMs and reads all states from OpenStack. VNFM would be happy to know his VM is down. Here if you haven't had the external system a way to update all states, VNFM does not get right information about his VMs and also if nova-compute state is wrong VM might be scheduled to host that is down.

In my opinion states needs to be correct and OpenStack is here the central place where those states are. Therefore I would work to have API to have states correct fast. I was also to work with for example the VM power_state, so one already get indication on single VM level that maybe need to do something about it."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-05-08 23:14:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

Just my 2 cents,

I'm really not a fan of more modifications of the database service table when the service group concept seems to be in shambles as is.

See: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063602.html

Nothing against this spec (or its authors), but it really feels like we should stop adding more functionality to a foundation that isn't very well designed and is on shakey grounds with the existing features that already exist."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-05-08 23:27:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

(3 comments)

Right now, the db service implementation is what is most widely-deployed. The issues with it are well-known, but I think we're a long ways away from saying that something else is either a formal dependency or the preferred mechanism for deployment.

IMHO, we *should* add this force-down thing, not only because it's mostly the API that we care about and we need to implement it in the db service driver so that people can actually use it now."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-05-09 15:23:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

Fair enough, all that I'm saying is adding more things to a foundation that is in shambles (and only works with 1 driver) will not exactly make that transition to something that does work (aka repairing the whole service group mess) that much easier. But I understand the need for fixing problems that exist in the *now* and the conflict of fixing with hacks vs fixing the foundation. It's not my decision anyway in the end (obviously)."}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2015-05-10 12:14:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(3 comments)

So it seems, that for os-services part, there is no difference between the v2 and v2.1 - the api calls looks exactly the same. Should we change the convention for this single API call, make it coherent, or make them all more RESTful?'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2015-05-11 11:07:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-11 11:11:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Verified+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I think this is close. A few more corrections inline.

Just to be clear, I think this is really important for us to merge in this cycle. As more and more people try to make OpenStack HA, if we don't have this we're going to have people wanting to build HA into nova itself, which we have previously said isn't in scope. Merging this gives us a clear answer for "how you do this".'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-01 16:43:48.000000000', 'message': 'State of compute node and instances running on it should be changed
down by new API when host fault detected by external tool.

When a server goes down because of a host hardware, OS or hypervisor error,
the server state remains as operational in OpenStack API.

A new API is needed to report a host fault to change the state of the
instances and compute node immediately. This allows usage of evacuate API
without a delay. The new API provides the possibility for external monitoring
system to detect any kind of host failure fast and reliably and inform
OpenStack about it. Nova updates the compute node state and states of the
instances. This way the states in the Nova DB will be in sync with the
real state of the system.

Change-Id: I612582ba7b70bb6d167aa68bdfc47faa3b7b85ed
Implements: blueprint update-server-state-immediately

commit_message:
New nova API call to mark nova-compute down

New API call is needed to change the state of compute service 'down'
immediately. This allows usage of evacuate API without a delay. Also as
external system will make sure host is down and no VMs left running, there
will be no possibility to break shared storage or use same IPs again. API
usage applies mainly for cases where there is single host mapped to
nova-compute. Cases like in Ironic or vSphere would be out of scope.

APIImpact

Change-Id: I612582ba7b70bb6d167aa68bdfc47faa3b7b85ed
Implements: blueprint mark-host-down

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-14 20:32:55.000000000', 'message': "Add versioning to Agent decommission

As the agent will likely be rebooting while decommissioning (to apply BIOS/
firmware upgrades), it is possible the version of the agent will change
between boots. Including a version string in the Hardware Manager allows
the Hardware Manager builder to bump versions for any breaking changes.
I recommend that the entire decommission process be restarted if there
is a version mismatch, but that will be up to individual drivers to
implement.

This change also adds a new return value for Agent REST commands called
'DECOM_VERSION_MISMATCH' that will signal no command was run, and
Ironic should update its stored value. A 'hardware_manager_version'
will be returned with AsyncCommandResult, and should be set in the
Ironic driver_info field and sent with any decommission command.

Change-Id: I2ae0e93573e0348f023aa124a07bb16921b5c53e

commit_message:
Add versioning to Agent decommission

As the agent will likely be rebooting while decommissioning (to apply BIOS/
firmware upgrades), it is possible the version of the agent will change
between boots. Including a version string in the Hardware Manager allows
the Hardware Manager builder to bump versions for any breaking changes.
I recommend that the entire decommission process be restarted if there
is a version mismatch, but that will be up to individual drivers to
implement.

This change also adds a new return value for Agent REST commands called
'DECOM_VERSION_MISMATCH' that will signal no command was run, and
Ironic should update its stored value. A 'hardware_manager_version'
will be returned with AsyncCommandResult, and should be set in the
Ironic driver_info field and sent with any decommission command.

Change-Id: I2ae0e93573e0348f023aa124a07bb16921b5c53e

subject: Adding support for decommissioning

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-02 23:51:15.000000000', 'message': 'Adding support for decommissioning

The pluggable hardware manager should be able be used for decommissioning,
such as erasing disks, updating firmwares, changing BIOS settings, and
anything else specific hardware needs. This works with the agent driver
to store state in Ironic and request out of band reboots (which may be
required to make BIOS/firmware updates work).

Change-Id: Ia42a8e75d2b8887b2351de97c2137fe21a7f4041

'}, {'created': '2014-09-15 22:08:52.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for decommissioning

The pluggable hardware manager should be able be used for decommissioning,
such as erasing disks, updating firmwares, changing BIOS settings, and
anything else specific hardware needs. This works with the agent driver
to store state in Ironic and request out of band reboots (which may be
required to make BIOS/firmware updates work). Also allows the agent to do
some basic verification of the node's properties, to ensure they haven't
changed, such as a stick of memory dying.

Change-Id: Ia42a8e75d2b8887b2351de97c2137fe21a7f4041

commit_message:
Adding support for decommissioning

The pluggable hardware manager should be able be used for decommissioning,
such as erasing disks, updating firmwares, changing BIOS settings, and
anything else specific hardware needs. This works with the agent driver
to store state in Ironic and request out of band reboots (which may be
required to make BIOS/firmware updates work). Also allows the agent to do
some basic verification of the node's properties, to ensure they haven't
changed, such as a stick of memory dying.

Change-Id: Ia42a8e75d2b8887b2351de97c2137fe21a7f4041

commit_message:
Extract helper method to get image metadata from volume

This refactoring needs for futher review(-s).
First is here - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/170243
But it will be divided to separate reviews and some refactoring
should be done first.

commit_message:
Generate a SHA-2 certificate for Horizon

SHA-1 certificates are being deprecated and browsers are starting to
issue warnings about their use. We should begin generating SHA-2
certificates for Horizon.

Closes-bug: 1461983
Change-Id: I7f1933680e2859e007f6b8be262852b164f90b33

commit_message:
Revert "remove POSIX users, groups and file modes"

This reverts commit 2abad789290be9f9b5f06e7eac40b438748de84e.

This fixes issues in running the PKI setup which
requires the keystone user resource.

Change-Id: I8a9bd0cdc157430ade254650ceb1d77a72cda278
Closes-bug: 1463540

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 10:53:46.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: fix live migration handling of disk_info

Previous commmit:

  commit a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c
  Author: Joel Coffman <joel.coffman@jhuapl.edu>
  Date:   Fri Apr 24 16:14:25 2015 -0400

    libvirt: Remove unnecessary JSON conversions

Changes the '_create_images_and_backing' method to take a
dict instead of a JSON string for the 'disk_info' parameter.
Unfortunately it only updated one of the callers, so the
migration code was still passing a JSON string.

This wasn't caught because all the unit tests were broken,
mistakenly passing a dict instead of a json string to the
pre_live_migration method, and the _create_images_and_backing
method was stubbed out with a mock, so never ran. Add a
check on the parameters to the _create_images_and_backing
mock to ensure it is given a dict, and not a json string.

Change-Id: I6a8f009bb21bce9e6408ebc4508094bdcbef05c5
Closes-bug: #1463747
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: fix live migration handling of disk_info

Previous commmit:

  commit a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c
  Author: Joel Coffman <joel.coffman@jhuapl.edu>
  Date:   Fri Apr 24 16:14:25 2015 -0400

    libvirt: Remove unnecessary JSON conversions

Changes the '_create_images_and_backing' method to take a
dict instead of a JSON string for the 'disk_info' parameter.
Unfortunately it only updated one of the callers, so the
migration code was still passing a JSON string.

This wasn't caught because all the unit tests were broken,
mistakenly passing a dict instead of a json string to the
pre_live_migration method, and the _create_images_and_backing
method was stubbed out with a mock, so never ran. Add a
check on the parameters to the _create_images_and_backing
mock to ensure it is given a dict, and not a json string.

Change-Id: I6a8f009bb21bce9e6408ebc4508094bdcbef05c5
Closes-bug: #1463747

commit_message:
Add release notes for 0.19.0

Changes included in this release:

    $ git log 0.18.0..HEAD --no-merges --oneline
    dfa98ab Updated from global requirements
    6cb26fc Include owner and status option in v2 image list
    5d933b0 Fix Metadef Object update issue with python-glanceclient
    9f5c581 Fix functional tests in gate
    1686d6a Do not crash on homedir mkdir
    1f89beb Improve import related error handling
    583adc3 Check image-download for redirection
    9c172fb Add some basic CLI functional tests
    bf413a6 Use assertIn instead of assertTrue in tests
    6431fae Unorder compare in tests
    5fa71aa Add release notes for 0.18.0
    6d31116 Update README to work with release tools
    71d9783 Create functional test base
    f2a8a52 Move unit tests to standard directory
    f931a20 Fixed doc example

Co-Authored-By: Louis Taylor <louis@kragniz.eu>

commit_message:
Revert "Replace pip-installed requests CA bundle with link"

This does not gracefully handle the situation where requests
is not there at the beginning. Needs to be rethought.

This reverts commit 7d350720fe5d25fece68c5d1625a33a6cad431ef.

Change-Id: I101fac0dc6fdc97b7fb0b2955cffc6b4905152e5

[{'created': '2015-04-30 23:28:07.000000000', 'message': "Merge tag '2015.1.0'

Ceilometer 2015.1.0

Change-Id: I3c81175c88744eed642b2448ae92ad822f0b9b36
"}, {'created': '2015-06-09 17:47:00.000000000', 'message': "Merge tag '2015.1.0'

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: I3c81175c88744eed642b2448ae92ad822f0b9b36
"}]
commit_message:
Merge tag '2015.1.0'

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: I3c81175c88744eed642b2448ae92ad822f0b9b36

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for network_get_associated_fixed_ips

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
network_get_associated_fixed_ips.

It is called by the follow function:
  1. get_dhcp_leases, the contex is admin context
  2. init_host, the contex is admin context
  3. update_dhcp, it is called by:
     _setup_network_on_host, context is elevated
     _teardown_network_on_host, context is elevated
  4. update_dns it is call by
     _periodic_update_dns
     allocate_for_instance, it is fixed by
       https://review.openstack.org/#/c/150687
     deallocate_for_instance, it is called by
       _local_delete, context is elevated
     _deallocate_network, it is called by
       _build_instance, context is elevated
       _try_deallocate_network, context is elevated
       _cleanup_allocated_networks
  5. objects.Network.in_use_on_host
     deallocate_for_instance, it is called by
       _local_delete, context is elevated
     remove_fixed_ip_from_instance, it is called by _remove_fixed_ip

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: Ic28ab566d083f30e2749361bd80f6f446e73a93d

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-22 01:48:06.000000000', 'message': "Object: Fix incorrect parameter set in flavor save_extra_specs

In save_extra_specs, we pass to_add, and it's default value is None,
we have:
    to_add = to_add if to_add is not None else []
but seen from db.flavor_extra_specs_update_or_create, to_add should be a dict
instead of a list.

Change-Id: Ia60514c54f7ba473cc7c58b6c4a10779bafd15d0
"}]
commit_message:
Object: Fix incorrect parameter set in flavor save_extra_specs

In save_extra_specs, we pass to_add, and it's default value is None,
we have:
    to_add = to_add if to_add is not None else []
but seen from db.flavor_extra_specs_update_or_create, to_add should be a dict
instead of a list.

Change-Id: Ia60514c54f7ba473cc7c58b6c4a10779bafd15d0

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for floating_ips_bulk

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
floating_ips_bulk and add policy checking test for API layer.

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: Ia6e8ee37af82a934581f8ecccd320136a6774916

So there are a couple of things that I don't like very much in this script as it is:
- it uses tempest conf - which means we actually have to set admin creds in tempest to create the accounts... and remove them later? This script should behave more like python clients and accept credentials as CLI parameters. Whether credentials needs to be created, whether network resources are needed, is something devstack should figure out based on its local.conf.
- it always creates v2 credentials - it should allow for the creation of both v2 and v3 creds

I would prefer fixing this two things above first, but if this change is urgent I won't oppose it, conf dependencies can still be removed later."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2015-06-10 02:12:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Andrea's points are reasonable for me, these points will make the command more useful.

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-08 17:32:42.000000000', 'message': 'Add tenant network creation to account creation script

The script will now create a tenant network for each account in the same
way as the isolated creds code creates networks. In this case we always
create all network resource options since each test account could run a test
that requires any one of them. The accounts will only be created if neutron
is available and the user did not set auth.create_isolated_networks to
False.

Partially implements: blueprint test-accounts-continued

Change-Id: Id3b626b66f797e32e18f4d1771561a1db5ecd26c
'}]
commit_message:
Add tenant network creation to account creation script

The script will now create a tenant network for each account in the same
way as the isolated creds code creates networks. In this case we always
create all network resource options since each test account could run a test
that requires any one of them. The accounts will only be created if neutron
is available and the user did not set auth.create_isolated_networks to
False.

Partially implements: blueprint test-accounts-continued

Change-Id: Id3b626b66f797e32e18f4d1771561a1db5ecd26c

commit_message:
Generate a SHA-2 certificate for Horizon

SHA-1 certificates are being deprecated and browsers are starting to
issue warnings about their use. We should begin generating SHA-2
certificates for Horizon.

Closes-bug: 1461983
Change-Id: I7f1933680e2859e007f6b8be262852b164f90b33
(cherry picked from commit ed29e8a3d9e9f102158e35f8b0ea7bd3ef278327)
(cherry picked from commit dc862c803c6e9839f814ba31f2a2271b9d356611)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 14:07:00.000000000', 'message': 'Remove the surplus comma, it breaks the tempest tests

Because of that comma devstack believes that multiple backends are
configured (lib/tempest:454); so the multi-backend tests are run,
and consequently fail.

Change-Id: I6718757a3399496f4f7bfc9d482714590bca0603
'}]
commit_message:
Remove the surplus comma, it breaks the tempest tests

Because of that comma devstack believes that multiple backends are
configured (lib/tempest:454); so the multi-backend tests are run,
and consequently fail.

Change-Id: I6718757a3399496f4f7bfc9d482714590bca0603

commit_message:
add experimental job for integration testing with rake on chef cookbooks

- added experimental job template 'gate-{name}-chef-rake-integration' to the queue to start
  the building of integration layer tests for the openstack chef cookbooks
- this job has to stay in 'experimental' until all cookbooks include working
  and reliable rake tasks for integration testing and will be moved
  afterwards to 'check' and 'gate'
- modified regex to filter all chef-rake jobs depending on the branch

Change-Id: I17b07d86a0d8c502cba241c943bcbd8efccdc694

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 14:42:28.000000000', 'message': "Hyper-V: Fix instance event handler

The listener currently used by the instance event handler records
all WMI instance object changes, even though we only care about
power state changes.

For this reason, we currently record the last emited power state
change in order to see whether the power state actually changed
before emiting a new change.

This is problematic and unreliable. When the instance is created,
it will be powered off. If anything changes, the current
implementation will emit a power off event, having no previous
recorded state. For this reason, the manager can consider that the
the instance was unexpectedly powered off, calling the stop
API, which is highly undesirable.

This patch fixes the issue by constructing a WQL query used by the
event listener in order to catch events only in case the instance
actually transitioned into one of the states that we're interested
in.

Change-Id: I7efe33d8f4d8df44a09ac3c0ac3e29c2947fe67c
Closes-Bug: #1463814
(cherry picked from commit 490dfdd3167e27a38bb84299bb57350a11d846d4)
"}]
commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fix instance event handler

The listener currently used by the instance event handler records
all WMI instance object changes, even though we only care about
power state changes.

For this reason, we currently record the last emited power state
change in order to see whether the power state actually changed
before emiting a new change.

This is problematic and unreliable. When the instance is created,
it will be powered off. If anything changes, the current
implementation will emit a power off event, having no previous
recorded state. For this reason, the manager can consider that the
the instance was unexpectedly powered off, calling the stop
API, which is highly undesirable.

This patch fixes the issue by constructing a WQL query used by the
event listener in order to catch events only in case the instance
actually transitioned into one of the states that we're interested
in.

Change-Id: I7efe33d8f4d8df44a09ac3c0ac3e29c2947fe67c
Closes-Bug: #1463814
(cherry picked from commit 490dfdd3167e27a38bb84299bb57350a11d846d4)

commit_message:
Change defaultbranch in .gitreview

This is a branch-only change to make sure anybody
working on the branch will push to the right one.

Change-Id: I2d35d0659bd3f06c570ba99e8b8a41b620253e75

commit_message:
cleanup sahara docs in devref folder

de-capitalized sahara to comply w/ doc conventions
changed plugin to plug-in per doc conventions
de-capitalized titles to comply w/ conventions
doc conventions can be found at below link
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Conventions
Closes-Bug: #1448372

Change-Id: I8888f2c8969cfa6261351e44e6a6a35e986778d1

- gate-sahara-tox-bandit http://logs.openstack.org/23/177523/8/check/gate-sahara-tox-bandit/86fbfe4/ : FAILURE in 1m 45s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 7125, 'date': '2015-06-08 13:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Some concerns about "plugin/plug-in" words:

I think it's ok to call plugins as "Plugins" without "-". We get used to write "plugin" word and there is no mistake in my opinion. Proof link in wiktionary:

http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plugin

Also a lot of OpenStack components use this word as Sahara community:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron_Plugins_and_Drivers

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Heat/Plugins'}, {'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2015-06-09 12:41:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

I really don't like changing "plugin" to "plug-in" in all places in Sahara. And even if we'll be going to change it, it should be changed first in Sahara itself, not in docs.

Re decapitalizations done in this CR, in many places it's done for the frameworks, projects and objects names, what's the reasoning?'}, {'account_id': 9382, 'date': '2015-06-10 14:56:44.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
made a number of changes to sahara docs

corrected a number of things
distrbuted should be distributed
availibility should be availability
intance should be instance
decapitalized sahara to comply with doc conventions
changed plugin to plug-in per doc conventions
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Conventions
Closes-Bug: #1448372

Change-Id: I9704f82a1a0831195286a7c8de65e79f9e30e048

commit_message:
Instructions to resolve an openSUSE 13.2 dependency conflict

Adds a note with instructions to respond to a pattern dependency
conflict when a minimal server install is used.

Modified: replaced the note with a simpler instruction to remove
the offending package in the Basic Environment section of the
Install Guide.

Change-Id: I2ad6c8cf7ce76fa42950e51f267224cd8142199c
Closes-bug: #1462624
Backport: Kilo

'location of you accounts.yaml'.

commit_message:
Make required function arguments explicit

Instead of retrieving a value from `*args` as `*args[0]`
unconditionally, add the required argument (`context`) as a standard
named argument to the function prototype.

Change-Id: I979e7f5c0101353cb9c1819bde0e5051e2ce90c7

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 12:42:59.000000000', 'message': "Hyper-V: Fix instance event handler

The listener currently used by the instance event handler records
all WMI instance object changes, even though we only care about
power state changes.

For this reason, we currently record the last emited power state
change in order to see whether the power state actually changed
before emiting a new change.

This is problematic and unreliable. When the instance is created,
it will be powered off. If anything changes, the current
implementation will emit a power off event, having no previous
recorded state. For this reason, the manager can consider that the
the instance was unexpectedly powered off, calling the stop
API, which is highly undesirable.

This patch fixes the issue by constructing a WQL query used by the
event listener in order to catch events only in case the instance
actually transitioned into one of the states that we're interested
in.

Change-Id: I7efe33d8f4d8df44a09ac3c0ac3e29c2947fe67c
Closes-Bug: #1463814
"}]
commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fix instance event handler

The listener currently used by the instance event handler records
all WMI instance object changes, even though we only care about
power state changes.

For this reason, we currently record the last emited power state
change in order to see whether the power state actually changed
before emiting a new change.

This is problematic and unreliable. When the instance is created,
it will be powered off. If anything changes, the current
implementation will emit a power off event, having no previous
recorded state. For this reason, the manager can consider that the
the instance was unexpectedly powered off, calling the stop
API, which is highly undesirable.

This patch fixes the issue by constructing a WQL query used by the
event listener in order to catch events only in case the instance
actually transitioned into one of the states that we're interested
in.

Change-Id: I7efe33d8f4d8df44a09ac3c0ac3e29c2947fe67c
Closes-Bug: #1463814
