revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 13:03:15.000000000', 'message': 'Fix QoS issues caused by unsupported OS versions

Disk QoS is not available on versions prior to WS 2012 R2.

Because of this and the fact that the driver attempts to set IOPS
limits even if those are not specified, spawning instances currently
fails when using previous HyperV versions.

This patch fixes the issues by skipping setting QoS specs when
this feature is not supported, logging a warning.

Closes-Bug: #1463317

Change-Id: I086f3a034ffcc56a09a5ecf3e9a142cc86e67c41
(cherry picked from commit b97666aa6d897280a6a31d5ff6fd8d9eab3b7a4d)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix QoS issues caused by unsupported OS versions

Disk QoS is not available on versions prior to WS 2012 R2.

Because of this and the fact that the driver attempts to set IOPS
limits even if those are not specified, spawning instances currently
fails when using previous HyperV versions.

This patch fixes the issues by skipping setting QoS specs when
this feature is not supported, logging a warning.

Closes-Bug: #1463317

Change-Id: I086f3a034ffcc56a09a5ecf3e9a142cc86e67c41
(cherry picked from commit b97666aa6d897280a6a31d5ff6fd8d9eab3b7a4d)

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fix missing WMI namespace issue on Windows 2008 R2

The Hyper-V driver uses the Microsoft\Windows\SMB WMI namespace
in order to handle SMB shares. The issue is that this namespace is
not available on Windows versions prior to Windows Server 2012.

For this reason, the Hyper-V driver fails to initialize on Windows
Server 2008 R2.

This patch fixes the issue by properly handling the PathUtils
initialization.

Closes-Bug: #1463044
Change-Id: Ia99576589af6049ee07337c631ed7d5d6cf602d9
(cherry picked from commit 1de39b99ac144698a1ea0e01bd17d8fc6c78298d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 06:53:08.000000000', 'message': "Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volume container

The current configuration of LVM for cinder-volume has udev_sync=0.
This means that udev is not creating the devices that appear in /dev.
The device files created reference specific device numbers, and these
persist between reboots. When the host is rebooted there is no
guarantee that device numbers allocated to the logical volumes will
match those defined in the device files. This can be observed by
comparing the output of 'dmsetup info' and 'ls -l /dev/mapper'.

LVM's use of udev was disabled in an attempt to protect the host from
the potential that uevents generated would be processed by all
containers on the host. In practise this should not be an issue because
there are not other containers running on a cinder host.

This commit adjusts the lvm.conf file created so that udev is used. It
also adds a mount entry to create a devtmpfs on /dev. Finally
'udevadm trigger' is run to add the devices under /dev/mapper.
Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0
(cherry picked from commit 6ba292a295ab2e7effeefd053802e6afadd0ab9e)
"}]
commit_message:
Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volume container

The current configuration of LVM for cinder-volume has udev_sync=0.
This means that udev is not creating the devices that appear in /dev.
The device files created reference specific device numbers, and these
persist between reboots. When the host is rebooted there is no
guarantee that device numbers allocated to the logical volumes will
match those defined in the device files. This can be observed by
comparing the output of 'dmsetup info' and 'ls -l /dev/mapper'.

LVM's use of udev was disabled in an attempt to protect the host from
the potential that uevents generated would be processed by all
containers on the host. In practise this should not be an issue because
there are not other containers running on a cinder host.

This commit adjusts the lvm.conf file created so that udev is used. It
also adds a mount entry to create a devtmpfs on /dev. Finally
'udevadm trigger' is run to add the devices under /dev/mapper.
Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0
(cherry picked from commit 6ba292a295ab2e7effeefd053802e6afadd0ab9e)

commit_message:
Remove deprecated WritableLogger

WritableLogger from oslo.log is deprecated and with eventlet >= 0.17.2
we can directly pass the logger instance.

Change-Id: I862b31acb710c31ce55cd90a55e4fea41f046c50
Closes-Bug: #1440773

commit_message:
Make Docker resource available by default

Related blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/mos/+spec/murano-docker-based-applications
Implements blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/mos/+spec/heat-docker-resource-by-default 

Change-Id: I3102a579fb7c9aebb69fb852dfe4192d089b754f

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2015-05-29 02:24:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

So on Python 2, StringIO.StringIO will accept unicode or bytes [1] while io.StringIO (on Python 2 and Python 3) is only for unicode [2].

Personally, I think we should be using the appropriate io.*IO classes so we don't have to figure this out in X years when we drop Python 2.7. I know that means we can't autogenerate the patch, but I'm not very worried about that personally. I'll update in a separate patch if you'd rather that Victor.


[1]: https://docs.python.org/2/library/stringio.html#StringIO.StringIO
[2]: https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/io.html#io.StringIO"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-29 09:30:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-06-10 09:33:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-06-10 09:37:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Personally, I think we should be using the appropriate io.*IO classes
> (...)
> I know that means we can't autogenerate the patch, but I'm not very worried about that personally. I'll update in a separate patch if you'd rather that Victor.

Yeah, I chose to write patches with the least impacts on Python 2. Replacing StringIO.StringIO with six.StringIO has no impact on performances, since six.StringIO *is* StringIO.StringIO on Python 2.

Using io is a different thing. On Python 2.6, the io module is written in pure Python and it's very slow. Well, StringIO is also implemented in pure Python and cStringIO can be used instead for better performances ;-)

So yes, please write a new patch based on mine. I prefer to restrict this patch to adding Python 3 support."}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-06-10 09:38:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Note: Patch set 4 is a rebase. Other Python 3 patches were merged, I had to fix some conflicts.'}, {'account_id': 11356, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:36:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I think the best thing to do here is to just get minimal py34 support, then we can add patches on top of that to do the 'better' stuff (io.*IO)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:37:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

commit_message:
Use six.moves to fix imports on Python 3

* Use six.moves to get builtins, configparser, http_client
  and urllib modules
* Replace StringIO.StringIO with six.StringIO
* Replace reload(mod) with moves.reload_module(mod)

Patch generated by the six_moves, stringio and urllib operations of the
sixer tool version 0.4:
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/sixer

Manual changes:

* test_vmware_store: add _mock_http_connection() helper method to
  factorize code mocking http_client.HTTPConnection
* Reformat some lines to respect the constraint of 80 columns
* Replace reload() with imp.reload_module()
* Replace httplib with six.moves.http_client in mock.patch()

Change-Id: I5a065c0778436a12db90ac3b929fa840f3e86665

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 13:36:43.000000000', 'message': "Preserve data types in Hiera where possible

We didn't preserve the data types from Heat metadata when writing hiera
files. We treated the metadata as raw YAML, unless it was multiline, in
which case we wrapped it in quotes.

This commit fixes those things as much as possible:

* Proper JSON escaping is preserved for multi-line strings.

* Other data types such as arrays and hashes are properly passed into
  hiera, regardless if their string representation would be single-line
  or multi-line.

However, single-line strings are still treated as raw YAML, because
tripleo-heat-templates already depend on that behavior (instead of
having arrays in Heat metadata, we have strings there formatted as
arrays).

Change-Id: Ie984f3c7782687235cdc2d72ef1f94af89dc3ed4
Closes-Bug: #1462369
"}]
commit_message:
Preserve data types in Hiera where possible

We didn't preserve the data types from Heat metadata when writing hiera
files. We treated the metadata as raw YAML, unless it was multiline, in
which case we wrapped it in quotes.

This commit fixes those things as much as possible:

* Proper JSON escaping is preserved for multi-line strings.

* Other data types such as arrays and hashes are properly passed into
  hiera, regardless if their string representation would be single-line
  or multi-line.

However, single-line strings are still treated as raw YAML, because
tripleo-heat-templates already depend on that behavior (instead of
having arrays in Heat metadata, we have strings there formatted as
arrays).

Change-Id: Ie984f3c7782687235cdc2d72ef1f94af89dc3ed4
Closes-Bug: #1462369

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-09 00:53:22.000000000', 'message': "Add Crypto/HSM MKEK Rotation Support (Light)

Currently Barbican has no means to migrate secrets encrypted with a
crypto/HSM-style plugin to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and
its associated wrapped project KEKs. This blueprint proposes adding a
new Barbican service process that supports completing the rotation
process by re-wrapping the project KEKs with the new MKEK. Note that
unlike the similarly-named blueprint at
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/add-crypto-mkek-rotation-support,
this blueprint does *not* call for re-encrypting secrets and is
therefore this blueprint is a 'lightweight' alternative to that
blueprint. Comparing the two approaches, this lightweight one should
process more quickly when there are many secrets with numerous
project-IDs stored in the database. The downside to the lightweight
approach is that if the old MKEK was compromised *and* the attacker has
access to backup versions of the database, they could decrypt current
secrets since they could then decrypt the unchanged project KEK used to
encrypt the secret, and because the encrypted secret data is unchanged
and so can be decrypted by the now-unwrapped project KEK. Similar to
the other blueprint, this process would be started after deployers, out
of band: (1) generate new MKEK and HMAC signing keys with a binding to
new labels, and then (2) replicate these keys to other HSMs that may be
in the high availability (HA) group, and then (3) update Barbican's
config file to reference these new labels, and finally (4) restart the
Barbican nodes. The proposed process would then re-wrap the project
KEKs with the new MKEKs, updating the associated project KEK records
with the new wrapped project KEKs.

Change-Id: Ic35dc0fbd98a38c560a2e9cf8bd0b01325914646
"}, {'created': '2015-05-11 05:13:13.000000000', 'message': "Add Crypto/HSM MKEK Rotation Support (Light)

then re-wrap the project KEKs with the new MKEKs, updating the

Change-Id: Ic35dc0fbd98a38c560a2e9cf8bd0b01325914646

commit_message:
Add Crypto/HSM MKEK Rotation Support (Light)

Currently Barbican has no means to migrate secrets encrypted with a
crypto/HSM-style plugin to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and
its associated wrapped project KEKs. This blueprint proposes adding a
new Barbican service process that supports completing the rotation
process by re-wrapping the project KEKs with the new MKEK.

Note that unlike the similarly-named blueprint at
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/add-crypto-mkek-rotation-support,
this blueprint does *not* call for re-encrypting secrets and is
therefore this blueprint is a 'lightweight' alternative to that
blueprint.

Similar to the other blueprint, this process would be started after
deployers, out of band: (1) generate new MKEK and HMAC signing keys
with a binding to new labels, and then (2) replicate these keys to
other HSMs that may be in the high availability (HA) group, and then
(3) update Barbican's config file to reference these new labels, and
finally (4) restart the Barbican nodes. The proposed process would
then re-wrap the project KEKs with the new MKEKs, updating the
associated project KEK records with the new wrapped project KEKs.

Change-Id: Ic35dc0fbd98a38c560a2e9cf8bd0b01325914646

subject: Initial commit of the specs of a port-forwarding extension for the neutron router.
messages:
[{'account_id': 13067, 'date': '2015-03-24 10:42:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2015-03-24 10:42:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-24 10:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

Seems like this is the same as https://review.openstack.org/#/c/158213/, at least in theory.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2015-04-26 11:38:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Agree with Kyle. I hope you jump in the review of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/158213/ and discuss with the author on how to collaborate your effort. We don't necessarily adopt first-in approach for feature proposal, but the similar feature was proposed in a month, so I would suggest you two coordinate the effort. Discussing a spec in a single review helps reviewers especially."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-06-05 01:12:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Since this is already it's own stackforge project (see 970262a9ec4d71ef5ee2f1435e808fa70708c553), I don't think we need this here anymore."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-06-10 14:02:32.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

commit_message:
Start and stop n-net with n-cpu for partial upgrades

In a real environment, n-net will be co-located with n-cpu, and
upgraded at the same time. For the sake of expediency, this patch
makes n-cpu and n-net be started and stopped at the same time as
"the compute family of services." Grenade's existing partial upgrade
support will still apply, and we'll get a more realistic test.

Since grenade uses devstack old to do the shutdown, we need to backport
this patch to Kilo to make the Kilo -> master (Liberty) job work.

Change-Id: I7a2f3ee9c74b34fdf003f65f4936074a236784c2
(cherry picked from commit 18e9151b03583ba2426e95fc74d1733633777eb0)

This reverts commit a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c.

a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c is causing live migrate to

Closes-Bug: #1463747
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "libvirt: Remove unnecessary JSON conversions"

This reverts commit a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c.

a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c is causing live migrate to
fail. Live migration is now tested by check-tempest-dsvm-multinode-full.

Since this patch has landed no multinode jobs have worked, and the first
n-cpu stacktrace related to this bug was found on patch a7a0b4.

Change-Id: I61dbc60ceab0578c2e65ac5449b801a7ffbb6f5f
Closes-Bug: #1463747

commit_message:
Update README with missing usage changes

The README's usage section hadn't been updated in a while and did
not include some changes made in the past few commits.  These
include:
- csv and xml output format
- config file default location
- edit to context line description

Change-Id: I075c14df29c3abe668bb215b1ca9f799110cf782

Update project-team-guide groups

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-09 21:02:36.000000000', 'message': "Add swig packages

python-qpid-proton does something similar to pyzmq when libzmq is not
installed. It bundles the underlying library and builds it.
Unfortunately, python-qpid-proton currently has a dependency on `swig`
to build the python module. I'm adding swig to the list of packages to
install by default.

Change-Id: I562bec25df1addd1d8104811882de136eb72180f
"}]
commit_message:
Add swig packages

python-qpid-proton does something similar to pyzmq when libzmq is not
installed. It bundles the underlying library and builds it.
Unfortunately, python-qpid-proton currently has a dependency on `swig`
to build the python module. I'm adding swig to the list of packages to
install by default.

Change-Id: I562bec25df1addd1d8104811882de136eb72180f

commit_message:
Announce diskimage-builder in infra channel

Pinging people in two different channels to talk about changes is
starting to get crazymaking. Infra uses diskimage-builder and lands
paches to it for infra purposes. Let's watch the patches to it until
they become insane.

Change-Id: I0568ba0751f6d1a59d8bfb24de485bd4ddec0ad6

commit_message:
jenkins/jobs/tripleo/puppet: drop puppet-openstack

puppet-openstack module is not used at all by TripleO/Puppet. It's not
useful to have it in our OpenStack modules list.

Change-Id: I058d0622e505e8ca4268946c61e78c714c0aa025

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-03 20:27:34.000000000', 'message': "networking-ovn: Allow setting devstack-gate env vars

I recently added the ability to have pre and post gate hook scripts in
networking-ovn.  What I really wanted this for was to be able to set
DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_REGEX in the pre hook script.  It turns out this
doesn't actually work like I expected.  It seems fine to leave the
hooks for future use, but add a new call to a script to setup some env
vars before calling devstack-gate.

Change-Id: I67dceb8087d60e1bfc9d6402edcbbe5f5026fcba
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
networking-ovn: Allow setting devstack-gate env vars

I recently added the ability to have pre and post gate hook scripts in
networking-ovn.  What I really wanted this for was to be able to set
DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_REGEX in the pre hook script.  It turns out this
doesn't actually work like I expected.  It seems fine to leave the
hooks for future use, but add a new call to a script to setup some env
vars before calling devstack-gate.

Change-Id: I67dceb8087d60e1bfc9d6402edcbbe5f5026fcba
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Disable future parser check on puppet-swift (juno)

The puppet-future-syntax check runs a puppet 3 parser with the future
parser option turned on in preparation for migrating to puppet 4.
Unfortunately, it fails on the stable/juno branch of the puppet-swift
module[1]. The fix has been committed in master[2] but cannot be
backported because it would break the API. The only way to continue
development on the stable/juno branch is to disable this check and
accept that the Juno version of the puppet-swift module is not
future-parser or puppet 4 compatible.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/52/188952/1/check/gate-puppet-swift-puppet-syntax-future/1207ef3/console.html.gz#_2015-06-05_22_21_20_293
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/137187/

Change-Id: Id4295f0410b5f9f7acc568694811cd3dba6cae52

commit_message:
Sync puppet concat module to v1.2.2 from upstream

v1.2.2 sha1: 2d5734c2976933dd5332059c503cc92ee23121fd

Concat 1.1.0 has idempotancy bug described at
https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/MODULES-1311. Due to this bug
apache restarts everytime when we invoke radosgw granule

Partial-Bug: 1455389

Change-Id: Ibec45e3816774b9a4d7c1ce67b699cbff0cdf9ab
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

subject: Get mox from mox3, not from six.moves
messages:
[{'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2015-06-10 11:47:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-06-10 12:09:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

> oslotest 1.7.0 breakes oslo.messaging unittests, because it doesn't add mox to six.moves anymore - see change Ic59c73abb9b09cb594bf7df4173d7f99f81d526c

In fact, oslo.messaging already started to use directly mox3 instead of mox with the change Iaa22779cd516f842c9f70828f863f90ddae0bab5. six.moves was used to avoid mox3 on Python 2. Since mox3 is now also installed on Python 2, this change looks good to me."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2015-06-10 12:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 12:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

commit_message:
Get mox from mox3, not from six.moves

oslotest 1.7.0 breakes oslo.messaging unittests, because it doesn't add
mox to six.moves anymore - see change Ic59c73abb9b09cb594bf7df4173d7f99f81d526c

This patch fixes imports on test run.

[{'created': '2015-06-01 07:13:13.000000000', 'message': "Test cases for engine scheduler module

This patch adds unit test cases for the engine scheduler module. Maybe
we should call the 'scheduler' a 'thread_group_manager' or something
alike because it is not doing any scheduling at the moment.

This patch also deleted the 'action_wait' method which 1) is not used
anywhere 2) the implementation is buggy.

Change-Id: Ia43d26514efbfc69d935e1b26476d64f0e74d4c2
"}]
commit_message:
Test cases for engine scheduler module

This patch adds unit test cases for the engine scheduler module. Maybe
we should call the 'scheduler' a 'thread_group_manager' or something
alike because it is not doing any scheduling at the moment.

This patch also deleted the 'action_wait' method which 1) is not used
anywhere 2) the implementation is buggy.

Change-Id: Ia43d26514efbfc69d935e1b26476d64f0e74d4c2

(1 comment)

This looks straightforward (and awesome) to me'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2015-06-10 12:35:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

Just one nasty question: how does it play with our plans to stop using abusing vendor passthrough?'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2015-06-10 12:46:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Hi,

@Dmitry, I get the "vendor" in the name of passthru is not ideal. But, the way I see vendor passthru is the place to put all the driver specifics methods.

That said, I don't think we have been abusing driver passthru. Methods like heartbeat() and lookup() for example were specific for agent_* drivers, then as part of the effort to have IPA as default and only supported deploy ramdisk we added support to the pxe_* drivers to use IPA (and therefore use heartbeat() and lookup() as well) so those methods that are now common across all drivers are being promoted to the core API. But before the vendor passthru was the right place to them IMO.

Since iPXE is the only driver that is going to use that endpoint for now I don't see any other place to put that method, I can't add it to the core API because it's driver specific.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2015-06-10 13:10:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Vendors are e.g. DELL or HP. You and me are not vendors, not should be occupy vendor passthru space. Good example of vendor passthu is DELL BIOS configuration. Bad example is what we're doing.

I had a suggestion to create passthru system for driver interfaces as well, but people were against it.

Anyway, once we implement driver composition reform, vendor passthru will no longer be coupled with the boot interface, so this feature will break. Any ideas how to solve it?"}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2015-06-10 13:22:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

The only idea I see for it is what was discussed in the summit, to extend other interfaces to allow them to create their own [vendor] passthru methods too.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2015-06-10 13:24:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Do you feel like writing the spec, or should I? :) anyway, this answers my question, LGTM.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 13:24:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: -Verified

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2015-06-10 13:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I tend to agree with Lucas here; I think the naming is unfortunate. I see "vendor passthru" as more of a "driver passthru"; just that some of those drivers happen to be vendor-specific. It's designed to do things that not all vendors^Wdrivers can support. This is a prime example of that.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2015-06-10 13:27:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Then it definitely should not be a separate interface, rather parts of existing ones.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 13:33:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified+2

commit_message:
iPXE dynamic configuration

This blueprint adds support for dynamically generating iPXE configuration
files when booting a node.

Change-Id: I443d969638ce56beb5bc9b8484b65fdac4bc469a

subject: Handle the case of REMAINING_TIME <= 0

We can see what other people think, but I don't believe we need to make the v2 error messages consistent with the v1 error messages.  The nice part of the current v2 message is that it specifies the particular key and value that's a problem.  I'm not sure the value is helpful in this particular case, but it's definitely nice to have the problematic key stated.  Removing the '>=' is OK with me, but let's keep the content of the message informative!"}, {'account_id': 10485, 'date': '2015-06-05 13:09:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian: This only removes the '>=' and the duplicate details about problematic key and value.

With this change if user calls image create command with min_disk = -1, He will get following error message in response:

400 Bad Request: Invalid value '-1' for parameter 'min_disk': Cannot be a negative value (HTTP 400)

Do you think this information is not informative enough to the user."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2015-06-05 13:26:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I missed that the details were being duplicated, I'm good with this change."}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2015-06-05 13:56:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2015-06-08 14:18:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9096, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2015-06-10 12:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 12:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-05 07:38:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed error message for negative values of min_disk and min_ram

In case of v1 api if min_disk or min_ram is passed with a negative value
to the image create command, it returns 400 response with error message
formatted to HTML entity.

Eliminated special characters (>=) from error message, so it will not
cause any encoding issues. Also with this change the error message for
v1 api will be identical to v2 api.

Closes-Bug: 1461776
Change-Id: I71a3cc3ed6bf14f3c0273df053667f1cbf99e98f
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed error message for negative values of min_disk and min_ram

In case of v1 api if min_disk or min_ram is passed with a negative value
to the image create command, it returns 400 response with error message
formatted to HTML entity.

Eliminated special characters (>=) from error message, so it will not
cause any encoding issues. Also with this change the error message for
v1 api will be identical to v2 api.

Closes-Bug: 1461776
Change-Id: I71a3cc3ed6bf14f3c0273df053667f1cbf99e98f

commit_message:
create GRENADE_PLUGINRC to pass through grenade external plugins

Grenade is starting to support external plugins, this piece will be
needed to specify which plugins grenade should load.

This also overwrites PLUGIN_DIR to be the same as TARGET_RELEASE_DIR
so that we can reuse zuul checkout magic.

Change-Id: I09c37b0cec3b0656da104f3ff2ad756385e9e219

[{'created': '2015-06-08 18:22:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fix inconsistent usage of "Positional argument"

All help texts uses "Positional argument" with the exception of tempurl.
Update tempurl to use this as well so that the formatting tools work
fine and can show this nicely on
http://docs.openstack.org/cli-reference/content/swiftclient_commands.html#swiftclient_subcommand_tempurl
like it's done for other options.

Change-Id: Ib5502c23b236986bea5a4d4a63a46fca411a8494
Closes-Bug: #1463081
'}]
commit_message:
Fix inconsistent usage of "Positional argument"

All help texts uses "Positional argument" with the exception of tempurl.
Update tempurl to use this as well so that the formatting tools work
fine and can show this nicely on
http://docs.openstack.org/cli-reference/content/swiftclient_commands.html#swiftclient_subcommand_tempurl
like it's done for other options.

Change-Id: Ib5502c23b236986bea5a4d4a63a46fca411a8494
Closes-Bug: #1463081

The Hyper-V driver uses the Microsoft\Windows\SMB WMI namespace
in order to handle SMB shares. The issue is that this namespace is
not available on Windows versions prior to Windows Server 2012.

For this reason, the Hyper-V driver fails to initialize on Windows
Server 2008 R2.

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fix missing WMI namespace issue on Windows 2008 R2

The Hyper-V driver uses the Microsoft\Windows\SMB WMI namespace
in order to handle SMB shares. The issue is that this namespace is
not available on Windows versions prior to Windows Server 2012.

For this reason, the Hyper-V driver fails to initialize on Windows
Server 2008 R2.

This patch fixes the issue by properly handling the PathUtils
initialization.

Closes-Bug: #1463044
Change-Id: Ia99576589af6049ee07337c631ed7d5d6cf602d9

[{'created': '2015-06-09 09:13:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix QoS issues caused by unsupported OS versions

Disk QoS is not available on versions prior to WS 2012 R2.

Becaue of this and the fact that the driver attempts to set IOPS
limits even if those are not specified, spawning instances currently
fails when using such Windows versions.

This patch fixes the issues by skipping setting QoS specs when
this feature is not supported, logging a warning.

Closes-Bug: #1463317

Change-Id: I086f3a034ffcc56a09a5ecf3e9a142cc86e67c41
'}, {'created': '2015-06-09 12:52:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix QoS issues caused by unsupported OS versions

Disk QoS is not available on versions prior to WS 2012 R2.

Because of this and the fact that the driver attempts to set IOPS
limits even if those are not specified, spawning instances currently
fails when using previous HyperV versions.

This patch fixes the issues by skipping setting QoS specs when
this feature is not supported, logging a warning.

Closes-Bug: #1463317

Change-Id: I086f3a034ffcc56a09a5ecf3e9a142cc86e67c41
'}]
commit_message:
Fix QoS issues caused by unsupported OS versions

Disk QoS is not available on versions prior to WS 2012 R2.

Because of this and the fact that the driver attempts to set IOPS
limits even if those are not specified, spawning instances currently
fails when using previous HyperV versions.

This patch fixes the issues by skipping setting QoS specs when
this feature is not supported, logging a warning.

Closes-Bug: #1463317

Change-Id: I086f3a034ffcc56a09a5ecf3e9a142cc86e67c41

commit_message:
Import puppet-stackalytics into openstack-infra

This is a very basic git repo for puppet-stackalytics. Once imported,
we'll use the existing work by Monty to build up the module correctly.

Change-Id: I92424e5e8bb560ad7e127f6de976f843a32d546f
Depends-On: Iaae173a301e8ea64a4271f0f49349363ac3a9553
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Rename ironic-milestone group in gerrit to ironic-stable-maint

I was having a hard time finding the stable branch maintenance team for
ironic because they used a different naming convention for their group
from the rest of the projects:

https://review.openstack.org/#/admin/groups/?filter=stable

So rename the group to match the standard naming convention.

Change-Id: I32947e905770475ed3aea342dd80984fc90e3d69

subject: Bare Metal Trust Using Intel TXT

This is cool. Although I don't have a good picture of how this will work (see comments inline).

I may have missed it, but how/when does someone know whether the node is to be trusted or not? Eg, will Ironic find out/ fail the deployment if the node can't be trusted? Or is it up to some user to issue a request to the Oat Server, to find out if a particular node can be trusted or not, after ironic has deployed to the node?

It would help me if the spec could more clearly describe what is done by Ironic and what is done outside."}, {'account_id': 13362, 'date': '2014-12-04 13:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 13362, 'date': '2014-12-04 14:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

commit_message:
Bare Metal Trust Using Intel TXT

This provides a trusted boot solution, to determine the node
is trusted or not after deployed with Ironic, leveraging
Intel TXT to measure BIOS, Option ROM and Kernel/Ramdisk.
Talk and Demo:
https://www.openstack.org/summit/openstack-paris-summit-2014/
session-videos/presentation/trusted-bare-metal-what-and-39-s-that

Co-Authored-By: Bhandaru, Malini K <malini.k.bhandaru@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Villalovos, John L <john.l.villalovos@intel.com>

Change-Id: I046030cc42f943435ec6fc078c31228c1b22bd99

commit_message:
Move transport v1 tests out of tests/

This moves tests for wsgi v1 out of the tests directory. This finishes
the transport unit tests.

blueprint tests-refactoring

Change-Id: Id9cbd64a7c4f49870f767d1427f7de4a0ada3846

commit_message:
Drop usage of `` in if statements

Subshells are not required for if statements, so remove them. This
also drops all usage of `` in scripts.

Change-Id: I44c476ddfb67e5b3ebd3aaba3b26561f02708477

This seems like a potentially great idea, but as far as I can tell this change will allow the api to start when zero of the three database connections work. It would be better if it failed to start in this case as we would like to know as soon as possible that something is wrong.

In general we want failure to be visible as soon as possible, not sometime later when the first request of the API service is made.'}, {'account_id': 13560, 'date': '2015-06-02 15:40:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@cdent: It might still seem useful to start the api when at least one of the connections got initialized. The failure with connection could be temporary and will be retried for each request.

However, i get your point about the scenario when all the connections fail and in this case, we can prevent the api from starting. How does that sound?'}, {'account_id': 13560, 'date': '2015-06-02 23:35:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 13560, 'date': '2015-06-02 23:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 15843, 'date': '2015-06-02 23:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-21 00:15:17.000000000', 'message': 'Handle database failures on api startup

Storage layer connections are initialized
for metering, alarm and event in Pecan hook
middleware.
If any of the backends are not responding,
the connections are retried till maximum
retries and the exception propagated to the
Ceilometer-api which fails to startup.

This fix logs and handles the exception in
the Pecan hook and allows all connection
types to be initialized.

Closes-Bug: bug/1456944

Change-Id: Id70693dafc823927b3d72e0371e3e55d4e5588ce

'}, {'created': '2015-06-09 15:10:06.000000000', 'message': 'Handle database failures on api startup

Storage layer connections are initialized
for metering, alarm and event in Pecan hook
middleware.
If any of the backends are not responding,
the connections are retried till maximum
retries and the exception propagated to the
Ceilometer-api which fails to startup.

This fix logs and handles the exception in
the Pecan hook and allows all connection
types to be initialized.

Closes-Bug: 1456944

Change-Id: Id70693dafc823927b3d72e0371e3e55d4e5588ce
'}]
commit_message:
Handle database failures on api startup

Storage layer connections are initialized
for metering, alarm and event in Pecan hook
middleware.
If any of the backends are not responding,
the connections are retried till maximum
retries and the exception propagated to the
Ceilometer-api which fails to startup.

This fix logs and handles the exception in
the Pecan hook and allows all connection
types to be initialized.

Closes-Bug: 1456944

Change-Id: Id70693dafc823927b3d72e0371e3e55d4e5588ce

commit_message:
cleanup openstack-common.conf and sync updated files

periodic update of latest files from oslo-incubator. Please
note that a lot of files in */openstack/common/* are no
longer in oslo-incubator as they graduated into new oslo.*
libraries. So there's more work needed to move to those
libraries and delete the code from here.

Change-Id: Ie9f64ed73b246164978532f872e09e16d26556d9

commit_message:
Opencontrail: Enable opencontrail config provider

This patch adds support for neutron_plugin_opencontrail provider to edit
ContrailPlugin.ini configuration file.

Change-Id: I6f0d4248033e8e2324754541c77f934f1279ff52

subject: Object are sorted and concatenated by swift in cardinal order.
messages:
[{'account_id': 14867, 'date': '2015-06-06 12:26:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2015-06-06 12:26:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-06 13:13:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-swift-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/15/189015/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/dba7789/ : SUCCESS in 2m 34s
- gate-swift-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/15/189015/1/check/gate-swift-docs/a0ad362//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 07s
- gate-swift-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/15/189015/1/check/gate-swift-python27/1e32de6/ : FAILURE in 3m 10s
- gate-swift-tox-func http://logs.openstack.org/15/189015/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func/b3fa2cd/ : SUCCESS in 7m 07s (non-voting)
- check-tempest-dsvm-full http://logs.openstack.org/15/189015/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-full/667ca0b/ : SUCCESS in 46m 31s
- check-grenade-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/15/189015/1/check/check-grenade-dsvm/31172ff/ : SUCCESS in 37m 12s
- check-swift-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/15/189015/1/check/check-swift-dsvm-functional/0611bb6/ : SUCCESS in 24m 36s'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2015-06-06 18:32:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I was curious what "cardinal order" was and how it relates to lexicographical order, but some basic googling didn't help.

Then I went looking for the code actually doing the ordering to see what *it* says it does.  Best I can tell, the ordering is performed by SQLite's "BINARY" collation strategy: https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#collation

...which is literally memcmp(), presumably on the bytes of the UTF-8 representation of the names.

Is that what a "cardinal order" is?

It might be more understandable to just say that the bytes of the UTF-8 representation of the names are sorted with memcmp() if we're really trying to disambiguate the docs.'}, {'account_id': 14867, 'date': '2015-06-06 19:28:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2015-06-06 19:33:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Looks like you mistakenly reset the commit message. Can you restore it to the first version?

There's a known issue with the py27 tests right now in a dependency. It will probably be resolved in a day or so (ie during the workweek)."}, {'account_id': 14867, 'date': '2015-06-06 19:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14867, 'date': '2015-06-06 20:25:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Darrell,
  
Yes ,you are right the utf-encoded bytes are sorted in swift  , but specifying the function name used, in docs would not be necessary from docs perspective that why used cardinal. Other terms could also be used ,but for the issue this seems to be one of the proposed terms. suggestions are welcome :)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-06 20:40:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

commit_message:
Object are sorted and concatenated by swift in cardinal order.

Modified values in example in decimal to be more precise,
added a small description on Object are sorted and concatenated
by swift in cardinal order as a small phrase would be sufficient.

Change-Id: I914ded4e5726e50bb93b05759c3bfb76edda53ab
backport: none
Closes-Bug: #1383893

[{'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-15 21:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-04-15 21:31:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

overall, this looks good to me'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-04-16 15:42:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-04-16 16:02:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2015-04-16 16:07:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

I'd recommend adding a few more explicit items:

Level of python support
   - support for python 3 a requirement
   - minimum version of python supported (eg, 2.6+)

Should we restrict drivers to pure python?  Should all dependencies be available via PyPi?  In other words, can a driver have dependencies on non-python libraries (like the binary proton library)?

Is there any requirement on the level of distro support?  I think it's adequate to simply require CI tests, as all dependencies would need to be available to the CI platforms.


One other point - and perhaps this should be discussed elsewhere:

If oslo.messaging is intended to be messaging-implementation agnostic, then there's got to be a requirement on oslo.messaging to prevent new features from being added to the API that can be implemented in only a subset of these supported drivers.   Before a new API or feature can be officially supported, it must be implemented in all supported messaging drivers, not just rabbit."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2015-04-16 20:28:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-16 20:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-16 20:52:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Regarding kombu: At one time I thought this was a good idea. Just use and enhance kombu, and we can make oslo.messaging a thin layer around it. It sounds great.

But the reality is that kombu is meant to be a generic message passing library, while oslo.messaging is meant to be the common way OpenStack communicates between daemons. To rob OpenStack of knowledge of how its backends work and force it into least-common-denominator behaviors doesn't seem productive. At most I'd expect 2 or maybe 3 working drivers to ever live in oslo.messaging with the kind of support needed. If we just say "if its in kombu it's good" I don't think we'll actually gain users or stability.

So the real question is, what is the value of a virtuous circle with kombu, versus the value of being closer to the implementation. I do not have very informed answers for either of those, but my gut says it's a wash at best.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-16 20:59:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

I wanted to also address Ken's suggestion. I will add a general statement that it must support the versions of python commonly in use in OpenStack. I'm fine with oslo.messaging's maintainers making a call as to what versions fit that description, because I don't want to get too specific here. 2.6 is all but done, and 3.4 is more important than 3.3.

Regarding the API not allowing things that can't be done: I disagree. I am fine with a driver being a partial option, as some people will only want said driver for a specific purpose that may work fine. Any missing annotation of the limitations would be a very obvious documentation bug.

Finally I don't really want to get into Linux distros in this spec. If distros ignore a driver, but users and developers step up to maintain it, I don't really see a problem with us carrying it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-16 21:19:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-openstack-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/05/174105/2/check/gate-openstack-specs-docs/6276f3a//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 40s'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2015-04-16 21:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-04-16 23:13:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7849, 'date': '2015-04-20 16:28:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think this all seems reasonable.  Quick question on the feasibility of the requirements (Testing, Documentation, Support) though - do we have a list of drivers which currently meet these requirements and a list which would be immediately deprecated?  I'm assuming that the deprecation cycle (2 releases) is meant to function as a grace period for interested folks to re-certify old drivers."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-20 16:40:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Good questions.

I believe only RabbitMQ would qualify if we started deprecating things today. zmq is close, but needs a larger community of users to surface and add a gate job, and commit to supporting it long term.

The grace period is to allow distributors and operators who have based their clouds on a now-deprecated driver to migrate off of it separate from their OpenStack upgrade process.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-20 23:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-21 00:27:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-openstack-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/05/174105/3/check/gate-openstack-specs-docs/b32798c//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 46s'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-04-21 15:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-21 19:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2015-04-21 21:23:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-04-21 21:30:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2015-04-29 14:37:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2015-05-11 14:26:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:31:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:34:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Generally agree with all of this, it's what the other projects are doing with vendor plugins, like nova/cinder/neutron, and we should have something like this in oslo.messaging.

We (IBM) are supporting rabbit and qpid (qpid only before juno when we added rabbit support too) and now we're default rabbit and at this crossroads of do we drop qpid support - and a big part of that is the fact that it's not gated as a config upstream and we don't want to be on the hook for supporting qpid if it's, like is said in the mailing list on this, you're on your own.

The qpid maintainers like Ken have done a nice job of helping us with issues but we really need openstack testing regularly with the qpid backend for people to be comfortable in shipping it and supporting it in their distros."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2015-05-13 17:58:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thanks for your thoughts Matt. I think we'd all welcome investment from QPID-interested parties in QA for QPID. As the policy states though, it isn't just about setting up the tests, it's about committing to being responsive when they are broken, and to maintaining the driver over the long run. Nobody has come close to doing that for QPID yet, and so I think it will just be the first deprecation via this policy."}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2015-05-13 21:17:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Seems to me that both the QPID driver and the AMQP1 driver would be candidates for deprecation under this policy.

Personally, I in favor of deprecating the QPID driver (impl_qpid). My effort has been going into developing the AMQP1 driver for qpidd rather than try to divide effort between the two.

The intent of the AMQP1 driver is to replace impl_qpid, at least as far as I'm concerned (and other QPID developers).  However there's been very little uptake of the AMQP1 driver, which is unfortunate.  Until we get more adoption, that driver won't get beyond the experimental stage.

In Ken's Perfect World, we'd be deprecating impl_qpid first, and recommending qpidd environments start testing the AMQP1 driver in preparation for migrating to it.

In this world I'd also have a Telsa. A blue one. :)"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2015-05-14 12:19:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

I'm happy with this % nits"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-05-14 19:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2015-05-28 21:01:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2015-06-01 19:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2015-06-02 20:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2015-06-02 21:27:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

It's kind of implicit but I believe it'd be worth mentioning."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2015-06-03 13:50:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2015-06-03 16:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2015-06-04 06:47:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Update test-birfrost to limit log lines

test-birfrost notes that only the last 1000 lines of some log files
will be output, but uses cat to dump the entire file. This patch limits
output to 1000 lines.

Change-Id: I02fce16edd9d1494a7bee3c534db4c264923a12d

Can you please add a brief description of how this change fixes the issue as I had to go back and forth on the bug to understand it?

Also, I think the issue is that we do not handle a general "Exception" in the api/v2/images. May be you can add that in this patch so that we don't see regression if some new exception is to be expected.'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2015-06-09 18:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Fix partially looks good.'}, {'account_id': 13717, 'date': '2015-06-09 19:08:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated'}, {'account_id': 13717, 'date': '2015-06-09 19:12:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 13717, 'date': '2015-06-09 19:17:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thanks for the review! 
Added some more info in the commit message. 

Nikhil, honestly, I don't like the idea of catching the general Exception in api methods: I don't support the catch-em-all principle and the appearance of a new 500 due to some uncaught Exception is an indication that we need to turn attention to some problem, which is not bad, imho.

I may be mistaken, of course, so the more opinions - the better."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-09 20:20:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

commit_message:
Fix HTTP 500 on NotAuthenticated in registry (v2)

If for some reason (absent\invalid token) authentication failed during a
registry call, InternalServerError appeared as long as
exception.NotAuthenticated was not being caught in ImagesController.

This patch fixes the issue by catching the exception and raising
401 Unauthorized.

Change-Id: I72016c5c7868fdc7a72def8b6f5a05324dcee387
Closes-Bug: #1451850

commit_message:
Merge tag '2014.2'

This is a null-merge of the 2014.2 release tag back into the
master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: Iaed05cac703604639608e5fd203cffc2ed474e34

commit_message:
Generate a SHA-2 certificate for Horizon

SHA-1 certificates are being deprecated and browsers are starting to
issue warnings about their use. We should begin generating SHA-2
certificates for Horizon.

Closes-bug: 1461983
Change-Id: I7f1933680e2859e007f6b8be262852b164f90b33
(cherry picked from commit ed29e8a3d9e9f102158e35f8b0ea7bd3ef278327)

commit_message:
add DNS events

this patch adds support for dns crud notifications
as events in ceilometer.

Change-Id: I7287a160b510bdb91a68594874bbbba45e6a210f
Partially-Implements: blueprint dns-service-notifications

commit_message:
Switch from MySQL-python to PyMySQL

As discussed in the Liberty Design Summit "Moving apps to Python 3"
cross-project workshop, the way forward in the near future is to
switch to the pure-python PyMySQL library as a default.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-cross-project-python3

Change-Id: I058419b25f55dcfd93af522aa1f5f61b8f06407e

commit_message:
Naming clean up

This refactoring patch fixes a few naming problems:
* namespace for processing hooks implied that it's the only type
  of hooks, added ".processing" postfix
* node_info -> introspection_data
* cached_node -> node_info

Change-Id: I8401f95236e269583257c3c5ba3762d0920d32e8
Implements: blueprint plugin-interface-v2

commit_message:
Reduce SQL Server downtime and Snapshot option on windows

CLI argument for snapshots on windows (vssadmin)
Reduce downtime with SQL Server if a snapshot is available

Change-Id: Iaae4d028cd19e1732925ec5bd86665b839528cd3

- gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ceph http://logs.openstack.org/99/189799/3/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ceph/9ea8a2b/ : SUCCESS in 47m 23s'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 05:15:39.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2015-06-10 11:33:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

So the 'encrypted' flag in the connection_info comes from the cinder volume driver. In the case of a volume accessed via iSCSI, the driver is ISCSIDriver in  cinder/volume/driver.py. In the case of a volume accessed via RBD/Ceph, the driver is RBDDriver in cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py

The ISCSIDriver is the only one that ever sets the 'encrypted' flag in the 'init_connection' method. So AFAIK, the RBD code won't ever do encryption. So given that the tempest test is still succeeding, it looks like the cinder API is silently ignoring the request to use encryption with RBD, which seems like a pretty bad idea to me. I'd expect a fatal error if the user requested encryption with a volume driver that doesn't support it."}]

commit_message:
volume: log which encryptor class is being used

After resolving which encryptor class to use with a cinder
volume, record it in the logs for easier debugging.

Related-Bug: #1463525

Change-Id: Ic753b11a48cb2c17c24c6636a456f00966f7c8ab

commit_message:
VPNaaS: And devref doc infrastructure

This wasn't setup in the reppo, so I'm adding it now. Empty for
now, with TODOs for some sections. The "tox -e docs" was updated
to generate the documentation.

Change-Id: I17e475b2a870a1ecdb2a1cacf2087a96beac3f78

commit_message:
VPNaaS: Enable pylint duplicate-key check

I tried this in the VPNaaS repo and it passes, so we can enable
this, in a manner similar to Neutron (see review 188247 with commit
If4fed9714cd7fa586845f21f8f56dde2645cc5e0).

Change-Id: I3e2ba541142aefc38ca10e94400f942443c00f7b

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: I2e88cb9f04864c901a67340620949eb7c54d5543

commit_message:
Merge tag '2015.1.0'

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: I2e88cb9f04864c901a67340620949eb7c54d5543

@dims: Thanks for keeping an eye out on this..

I am curious to know couple of things:

2) Once the modules are removed, where do we look for the new import paths?'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-06-08 18:38:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi devdatta,

We have a weekly meeting in Oslo where we go over such items. Typically each project nominates someone to be liaison with oslo (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CrossProjectLiaisons). So i'd request Solum folks to do the same. 

thanks,
dims"}, {'account_id': 2506, 'date': '2015-06-08 19:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks @dims for the information.

We will check among Solum team members about someone being a liaison and participating in Oslo meetings.

It seems like current approach to build the packages don't include

Change-Id: I4cf05d3ab23b7b36f2645eac47b606585285afba

commit_message:
Add non *py files in the package

It seems like current approach to build the packages don't include
non-python files. Fixing this using `python_distutils` in deb.

Change-Id: I4cf05d3ab23b7b36f2645eac47b606585285afba

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-23 22:20:10.000000000', 'message': "Change L3 agent AdvancedService class to be non-singleton

The idea behind the AdvancedServices (Metadata, *aaS) drivers
to be singletons was to (1) offer a way to get an instance of such
a driver in a convinient manner, and to (2) ensure that only one
driver registered per driver type.

(1) Since the AdvancedService.instance method required an instance
of a L3 agent, this point was kind of missed. If you have a L3 agent
instance in your hand, just use it to access the driver you're looking
for.

(2) This is now fulfilled by asserting that only one driver is registered
(per type) in the .add method.

The motivation to make them non-singletons is that:
a) They don't need to be
b) The code is simplified this way
c) I've been facing crazy issues during functional testing where we're
   constantly instantiating L3 agents, and the (singleton) drivers were
   referencing the wrong configuration object. Basically the driver was
   re-initialized during a test, screwing up the configuration of other
   mid-run tests.

Change-Id: I192e4d12380346c53c8ae0246371ccc41a836c4c
"}, {'created': '2015-02-23 23:24:33.000000000', 'message': "Change L3 agent AdvancedService class to be non-singleton

The idea behind the AdvancedServices (Metadata, *aaS) drivers
to be singletons was to (1) offer a way to get an instance of such
a driver in a convinient manner, and to (2) ensure that only one
driver registered per driver type.

(1) Since the AdvancedService.instance method required an instance
of a L3 agent, this point was kind of missed. If you have a L3 agent
instance in your hand, just use it to access the driver you're looking
for.

(2) This is now fulfilled by asserting that only one driver is registered
(per type) in the .add method.

The motivation to make them non-singletons is that:
a) They don't need to be
b) The code is simplified this way
c) I've been facing crazy issues during functional testing where we're
   constantly instantiating L3 agents, and the (singleton) drivers were
   referencing the wrong configuration object. Basically the driver was
   re-initialized during a test, screwing up the configuration of other
   mid-run tests.

Depends-On: I155aece9b7028f1bdd3d9709facef392b38aec27
Depends-On: I199f6a967c64e921624b397fa5b7dfc56572d63a
Change-Id: I192e4d12380346c53c8ae0246371ccc41a836c4c
"}, {'created': '2015-02-26 00:09:51.000000000', 'message': "Change L3 agent AdvancedService class to be non-singleton

The idea behind the AdvancedServices (Metadata, *aaS) services
to be singletons was to (1) offer a way to get an instance of such
a service in a convinient manner, and to (2) ensure that only one
service registered per service type.

(1) Since the AdvancedService.instance method required an instance
of a L3 agent, this point was kind of missed. If you have a L3 agent
instance in your hand, just use it to access the service you're looking
for.

(2) This is now fulfilled by asserting that only one driver is registered
(per type) in the .add method.

The motivation to make them non-singletons is that:
a) They don't need to be
b) The code is simplified this way
c) I've been facing crazy issues during functional testing where we're
   constantly instantiating L3 agents, and the (singleton) metadata
   service was referencing the wrong configuration object. The service
   was re-initialized during a test, screwing up the configuration of
   other mid-run tests.

Closes-Bug: #1425759
Depends-On: I155aece9b7028f1bdd3d9709facef392b38aec27
Depends-On: I199f6a967c64e921624b397fa5b7dfc56572d63a
Change-Id: I192e4d12380346c53c8ae0246371ccc41a836c4c
"}]
commit_message:
Change L3 agent AdvancedService class to be non-singleton

The idea behind the AdvancedServices (Metadata, *aaS) services
to be singletons was to (1) offer a way to get an instance of such
a service in a convinient manner, and to (2) ensure that only one
service registered per service type.

(1) Since the AdvancedService.instance method required an instance
of a L3 agent, this point was kind of missed. If you have a L3 agent
instance in your hand, just use it to access the service you're looking
for.

(2) This is now fulfilled by asserting that only one driver is registered
(per type) in the .add method.

The motivation to make them non-singletons is that:
a) They don't need to be
b) The code is simplified this way
c) I've been facing crazy issues during functional testing where we're
   constantly instantiating L3 agents, and the (singleton) metadata
   service was referencing the wrong configuration object. The service
   was re-initialized during a test, screwing up the configuration of
   other mid-run tests.

Closes-Bug: #1425759
Depends-On: I155aece9b7028f1bdd3d9709facef392b38aec27
Depends-On: I199f6a967c64e921624b397fa5b7dfc56572d63a
Change-Id: I192e4d12380346c53c8ae0246371ccc41a836c4c

(6 comments)

For the most part I like it.  One thing I would make sure is pointed out is the ability for said "cache" objects to be volumes or snapshots.

I'm not sure about reuse of the Volume object for this, I kinda think having a cache object of some sort might be more flexible, particularly when dealing with those backends that need to use snapshots for whatever reason.

One other thing, that I can think of... need to stress the importance and use of virt_size from the image-metadata and be sure that we're using the "smallest" size volume possible and then extending as needed.

All in all though I think this is doable higher up the food chain.  Initially when I put it together I didn't think it would be that useful for everybody but I was definitely wrong about that :)'}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2015-05-13 04:20:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-13 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

(6 comments)

Thanks John! I made a few updates for things in the latest patchset, and have some responses questions inline.

Thats a good point about using snapshots... I had only considered volumes initially. I think after chatting in IRC I've convinced myself that if someone really needs to use snapshots they can take one of the cache volume and then create a volume from that snapshot. Since for any of the backends they will need to create a volume from the image first anyway.

So my thinking for re-using the volume object is that we already have so much machinery in place to create, attach, delete, etc that could be borrowed for doing this with the image volumes. Things like volume meta data, backend specific junk, whatever other drivers need to make their stuff work."}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2015-05-13 11:02:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Generic image volume cache functionality

The proposes a generic image cache feature that would allow any backend
to use volumes to store images as a cache for future create from image
operations.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2015-05-28 06:15:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Patrick, I am not sure if you have already know about this.
As I put in the mail list, Manila folks implements a sort of private storage via https://review.openstack.org/#/c/176877/.

Hope you can take as a reference to see how similar it can be to the implementation in Cinder. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2015-05-28 06:34:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks Vincent! I replied to the email thread, but i'll copy it here so its easier to find later...

Thanks for the info!

I think for the migration use case this would definitely solve the issue, but for the image cache we would need more as we would be creating volume objects and need to track them in the Cinder database. We could use a system like that to essentially put a 'hidden' flag in the meta-data entries of the cached images, but its not much better than just adding a hidden flag in regards to having to filter them out from api calls and not accounting for them in quota anywhere.

Alternatives for using a special tenant are definitely worth considering, I admit its not really an ideal solution, but it happens to be fairly appealing for the problem we are solving. I'll take a closer look at the Manilla changes and adjust the spec's I have for cinder as needed."}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2015-05-28 06:36:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

occurred to me right after copy-pasting there is a better way:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/064958.html'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2015-05-30 02:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Please see my comments inline. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2015-05-30 21:21:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I support this proposal and the -1 is truly just for some additional work that we need to do before merge.

That said, I do plan to talk to our folks active in manila and ensure that there's not something we're missing here given their private storage initiative (and vice versa)."}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2015-05-31 02:07:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Here's the mailing list discussion on whether Manila should use private data storage during migration to avoid creating the 2nd db entry for the volume. The investigation so far indicates it is very difficult to handle error status if we go that route. It is not completely settled yet, but private data storage doesn't seem promising as it will also introduce lots of complexities.

https://www.mail-archive.com/openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org/msg53926.html

Internal tenant seems to be a cleaner approach to me, at least for image volume cache and non-disruptive backup use cases."}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2015-06-01 16:33:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2015-06-01 16:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-01 16:47:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

I'm with the current proposal. Patrick mentioned there were suggestions of having multiple tenants for different types of Cinder operations. I'm happy to hear those reasons, but I don't think we should block this longer. I will be approving this on Friday unless there is a good reason to halt."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2015-06-09 18:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:38:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I think the one tenant .v. several is hard to judge right now - I lean towards separation of concerns, for easy of debugging and management (e.g. seeing how much space the cache is taking up), but one tenant for all makes for a simpler config file.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:38:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Verified

commit_message:
Cinder internal tenant

This spec proposes the addition of config options and utilities needed
for a cinder-internal tenant.

Change-Id: I57259a92a8993d0f1ccdd6a4b51f7f10cab1985c

(7 comments)

Hi Xiaohui,

This grouping can still be confusing. Backends reporting "unknown/infinite" may support thin provisioning. This grouping gives people impression that these backends don't support thin provisioning and therefore it is misleading. Also some backends can support both thin and thick. Are you going to put it under thin or thick group? Either way, it is not accurate. Putting it under both groups is also not accurate as you will be showing their capacities twice.'}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-05-14 05:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-14 05:40:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

(6 comments)

I support this initiative but have some recommendations inline where I think we need a bit more clarity.'}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-06-05 01:21:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Thanks for the comments. But my intention is to report the capacity with backend granularity and not with pool.'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2015-06-08 08:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

The scheduler works on a pool granularity, thick/thin decisions are per pool (if not per volume), and volume types are directed at a pool. Free capacity per backend rather than pool does not seem to be anything particularly useful for capacity planning, and if really desired can trivially be calculated on the client as a sum of the pools.'}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-06-09 06:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-09 06:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified+1

As far as pool vs backend; My understanding is that one of the main goals here is to surface backend capacity info to ceilometer, or at the very least provide something that gives a total available picture.

I think the pool work is already done here, but it it appeases some folks in terms of the spec seems like a win to me.

Pools, Shmoools... they're nothing but trouble :)"}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:29:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks, that looks better.

Pools are a reality of our code, and ignoring them is not going to help - if you want to propose a patch to remove pool support, I'll bring the popcorn."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:29:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: -Verified

Change-Id: Ifc9c3ecbc4c5c4f03da2ec4971dfdc6b127b2961
blueprint: capacity-headroom
'}, {'created': '2015-05-12 07:15:24.000000000', 'message': 'capacity-headroom

The spec is for blueprint capacity-headroom.

The proposol groups the backends into
thin/thick/unknown, calculates and show
total capacity for each group individually.

For thin, calculates total virtual free
capacity for all thin provisioning backends.

For thick, calculates total free capacity.
For unknown, calculates total backends number.

commit_message:
capacity-headroom

The spec is for blueprint capacity-headroom.

The proposol calculates virtual free capacity
for pool and sum total for the backend which
support thin provisioning. It will then notify
various capacity info to ceilometer service.

Change-Id: Ifc9c3ecbc4c5c4f03da2ec4971dfdc6b127b2961
blueprint: capacity-headroom

[{'created': '2015-05-28 19:43:52.000000000', 'message': 'Replace pip-installed requests CA bundle with link

If the version of python-requests required is higher than
that provided by the operating system, pip will install
it from upstream.

The upstream version provides its own CA certificate bundle
based on the Mozilla bundle, and defaults to that in case
a CA certificate file is not specified for a request.

The distribution-specific packages point to the system-wide
CA bundle that can be managed by tools such as
update-ca-trust (Fedora/RHEL) and update-ca-certificates
(Debian/Ubuntu).

When installing in SSL/TLS mode, either with SSL=True or by
adding tls-proxy to ENABLED_SERVICES, if a non-systemwide
CA bundle is used, then the CA generated by devstack will
not be used causing the installation to fail.

Replace the upstream-provided bundle with a link to the
system bundle when possible.

Change-Id: I349662ff8f851b4a7f879f89b8975a068f2d73dc
Closes-Bug: #1459789

commit_message:
Replace pip-installed requests CA bundle with link

If the version of python-requests required is higher than
that provided by the operating system, pip will install
it from upstream.

The upstream version provides its own CA certificate bundle
based on the Mozilla bundle, and defaults to that in case
a CA certificate file is not specified for a request.

The distribution-specific packages point to the system-wide
CA bundle that can be managed by tools such as
update-ca-trust (Fedora/RHEL) and update-ca-certificates
(Debian/Ubuntu).

When installing in SSL/TLS mode, either with SSL=True or by
adding tls-proxy to ENABLED_SERVICES, if a non-systemwide
CA bundle is used, then the CA generated by devstack will
not be used causing the installation to fail.

Replace the upstream-provided bundle with a link to the
system bundle when possible.

Change-Id: I349662ff8f851b4a7f879f89b8975a068f2d73dc
Closes-Bug: #1459789

commit_message:
Merge tag '2015.1.0'

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: Ie7036b2fe48dde67d835e0701dbbbdc5cb05457b

subject: Provide a signal URL attribute for alarms

Also as a side note, I see that the changes that went into Ceilometer to support this have another instance of the auth_uri.replace("v2.0", "v3") in the uri, once we decide what to do to clean that up on our side we have to update the Ceilo side as well.'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2015-05-22 15:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2015-05-26 06:23:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2015-05-26 06:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Provide a signal URL attribute for alarms

This patch adds a new attribute to scaling policies allowing it to be
called by the ceilometer service user using trusts on alarming.

Implements: blueprint trust-alarm-urls
Change-Id: Ic039d9aaf3804ab09e3d546d3ae55a18b528d585

subject: Use dynamic method to get "ip" path not "/bin/ip"
