(3 comments)

Yair Fried	, thank you! I will put another patch later.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2014-10-23 16:07:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I am not a linux shell expert. Can you explain why you need to call whereis to get an absolute path which is then called, rather than just calling the command? Isn't the lookup path used for locating the command to call the same as whereis would use?"}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2014-10-23 16:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with David here.

Why not just calling "ip" instead of "/bin/ip" ?'}, {'account_id': 12412, 'date': '2014-10-24 02:23:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@David and @Jordan, because these commands will be executed by ssh connection in remote host, ssh only execute command in "/bin" when we don't use absolute path, eg. if we use "ip", ssh will execute "/bin/ip" instead of searching in $PATH and executing it.'}, {'account_id': 12119, 'date': '2014-10-24 07:51:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2014-10-24 13:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks Shang for the explanation. You are right.

I'd like to see that explanation in the commit message, because I think it's not really well known that sshd comes with its $PATH

Also, please take into account Yair's suggestions. (at least the "strip" thing)

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 12412, 'date': '2014-10-24 16:11:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-24 17:47:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2014-12-23 11:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I agree with the intent of supporting multiple guest image types, however I think this is not the right direction.
Using an ssh client which creates a new connection for every command may be ok for very simple things, but if we want to build a more complex logic we need a different approach. 

On some images the ssh client is configured for reverse DNS lookup of the client IP, which may take several seconds to timeout, so multiple calls are not ideal.

The bash code written in bits and pieces within python code also become fairly unreadable. 

One way of improving this could be to have a small library of bash functions / scripts, loaded on the images at boot time, which provide a consistent interface across all images.

It might go a little beyond the scope of tempest, but I would be in favour of it as long as it is specifically targeted to improve the validation of API calls / scenarios - e.g. verify a volume is actually attached, a VM in the same tenant network is pingable etc.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2015-03-25 19:28:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

So I think the solution here is unecessarily complex. Instead of doing a whereis (or a which) and getting the path of the binary, just drop the /bin from the ip call. If the ip (or any other ssh command we use in tempest) is not in the default PATH then we just say you can't use that image with tempest."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2015-03-25 19:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

What about a compromise where there is a tempest conf option that is a path containing user_data that will be added to create_server calls and can be used to make the commands tempest is making work? That would eliminate the complexity while still allowing images to be used that did not have the same commands/path as we are assuming. There really isn't any "standard" for these commands.'}, {'account_id': 4727, 'date': '2015-03-26 08:26:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I agree with Matthew. We should keep it as simple as we can.'}, {'account_id': 12412, 'date': '2015-06-10 10:26:10.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Use dynamic method to get "ip" path not "/bin/ip"

SSH only executes commands in "/bin/" if we don't use absolute
path, "ip" path is different(not always "/bin/ip") in different
Linux distributions, eg. "/sbin/ip" in CentOS, "/usr/sbin/ip" in
fedora, so we have to get the real "ip" path dynamicly by "whereis"
command, and then use it safely.

Change-Id: Ie5617e2cd086a6f3b1484526067373bb519d8a31
Related-Bug: 1381416

commit_message:
Stop using deprecated 'oslo' namespace

Replace usage of deprecated 'oslo' namespace with appropriate 'oslo_*'
namespaces in Manila setup.cfg file.

Change-Id: I3fbe75023d3dec266c0121df436639a2041eadd5

[{'created': '2015-06-03 18:00:11.000000000', 'message': 'Handle cells race condition deleting unscheduled instance

In cells, if a delete request comes in before an instance has been
scheduled to a cell, the API cell will broadcast a message to
delete the instance "everywhere" (in all cells) followed by a local
delete at the top. This causes a race between cells who have a
record for the instance syncing to the top via instance_destroy_at_top
and the local delete at the top (double delete is possible). If a
second delete is attemped, InstanceNotFound will be raised and
propagated up to the API, resulting in a 404 response to the caller
who requested to delete the instance.

This change catches and ignores InstanceNotFound during local delete
at the API cell to prevent propagating an error when the instance
has already been deleted.

Change-Id: Ic67f0f6edb0d38722787a6b88b39eae218110dc9

commit_message:
Handle cells race condition deleting unscheduled instance

In cells, if a delete request comes in before an instance has been
scheduled to a cell, the API cell will broadcast a message to
delete the instance "everywhere" (in all cells) followed by a local
delete at the top. This causes a race between cells who have a
record for the instance syncing to the top via instance_destroy_at_top
and the local delete at the top (double delete is possible). If a
second delete is attempted, InstanceNotFound will be raised and
propagated up to the API, resulting in a 404 response to the caller
who requested to delete the instance.

This change catches and ignores InstanceNotFound during local delete
at the API cell to prevent propagating an error when the instance
has already been deleted.

Change-Id: Ic67f0f6edb0d38722787a6b88b39eae218110dc9

I asked in INFRA about this patch. Clarkb was very helpful and provided me with this info: http://paste.openstack.org/show/WUH2i52icze85lmgtG7F

Though when I run the commands he talks about I do not see the test or the tag mentioned in my output.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2014-12-19 13:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Thanks Chris for asking about this patch.

When I run the commands he mention I can see the tag and that there's no changes on master, idk why gerrit shows that test being deleted tho (I will assume gerrit doesn't know how to represent this change correctly), see the my output here: http://paste.openstack.org/show/153160/

Plus, just a commenting about how the "I DON'T UNDERSTAND -1" works. When you submit a patch be it submitted by bot or a human, you *AWAYS* can use the commit message to indicate WHAT is that change and HOW it works, so it's definitely not our fault to -1 because we don't understand the change, "Ironic 2014.2" doesn't means anything to me, if they synthesize everything clarkb have said on IRC in the commit message we probably wouldn't have -1 this patch.'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2014-12-22 21:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

I'm not sure how long things stay pasted in paste.openstack.org, so copying the relevant bits here:

23:48 | clarkb > NobodyCam: and the question is? why is that test case removed?
23:48 | NobodyCam > yep
23:48 | clarkb > I love how people just go "I DON"T UNDERSTAND -1"
23:48 | NobodyCam > gota love the comment ?!?!?!?
23:48 | NobodyCam > I want to understand
23:48 | NobodyCam > soo I ask
23:48 | clarkb > so we merge tags back into master
23:49 | clarkb > we do this so that when you are on master you always have that tag in your history
23:49 | clarkb > so that logically on the git graph that version occurred in the psat prior to now
23:49 | clarkb > we do this in a way that keeps master's code with a pointer to the old code. So its a special merge
23:50 | clarkb > NobodyCam: the unfortunate bit is that gerrit doesn't render this well
23:50 | clarkb > NobodyCam: so the best way to review those is with git diff locally. you can do `git diff HEAD^` to see that there shouldn't be any diff against master
23:51 | clarkb > and you can `git describe --always` to see that the tag is now in your history. But you have to git remote update before you do that to ensure you have the tag available
23:52 | clarkb > and I can confirm running those that this is the case
23:53 | clarkb > and if you grep for the test that is "removed" it is there
23:53 | clarkb > I think that means that that test may have been removed on the tag side?'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2014-12-22 21:53:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Assuming clarkb knows what is going on, I see the tag and no differences in the code. I looked and I see that test in master AND in our tag 2014.2, so maybe git is confused or there is some bug in git, but I am not going to worry about it.

And yeah, it'd help if the commit had more information. I think it deserves a -1 just cuz the commit is not helpful, but anyway..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-12-23 13:14:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

commit_message:
Merge tag '2014.2'

This is a null-merge of the 2014.2 release tag back into the
master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: Icf942802a151d4816ce38fac343a70375720ed47

commit_message:
Make create task as non-blocking

Currently, the create task api is blocking and waits until the task
is complete to return a 201 but that too with a Pending status.

The patch runs the task executor in an eventlet thread.

Closes-Bug: #1459051

Change-Id: I94f932afb5b754d9bcfa7bbbd1c450bdef7f28ef

[{'account_id': 16433, 'date': '2015-05-27 15:52:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2015-05-27 15:52:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 16433, 'date': '2015-05-27 15:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9377, 'date': '2015-05-27 16:30:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-27 16:54:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Added documentation to tempest-account-generator

Added docstring to cmd/account_generator.py.
Fixed help messages.
Added sphinx documentation for tempest-account-generator utility.

Change-Id: I6640ba8a0eaaea187cf38582ab537394dec020b6

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-06 17:23:16.000000000', 'message': "virt: Move building the block_device_info dict into a method

The block_device_info structure is needed in several places, so it's
useful to move it into a method and remove the code repetition that is
all over the place.

Also make sure there is a single way to get the legacy dict format for
the drivers that need this (however at this point we should probably
remove that soon, and convert all the in-tree drivers to expect the new
format).

Related-bug: 1231874
Partial-bug: 1452224

Change-Id: I608042c58c04f333f6fbb8d9824eb8f3913c6310

commit_message:
virt: Move building the block_device_info dict into a method

The block_device_info structure is needed in several places, so it's
useful to move it into a method and remove the code repetition that is
all over the place.

Also make sure there is a single way to get the legacy dict format for
the drivers that need this (however at this point we should probably
remove that soon, and convert all the in-tree drivers to expect the new
format).

Related-bug: 1231874
Partial-bug: 1452224

Change-Id: I608042c58c04f333f6fbb8d9824eb8f3913c6310

commit_message:
Convert the Identity Management chapter to RST

Common files converted to RST and directly added to the Cloud Admin Guide (since they are not used elsewhere):
- Identity user management
- Identity service management
- Groups
- Troubleshoot the Identity service

Change-Id: Id109437e45144653d894b6d1bced3a6106db58d4
Implements: blueprint reorganise-user-guides

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-24 20:19:12.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Remove unnecessary JSON conversions

_get_instance_disk_info creates information as a list but returns a
JSON representation of the list. The JSON is repeatedly converted by
other methods that operate on the original list.

This change updates _get_instance_disk_info to return a list rather
than JSON. The get_instance_disk_info method still returns JSON --
the only difference between the methods is their arguments.

Change-Id: Iec47ed1c43007c7852bdf81945ffa0ff9003150f

commit_message:
libvirt: Remove unnecessary JSON conversions

_get_instance_disk_info creates information as a list but returns a
JSON representation of the list. The JSON is repeatedly converted by
other methods that operate on the original list.

This change updates _get_instance_disk_info to return a list rather
than JSON. The get_instance_disk_info method still returns JSON --
the only difference between the methods is their arguments.

Change-Id: Iec47ed1c43007c7852bdf81945ffa0ff9003150f

commit_message:
Fix several bugs in verify_tempest_config

The version of get_versions() in tempest_lib somehow lost the removal
of the first argument so we need to capture it.
The version checking was looking for explicit minor version matches but
it seems that some services bumped them. This commit fixes the check to
only look for a match against the major veresion number.

Note that the unit tests were passing in spite of this bug. It would be better
if devstack failed when calling this script if there were any changes
suggested.

Change-Id: I0eba11d54b63dc2078e6987789933c1dc4650b71

subject: Add acl settings for loadbalancer listener
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 09:59:39.000000000', 'message': 'Add acl settings for loadbalancer listener

Now user can set acl for haproxy frontend(lbaas listener).
Required params are: name, action, condition,
operator, match_condition.

One haproxy frontend acl will show like:
"""
acl name action condition
operator [match] if [name, [!name]...] match_condition
"""

Jira blueprint: OPENSTACK-321

Change-Id: I4d73031e3a73553acba748941027822d793bfa3a
'}]
commit_message:
Add acl settings for loadbalancer listener

Now user can set acl for haproxy frontend(lbaas listener).
Required params are: name, action, condition,
operator, match_condition.

One haproxy frontend acl will show like:
"""
acl name action condition
operator [match] if [name, [!name]...] match_condition
"""

Jira blueprint: OPENSTACK-321

Change-Id: I4d73031e3a73553acba748941027822d793bfa3a

commit_message:
Port remaining tests to Python 3

* Use bytes to handle image content
* Replace StringIO.StringIO with six.BytesIO for image content

Change-Id: I5ec4b8a685e95a701f6e8497695bd672dc22ec5e

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-04 13:39:19.000000000', 'message': "Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volumes container

There have been reports of cinder performing operations on the wrong
volume. This appears to be due to inconsistencies in the device
numbers recorded for the logical volume. The issue is difficult to
reproduce but appears to be related lvm not using udev.

LVM's use of udev was disabled due to the potential that the host would
be saturated with uevents from containers. The cinder-volumes container
runs on its own host and so this should not be an issue.

This commit adjusts the lvm.conf file created so that udev is used. It
also adds a mount entry to create a devtmpfs on /dev. Finally
'udevadm trigger' is run to add the devices under /dev/mapper. The
container creation configuration for cinder-volumes has been broken out
from other cinder containers so that these changes are targeted at the
relevant hosts.

Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0
"}, {'created': '2015-06-05 15:41:08.000000000', 'message': "Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volume container

The current configuration of LVM for cinder-volume has udev_sync=0.
This means that udev is not creating the devices that appear in /dev.
The device files created reference specific device numbers, and these
persist between reboots. When the host is rebooted there is no
guarantee that device numbers allocated to the logical volumes will
match those defined in the device files. This can be observed by
comparing the output of 'dmsetup info' and 'ls -l /dev/mapper'.

LVM's use of udev was disabled in an attempt to protect the host from
the potential that uevents generated would be processed by all
containers on the host. In practise this should not be an issue because
there are not other containers running on a cinder host.

This commit adjusts the lvm.conf file created so that udev is used. It
also adds a mount entry to create a devtmpfs on /dev. Finally
'udevadm trigger' is run to add the devices under /dev/mapper.
Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0
"}, {'created': '2015-06-05 21:34:01.000000000', 'message': "Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volume container

Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0

commit_message:
Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volume container

The current configuration of LVM for cinder-volume has udev_sync=0.
This means that udev is not creating the devices that appear in /dev.
The device files created reference specific device numbers, and these
persist between reboots. When the host is rebooted there is no
guarantee that device numbers allocated to the logical volumes will
match those defined in the device files. This can be observed by
comparing the output of 'dmsetup info' and 'ls -l /dev/mapper'.

LVM's use of udev was disabled in an attempt to protect the host from
the potential that uevents generated would be processed by all
containers on the host. In practise this should not be an issue because
there are not other containers running on a cinder host.

This commit adjusts the lvm.conf file created so that udev is used. It
also adds a mount entry to create a devtmpfs on /dev. Finally
'udevadm trigger' is run to add the devices under /dev/mapper.
Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0

commit_message:
Add validator to check parameter inside a dictionary argument

Currently the validator checks parameter inside args i.e.
{"args": "parameter"} but if the parameter is inside a
specific_args i.e. {"args": {"specific_args": "parameter"}
it fails to validate.
This is needed in scenarios like loadbalancer where the
parameter "subnet_id" could be specified in "pool_create_args"

Change-Id: Ic2dc13b84be107cd8c6add28a22835c448f1b71f

commit_message:
Python 3: use next() instead of iterator.next()

The latter only works in Python 2.

Also define a __next__ method in the classes that define a next method.

Change-Id: Iaa1a1e500facab50d8bcdffda39ccad3f2e4e9bb
Blueprint: neutron-python3

subject: Refactor of BaseTestCase
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-10 09:00:55.000000000', 'message': "Refactor of BaseTestCase

To run integratin tests, there needs to be set environment variable
INTEGRATION_TESTS. In past, positive behaviour was enclosed in one big
'if' branch.
I've moved negative behaviour to beginning and len rest of method as
ordinary function body.

Change-Id: Id96c6d416bc4fab2944c8431bbb147f9db5469d9
"}]
commit_message:
Refactor of BaseTestCase

To run integratin tests, there needs to be set environment variable
INTEGRATION_TESTS. In past, positive behaviour was enclosed in one big
'if' branch.
I've moved negative behaviour to beginning and len rest of method as
ordinary function body.

Change-Id: Id96c6d416bc4fab2944c8431bbb147f9db5469d9

commit_message:
libvirt: remove _get_disk_xml to use get_disk from Guest

Updates code to remove the method _get_disk_xml also this method
has been replaced with the method get_disk from the Guest object
which returns a LibvirtGuestDisk object.
Also update LibvirtGuestDisk to handle an undefined property

Change-Id: I896d390373731411fefe381f11872f3282cee48b

With the move of Bandit to test-requirements, you'll have to install all the other test requirements to install Bandit. commit_message:
Fix bandit tox environment to properly run

These changes were necessary:
- Move bandit dependency from test-requirements-bandit.txt to
  test-requirements.txt
- Only print high and medium severity errors (-ll)
- Rename blacklist_functions to proper plugin name of
  blacklist_calls

Change-Id: Ibf2a16e3fc62aadc995c70b5dfe2258f1cf23f85

commit_message:
[networking-guide] TCP/UDP/ICMP

Add TCP/UDP/ICMP overview to the "intro to basic networking" section of
networking guide.

Changed some text in other parts of "intro to basic networking" from future
tense to present tense.

Change-Id: I2c75f5728f6c5daeb9f9381d8e3e0e69767b4ac3

@Vitaly Don't agree. It is always better to fix generic problem than implement half-way solution."}, {'account_id': 8090, 'date': '2015-06-04 19:43:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

@Vitaly, I do not prefer to use int() here. For you do not know the type of your input value. From Horizon it is always string, but if from saharaclient, it can be any type. So it is better sahara api server transforms them in a general way before sending them to the engine backend to deal with.
And you do not either know whether you need to change a unknown type value into int or float, and int() may convert a input float value 1.1 into 1. That is not desired.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-05 03:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

commit_message:
Transform configuration values into int or float when needed

All configuration values from Horizon are read as string. We turn
them into int or float.

Closes-Bug: #1460763
Change-Id: I1c04dd74077624cb75d00cbd65692af1246b4d69

This issue does not seem to be a provisioning related issue because during provisioning we do not install this package, no matter if it is classic or IBP. The only place where I've managed to find xfsprog is swift puppet manifest. I think, we first need to ask xarses for additional info about this case."}, {'account_id': 8797, 'date': '2015-05-19 22:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8797, 'date': '2015-05-19 22:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Andrew, could you please resolve @Kozhukalov's question? We didn't need it before, so why now? And even if so, why not to install it during deployment?"}, {'account_id': 12200, 'date': '2015-05-26 12:45:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Igor,  pasting Andrews comment from bug:

If it's not installed and you need to fsck the file system you likely are read-only and will be unable to install anything, let alone get network loaded to attempt to install the package. leaving the user unable to access data in the event fsck was required. This creates loss in access to data, so therefor it can be High."}, {'account_id': 8003, 'date': '2015-05-26 15:38:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10391, 'date': '2015-05-26 16:08:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Sebastian,

I still do not understand.

Why did you add it only for trusty? Why skip centos? What about classic provisioning? Are you going to make a patch for it? Why we can't install it during deployment? Does it mean that in some cases without this package after provisioning we'll be unable to install anything at all?"}, {'account_id': 12200, 'date': '2015-05-26 17:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

@Igor there are other patches for centos and for classic provisioning, see bug or patch topic.


But, again, this bug is considered as invalid.'}, {'account_id': 12200, 'date': '2015-06-10 08:11:36.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

- check-ceilometerclient-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/33/184233/3/check/check-ceilometerclient-dsvm-functional/4d3df37/ : SUCCESS in 23m 13s'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2015-06-03 17:05:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Since under the covers this is still making multiple posts what's the specific benefit of this change? Is the desire to avoid the startup cost of the client for each sample? If that's the case, why use the client at all: just write some web requests?

(I'm not against the change I'm just trying to understand the reasons why.)"}, {'account_id': 7729, 'date': '2015-06-04 16:07:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi, Chris! 
We main point for using this patch it's rally tests. In rally now we have only benchmarks which check only base functional and they don't check any performance of ceilometer work. 

For example, statistic benchmark create only one sample and run statistics on it. I suggested to improve this benchmark to real load for out api. 
We need to specify amount of generated data for this implementation, but creating samples one by one it's bad and slow approach. So, 1000 samples by 1 batch are written 3 seconds, but writing 1000 samples 1 by 1 is a waste of our lives. 

So, we want to create rally api benchmarks which create a amount of samples (thousands) and get any statistics, lists and etc."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2015-06-05 10:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Cool, makes sense.'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2015-06-05 10:31:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7729, 'date': '2015-06-05 13:03:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3012, 'date': '2015-06-05 13:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-05 13:08:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Verified

commit_message:
Add capability for creating array of samples

Added method for creating array of samples to samples manager.
Added shell command for creating array of samples.
Added tests for this changes.
It is made for Rally tests that use big data arrays. So now only one
function may be called instead of numerous calls simple create function.

Change-Id: I01ba4f0c0db40c95ef72dadaa34b3fafc034e417

commit_message:
Monasca resource plugin for Alarm and Notification

Adds following resource plugins:
- OS::Monasca::Alarm
- OS::Monasca::Notification
- OS::Monasca::AlarmI
- Custom constrain 'monasca.notification'

blueprint support-monasca-alarm-notification

Change-Id: I27f071fa1bd79038875918aa32d276c16216a729

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code

[{'created': '2015-06-10 07:52:11.000000000', 'message': 'Check if user already exists before create_user

Before create user, call "keystone user-list" command instead of
"keystone user-list --tenant-id <tenant=id>" command to check if user

Change-Id: I5eb1aec1cbf50edb88fa75b6fd487c5ef93cac0d

commit_message:
Check if user already exists before create_user

Before create user, call "keystone user-list" command instead of
"keystone user-list --tenant-id <tenant=id>" command to check if user
already exists

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-09 17:11:29.000000000', 'message': 'Use latest version of python-cinderclient

Pre v1.2.2 of python-cinderclient a bug was introduced that meant
cinderclient was not using the "endpoint-type" option.

Bumping this to 1.2.2 ensures endpoint-type will work again for cinder.

Change-Id: I57f78dac8b433f4bab5f7865326329a5e9474073
Closes-Bug: #1463493
'}]
commit_message:
Use latest version of python-cinderclient

Pre v1.2.2 of python-cinderclient a bug was introduced that meant
cinderclient was not using the "endpoint-type" option.

Bumping this to 1.2.2 ensures endpoint-type will work again for cinder.

Change-Id: I57f78dac8b433f4bab5f7865326329a5e9474073
Closes-Bug: #1463493

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-02 20:39:30.000000000', 'message': "Add a reference for User Committee repos

Currently the User Committee doesn't have a place to track the
repos it owns. This patch adds a yaml file to track User
Committee repos.

A User Committee repo was created prior to this patch and is
currently in stackforge. The repo will be renamed to live in
the openstack/ namespace and the contents of this yaml file
will be updated to reflect its location when it changes.

Change-Id: If6dbd44266b95a189cd1746bfb245cf1c31616d0
Reference: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/185106/
"}]
commit_message:
Add a reference for User Committee repos

Currently the User Committee doesn't have a place to track the
repos it owns. This patch adds a yaml file to track User
Committee repos.

A User Committee repo was created prior to this patch and is
currently in stackforge. The repo will be renamed to live in
the openstack/ namespace and the contents of this yaml file
will be updated to reflect its location when it changes.

Change-Id: If6dbd44266b95a189cd1746bfb245cf1c31616d0
Reference: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/185106/

commit_message:
Merge tag '2015.1.0'

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: I69e520148633c8f1ec1be019ec83f06f11b84060

to embrace networking-midonet within its fold. This project provides

commit_message:
Add networking-midonet repo to Neutron

According to procedure defined in [1], this patch proposes Neutron
to embrace networking-midonet within its fold. This project provides
Neutron support for MidoNet. [2]

For more information on networking-midonet:
    https://github.com/stackforge/networking-midonet

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/doc/source/devref/sub_projects.rst
[2] http://midonet.org/

Change-Id: If7e812dd03285fdcb50ea220bfdcc7450803a221

[{'created': '2015-06-10 07:25:22.000000000', 'message': "Add babel-django plugin for Horizon

Horizon is migrating to babel to allow translation of AngularJS
based pages.

Rather than use a mix of Django's builtin i18n and babel Horizon
will also use the babel-django plugin for legacy i18n.

babel-django is available on the cheeseshop but will require
packaging.

It is in active maintenance (last updated 2015-04-22 for the Django
1.8 release).

License is BSD

Having this package available will simplify translation for
Horizon's new AngularJS based components and mean that Horizon is
more closely in line with other projects' i18n processes.

Change-Id: I06281979b42b72b26d2cdcfbcb12affadd490a4e
"}]
commit_message:
Add babel-django plugin for Horizon

Horizon is migrating to babel to allow translation of AngularJS
based pages.

Rather than use a mix of Django's builtin i18n and babel Horizon
will also use the babel-django plugin for legacy i18n.

babel-django is available on the cheeseshop but will require
packaging.

It is in active maintenance (last updated 2015-04-22 for the Django
1.8 release).

License is BSD

Having this package available will simplify translation for
Horizon's new AngularJS based components and mean that Horizon is
more closely in line with other projects' i18n processes.

Change-Id: I06281979b42b72b26d2cdcfbcb12affadd490a4e

commit_message:
Updated upgrade and deployment processes for https

This change simply makes sure that all containers and hosts have the
`apt-transport-https` package installed. this package is absolutly
required everywhere because we've changed all of the repo endpoints
to https and not all systems have this package installed on a base
kick. Furthermore an entry was added into the upgrade script to
ensure that upon upgrade everything will converge and remain
consistent.

Change-Id: I4b357ff7099a4c1c63c85ac9560aefc8d56709be
Closes-Bug: #1463155

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-22 20:42:45.000000000', 'message': 'Apply a naming rule of GET to compute clients(f*)

[GET /resources] methods should be "list_<resource name>s"
or "show_<resource name>", so this patch applies the rule
to compute clients which names are "f*".

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I3fdfa1101b966015798a61aa6ba5acfdf4649831
'}, {'created': '2015-06-08 05:32:33.000000000', 'message': 'Apply a naming rule of GET to compute clients(f*)

[GET /resources] methods should be "list_<resource name>s"
or "show_<resource name>", so this patch applies the rule
to compute clients which names are "f*".

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I3fdfa1101b966015798a61aa6ba5acfdf4649831
'}]
commit_message:
Apply a naming rule of GET to compute clients(f*)

[GET /resources] methods should be "list_<resource name>s"
or "show_<resource name>", so this patch applies the rule
to compute clients which names are "f*".

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I3fdfa1101b966015798a61aa6ba5acfdf4649831

This looks basically good.  However, we am not ready to make the SDK a requirement yet.  The integration would be pretty different than this if we did. The SDK Connection bits are roughly parallel to OSC's ClientManager, my intention has always been to use a low-level API from the SDK.  The lowest level it has is the Resources, which is still higher than I want but would work.

If this were an OSC plugin, using the SDK would be acceptable as it would not become an OSC dependency.  Although you might want to be able to leverage OSC's auth there is no requirement to do that.  If it behaves the same, users probably would not care."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2015-03-02 15:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I need to use the client to have Ceilometer and especially Gnocchi clients ready by Kilo. So can this be good enough and refactored later?'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2015-03-02 20:10:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

i'm OK with the sdk being pull in, i figured it will be pull ed in eventually anyway... 

left some comments on the patch, and i'd like to see an entry for alarms here https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/tree/master/doc/source/command-objects

also we need to get this change (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/159590/) merged before we continue to push osc changes"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2015-03-03 12:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
telemetry: add support for alarm creation

This adds a first telemetry operation which is alarm creation, using
openstacksdk.

Change-Id: I6d662ce8daafd7576504d70487187b764f916013

[{'created': '2015-03-26 22:26:22.000000000', 'message': "Enhance 'stop' and 'start' calls

If you run 'restack start' no check is made to see if the processes
are already running.  This can potentially cause multiple sets of
the Trove services to be running at the same time.

By the same token, calling 'stop' when several sets are running will
only remove one set, potentially leaving multiple sets still executing.

'start' now checks to make sure that no Trove process are running; if
so, a warning is emitted.  'stop' tries to remove up to 5 instances
of Trove processes.  If more than 5 are found a warning is emitted.

A 'restart' command was also added, which just calls 'stop' then
'start.'

A few of the help messages were also cleaned up.

Change-Id: I4df6490c437deecfe3c2723d5e7965b2114adc9f

commit_message:
Enhance 'stop' and 'start' calls

If you run 'redstack start' no check is made to see if the processes
are already running.  This can potentially cause multiple sets of
the Trove services to be running at the same time.

By the same token, calling 'stop' when several sets are running will
only remove one set, potentially leaving multiple sets still executing.

'start' now checks to make sure that no Trove process are running; if
so, a warning is emitted.  'stop' tries to remove up to 5 instances
of Trove processes.  If more than 5 are found a warning is emitted.
(5 was chosen arbitrarily so that failing to stop the processes
wouldn't result in an endless loop.)

A 'restart' command was also added, which just calls 'stop' then
'start.'

Change-Id: I4df6490c437deecfe3c2723d5e7965b2114adc9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-04 20:43:24.000000000', 'message': 'Defer segment lookup in port context object

Avoid call to get network segments for port context object until a caller
actually tries to lookup the segments. This optimizes cases where the user of a
port context never looks at the segments (e.g. update_port_status).

commit_message:
Defer segment lookup in NetworkContext object

Avoid call to get network segments for network context objects until
a caller actually tries to lookup the segments. This optimizes cases
where the user of a port context never looks at the segments of the
associated network context (e.g. update_port_status).

Closes-Bug: #1463254
Change-Id: I7e95f81d9a3ef26ccdb18c6bfdf9adc29523aa79

- vpnaas http://128.107.233.10:8080/job/vpnaas/2912 : FAILURE in 8m 51s"}, {'account_id': 14605, 'date': '2015-06-07 03:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2015-06-07 12:48:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14249, 'date': '2015-06-07 13:40:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2015-06-08 01:46:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

please don't remove the invalid config exception. the risk of breaking an out-of-tree driver/plugin for no strong reason isn't worth it."}, {'account_id': 11343, 'date': '2015-06-08 04:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Kevin,

Do you mean abandon this change completely or just remove that one exception?
I personally would want that out of tree plugins/drivers that use these exceptions will implement them in there own tree and thats one way to make them do it :)

But if you think thats currently not acceptable i will abandon this.'}, {'account_id': 6524, 'date': '2015-06-08 11:27:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I am kind of siding with Gal on this, i.e. out-of-tree plugins/drivers should define exceptions in their own repos if they are not used in the neutron core.

If the exception is "generic" this could result in multiple repos defining essentially the same exception separately, perhaps resulting in some inconsistencies like InvalidConfigurationOption in one driver vs. ConfigurationOptionNotValid in another. However, I don't see this as a problem.

Adding Armando to the review for his opinion.

Why are there so many bike sheds?'}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2015-06-08 21:27:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

FWIW, I vote remove it.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-08 21:33:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-06-09 23:38:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

The lib work can't happen fast enough. I both agree that since it's not a stable interface yet, go nuts, and that removing just to remove is reckless, given that we kicked everyone out."}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2015-06-09 23:59:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

https://github.com/nuage-networks/nuage-openstack-neutron/blob/245c5a157936c58dff189910f3447ce10c286807/nuage_neutron/plugins/nuage/common/exceptions.py#L20

I don't see the advantage to removing that exception. Yes, we can document and move on, but it's just creating work for devs.

Henry, I don't understand why they should be defining their own exceptions. Do we make them define their own testing setup helpers and everything as well? Exceptions are particularly bad because they result in user-facing error messages. I don't want to have 50 different vendors defining their own slightly different way to say there was a bad config value."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-06-10 00:02:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

To build on Kevin's point, vendor's won't localize, either."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 00:03:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

ok, leave it in. I was under the assumption that we had a process, albeit not perfect, to manage transient breakages. Perhaps this is a case where breakage is not justified, and that's okay, although I am puzzled by a double standard in place"}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2015-06-10 00:17:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We do have a process, but there should be some minimum criteria to cause a breakage (e.g. fixes an issue, is part of a refactor/reorg, required for a feature). This patch doesn't gain us anything so I don't see it being worth the effort involved for everyone to deal with the break."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-06-10 00:38:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Armando, I think it's more that we're in a state of flux, and badly need some stable interfaces. Once we have a blessed "lib", then we can make backwards compatibility sacrosanct, coupled with a long deprecation process, for just those routines. And then the neutron core can refactor like a mad puppet on meth that never sees the sun. But right now, we kicked everyone out, they're all reaching into the guts and calling stuff, and we don't even let them co-gate. Any change now has a pretty high cost to our related repos, and so in my mind, that means we should keep the purely cosmetic/cleanup stuff for later. IMO.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:33:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ok, does this apply just to the exception identified by Kevin or to the others too? In other words, is the patch an entire write-off or we can get rid of the lbaas related exception?

Let the bike shedding continue.'}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:38:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Does lbass still use it? Do others that we know of still use the policy exception? If so, I'd say abandon for now because we're not really gaining anything."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:39:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

well, we'd be losing a pretext for bike shedding...I think that's an important loss."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:42:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

I'm gonna vote +2 here mostly to sway my stats and continue the bike shedding.

Seriously, are we now optimizing for out-of-tree plugins at this point, or are we optimizing for efficiency of the in-tree core code? Playing devil's advocate in this game of yak shedding."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:50:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

Kyle, we split all this stuff out, before identifying stable interfaces, I thought, to force us to identify and stabilize them (else it'd never happen.)  Now that we've kicked everything out, but BEFORE we've stabilized anything, it's time to take a chainsaw to the internals? That seems to be a giant middle-finger to anyone out of tree. AND WE PUT THEM THERE. I'm against it until *WE* do the work to fix the mess we created.

(Sorry to pick on this patch; you're not the first, nor is it personal.)"}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

Fair enough. The dreaded double -2 hammer has commenced.

See, I can be reasonable. :)'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:53:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:54:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:54:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

bah'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:56:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

it seems like we're overreacting, no-one is giving the middle finger to anyone."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Likely.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-06-10 01:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 02:08:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Ah!'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 02:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Gotcha!'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-06-10 02:09:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 6524, 'date': '2015-06-10 02:57:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Kumbaya?'}, {'account_id': 11343, 'date': '2015-06-10 07:01:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Sorry but the review party has ended :)
I abandon this since there is no agreement to move forward.

There were some valid points raised regarding common error message interface, but in general i think that this decomposition process is not going to happen unless we set some specific dates.

In those dates the plugin vendors must understand that their out-of-tree code might be broken and they need to align it. (if they still have code referenced from Neutron which is not an API)

Otherwise it will be very hard to move forward with this task.'}]

neutron-lbaas, neutron-fwaas and neutron-vpnaas

[{'created': '2015-03-18 11:11:57.000000000', 'message': "Fix schema type of `additionalProperties` to support null values

Right now the `additionalProperties` field in permissive schema has type
set to 'string'. It's invalid behaviour, because additional
properties can contain null values as well, so we are changing it to
support ['null', 'string'] types.

Change-Id: Ie124fc47fec8219401e9d0d1b3f17394af30089e
Closes-Bug: 1419823
"}]
commit_message:
Fix schema type of `additionalProperties` to support null values

Right now the `additionalProperties` field in permissive schema has type
set to 'string'. It's invalid behaviour, because additional
properties can contain null values as well, so we are changing it to
support ['null', 'string'] types.

Change-Id: Ie124fc47fec8219401e9d0d1b3f17394af30089e
Closes-Bug: 1419823

commit_message:
Use timeout varibale for assert_task_success

In huge_environments test we set bigger timeout variable for
    deploy_cluster_wait but don't set when invoke assert_task_success
    method. Because of this behavior assert_task_success uses default
    timeout 7800 sec

Change-Id: I97ea23601f9acf3060b9b59bbd95c96e9aa4cc4b
Closes-bug: #1449596
(cherry picked from commit ec2544ac85f63bdb55237bb17c9acd21d5f00f16)

[{'created': '2015-06-08 19:30:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix DRAC driver job completion detection

The DRAC driver code determined job completion by comparing the
returned JobStatus to "completed" and "failed".  Testing with hardware
showed that JobStatus can also return "Completed with Errors".

"Completed with Errors" for the JobStatus as a completed job.

Change-Id: I051d6703194231712f0234f31b0b49208bf0e6ec

The DRAC driver code determined job completion by comparing the
returned JobStatus to "completed" and "failed".  Testing with hardware
showed that JobStatus can also return "Completed with Errors".

This change updates the DRAC driver so that it recognizes a job with

commit_message:
Fix DRAC driver job completion detection

The DRAC driver code determined job completion by comparing the
returned JobStatus to "completed" and "failed".  Testing with hardware
showed that JobStatus can also return "Completed with Errors".

This change updates the DRAC driver so that it recognizes a job with
"Completed with Errors" for the JobStatus as a completed job.

Change-Id: I051d6703194231712f0234f31b0b49208bf0e6ec
Closes-Bug: 1462513

[{'created': '2015-06-05 22:51:14.000000000', 'message': 'Launch Instance NG - Create Volume if Nova Ext

The new angular launch instance does not look at
allowCreateVolumeFromImage property to determine whether
or not to show "create from volume". That property is
being set based on if the nova extension is enabled that

commit_message:
Launch Instance NG - Create Volume if Nova Ext

The new angular launch instance does not look at
allowCreateVolumeFromImage property to determine whether
or not to show "create from volume". That property is
being set based on if the nova extension is enabled that
supports it.

Change-Id: I7670d2cfdbb6c0ee3638c5a2783cb234b6f5267f
Closes-Bug: #1462547

commit_message:
Split engine service test cases (5)

This patch separates out test cases related to stack create and
validation. The patch also replaced the existing mox calls with mock
calls.

Change-Id: I167edf7b063f66c835a07d5143f02bd07f62e0a0

commit_message:
Merge tag '2014.2'

This is a null-merge of the 2014.2 release tag back into the
master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: I46c0f42fde056803278f44797375812d605c2af0

commit_message:
Fix wrong definition of assert

Fix warning error message in unittests log, which was added in patch
Ie881a1bdb88f4bcb1c03c037bcedf2a328d5d41c:

"heat/engine/attributes.py:80: SyntaxWarning: assertion is always true,
perhaps remove parentheses?"

Change-Id: I165d3a1f4e281debd8afb390520f18fc59084b87

commit_message:
Merge tag '2015.1.0'

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: I7467bea4c34a852b4efd9ebb8178aa8c77e9a7f7

commit_message:
Switch to plugin base deployengines and serverproviders

This patch switch to plugin base and unify
deployengines and serverproviders plugins.

Co-authored-by: Olga Kopylova <olkonami@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Boris Pavlovic <boris@pavlovic.me>

Change-Id: I06fdef2a176266ab37325a421c10d386045cc2b9

commit_message:
Fix testing of agent manager with tooz

The test test_load_plugins_pollster_list_forbidden is currently failing
because the agent tries to load the tooz driver before doing the sanity
check. That makes tooz trying to load an http driver that does not
exist, and the test fails.

Let's do the check before anything else to fix that.

Closes-Bug: #1463636
Change-Id: I646ac0ed0fb9db04fa81f10cd8da0ac7bff5c138

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-20 01:08:39.000000000', 'message': 'Switch from MySQL-python to PyMySQL

As discussed in the Liberty Design Summit "Moving apps to Python 3"
cross-project workshop, the way forward in the near future is to
switch to the pure-python PyMySQL library as a default.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-cross-project-python3

Change-Id: I5aa90236424818e9a70f28619b5da5f47330d4e5
'}]
commit_message:
Switch from MySQL-python to PyMySQL

As discussed in the Liberty Design Summit "Moving apps to Python 3"
cross-project workshop, the way forward in the near future is to
switch to the pure-python PyMySQL library as a default.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-cross-project-python3

Change-Id: I5aa90236424818e9a70f28619b5da5f47330d4e5

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-09 20:57:10.000000000', 'message': "Turn debug logging on for beaker jobs

Inexplicably, the current version of beaker defaults to not verbosely
logging its actions. This is a problem when run in a CI environment
because we always want as much information as possible. Setting the
environment variable BEAKER_debug to 'yes' returns the sane behavior.
This variable is documented here[1].

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/beaker/wiki/How-to-Write-a-Beaker-Test-for-a-Module#supported-env-variables

Change-Id: Ifd8450803bc8ab8780e81fa74feb0f455ce6be13
"}]
commit_message:
Turn debug logging on for beaker jobs

Inexplicably, the current version of beaker defaults to not verbosely
logging its actions. This is a problem when run in a CI environment
because we always want as much information as possible. Setting the
environment variable BEAKER_debug to 'yes' returns the sane behavior.
This variable is documented here[1].

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/beaker/wiki/How-to-Write-a-Beaker-Test-for-a-Module#supported-env-variables

Change-Id: Ifd8450803bc8ab8780e81fa74feb0f455ce6be13

[{'created': '2015-06-10 04:15:27.000000000', 'message': 'Moving Node update earlier in cluster create flow

Moving Node update to happen earlier in the cluster create process, such
that node VM ID is recorded regardless of cluster create success or
failure so that any VMs created during a failed cluster create can be
properly destroyed.

Change-Id: I0c46e18986c615948300b145a9e68bc6607e13ec
Closes-Bug: 1463605
'}]
commit_message:
Moving Node update earlier in cluster create flow

Moving Node update to happen earlier in the cluster create process, such
that node VM ID is recorded regardless of cluster create success or
failure so that any VMs created during a failed cluster create can be
properly destroyed.

Change-Id: I0c46e18986c615948300b145a9e68bc6607e13ec
Closes-Bug: 1463605

I am one of the authors of the other spec. Our implementation uses exclusively the router's IP address, and doesn't need to use any floating IPs.
The extension has been working successfully on our Icehouse and Juno clouds.
It is already available on Stackforge (https://github.com/stackforge/networking-portforwarding) if you want to check it out.
Moreover, we have developed further code that hasn't been published, e.g. unit tests for this extension, neutronclient and horizon support."}, {'account_id': 11126, 'date': '2015-05-15 02:28:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Add port forwarding to VM via port of floating IP

This Spec intends to implement a portforwarding function via floating ip
fip address1:port 22010 -> fixed ip address1: port 22
fip address1:port 22011 -> fixed ip address2: port 22

This function offers the connection to many VMs from public network
by a few floating(global) IPs.

Change-Id: I571427df4f68111c94028165b87bf79fc4a7d904
Blueprint: fip-portforwarding

About my objections to the provider code knowing that 'request' is implemented using ENV:

Yes, I am fully aware that we have to support ENV anyway.  Operators expect to be able to set ENV.  And rc files are used with the expectation that ENV will be set.  And the openstack command uses ENV.  

However, I still think the interface would be better if the providers did not know that - abstraction, implementation hiding, all that CS mumbo jumbo.

But, if I am overruled by the wider community, I withhold my objections, I won't -1, I just want this code to work and be supported/supportable."}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-22 01:21:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-08 05:51:36.000000000', 'message': 'redefined source of authentication information

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. The environment ENV[<OS_*]
  2. A RC file located by convention in current user homedir: ~/openrc
  3. Configuration file like keystone.conf or glance.conf (managed by providers,
     for now)

  User/Tenant/Token credentials can be passed but have to come from above list.

  As discussed [1], this removes purposefully the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to an instance of the resource.

  Note: The rc file data is now directly expanded in the environment.

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: I0294e57e5a1408ea364182302a734e2292ae0af4
Depends-On: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
'}, {'created': '2015-05-13 13:00:40.000000000', 'message': 'Refined source of authentication information

  This is base on using interface (module Auth) to provide class methods to
  provider (provider/keystone.rb) instead of relying on class inheritance
  which turned out to cause unnecessary complexity.

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. The environment ENV[<OS_*]
  2. A RC file located by convention in current user homedir: ~/openrc
  3. Configuration file like keystone.conf or glance.conf

  As discussed [1], this removes purposefully the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to an instance of the resource.

  Note: The rc file data is now directly expanded in the environment.

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: I0294e57e5a1408ea364182302a734e2292ae0af4
Depends-On: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
'}, {'created': '2015-05-13 13:03:23.000000000', 'message': 'Refined source of authentication information

  This is base on using interface (module Auth) to provide class methods to
  provider (provider/keystone.rb) instead of relying on class inheritance
  which turned out to cause unnecessary complexity.

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. The environment ENV[<OS_*]
  2. A RC file located by convention in current user homedir: ~/openrc
  3. Configuration file like keystone.conf or glance.conf

  As discussed [1], this removes purposefully the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to an instance of the resource.

  Note: The rc file data is now directly expanded in the environment.

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

  Uses module Auth defined in openstacklib/lib/provider/openstack.rb
  (see Depends-On) to get class methods to the providers.
  Instead of relying on class inheritance which turned out to cause unnecessary
  complexity.

Uses module Auth defined in openstacklib/lib/provider/openstack.rb, see
Depends-On, to get class methods to the providers. Instead of relying on class
inheritance which turned out to cause unnecessary complexity.

per provider basis.

commit_message:
Restructures authentication for resource providers

- Uses module Auth defined in openstacklib (see Depends-On)
respectively offering class methods for the providers.
Instead of relying on class inheritance which turned out to cause unnecessary
complexity.
- Also make use of Credentials (see Depends-On) object to keep authentication
details.

Change-Id: I0294e57e5a1408ea364182302a734e2292ae0af4
Depends-On: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
Implements: blueprint auth-restructure

commit_message:
Tacker Horizon: ImportError: No module named openstack_dashboard.dashboards

Fix up imports in new stackforge tacker-horizon repo to
use tacker_horizon module

Closes Bug: #1463648
Change-Id: I578b64727eb51e4511851207dc03760a5b95ab03

commit_message:
Add metadata size tests on the border

This patch adds a test for a 204 when a single metadata item in a POST causes
the backend aggregate constraints check to be on the border.

Background:
Overall metadata size constraint is enforced in the container and
account backends as well as in the proxy controllers.
Whereas the proxy controller can check that constraints are not exceeded
by a single PUT or POST request, the backend checks that constraints are not
exceeded by the aggregate of all PUTs and POSTs.

The change [1] added a test for a 400 when a single metadata item in
a POST causes the backend aggregate constraints check to go over limit.

[1] I1489e29686013cbd3d70283d8756b548aea3c2e1

Change-Id: Iac86ea71240ddde177e625c279c21aef67659d10

subject: Change usage help and Attention messages to warnings
messages:
[{'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2015-06-03 12:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2015-06-03 12:23:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The current usage says both containers and objects are options but in fact you can't specify an object w/o a container so I clarified.

I also felt the Attention! mismatch messages were misleading for a few reasons:
- they sound like errors when in fact they're warnings
- the message doesn't really say why there's a mismatch

I'm not particularly thrilled with my new messages but the fact is the code explicitly tests for rings named 'account' and 'container'.  If the names aren't required to be those, which I don't think they need to be, perhaps the tests/messages should be completely removed instead."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-03 13:00:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-swift-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/74/187974/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/34d7dba/ : SUCCESS in 2m 14s
- gate-swift-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/74/187974/1/check/gate-swift-docs/910a229//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 48s
- gate-swift-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/74/187974/1/check/gate-swift-python27/227349d/ : FAILURE in 4m 34s
- gate-swift-tox-func http://logs.openstack.org/74/187974/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func/bd854f9/ : SUCCESS in 5m 42s (non-voting)
- check-tempest-dsvm-full http://logs.openstack.org/74/187974/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-full/919d1d8/ : SUCCESS in 41m 35s
- check-grenade-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/74/187974/1/check/check-grenade-dsvm/a2400d5/ : SUCCESS in 41m 46s
- check-swift-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/74/187974/1/check/check-swift-dsvm-functional/5212cb5/ : SUCCESS in 18m 56s'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2015-06-03 14:01:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2015-06-03 14:28:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Nitpick about spacing in the usage message.

BTW, the *reason* for those warnings is that it's possible to look up, say, "account container object" in the account.ring.gz file and get an answer, but it'll be wrong.  The only thing that can detect that pilot error is convention in ring naming and that warning in the tool.

Perhaps that rationale for the code can guide the warning messages?  The ones for account and account/container seem fine, but the warning for policy != ring still doesn't seem as good as it could be.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-06-03 14:31:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-06-03 14:32:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

sorry, hit submit before typing message !

I like the change to Warning from Attention. Darrell already spotted the missing space.

I'd prefer no to see "error" for something that is actually ignored.'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2015-06-03 14:49:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2015-06-03 14:56:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've made the requested changes and still can't help but wonder if there are any other places in the code base that look for explicit ring names.  I do remain somewhat bothered  that while you can name a ring anything you want, this code only checks your args when you follow the naming convention, one of the reasons I changed the messages the way I did.

I'm also not sure what happens if you specify a policy and the name of the ring isn't object.  It looks like it won't see the policy.  Does this mean you HAVE to name your object right object-policy?  I remain confused..."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2015-06-03 15:10:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

One more nit.

On a less tactical level, I'm not sure there's value in really worrying about or messing with the existing naming convention for ring files.  It's there to reduce operator error and doesn't hurt anything AFAICT."}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2015-06-03 15:19:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2015-06-03 15:22:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I actually considered name vs names at the time I made the patch and thought since we're talking about 2 of them it should be plural, but then again I wasn't an english major so will defer to everyone when it comes to grammer.

I'd still like to hear others weigh in on whether or not there are any potential risks in not following the naming convention for rings and if so perhaps stronger messages should be generated."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-03 19:04:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

What's the use-case for ring files that aren't "account.ring.gz", "container.ring.gz", "object.ring.gz", and "object-#.ring.gz"?

Maybe knowing the use-case would garner more interest?'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-06-04 09:27:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

For the record (since I see discussion in irc) - my out of band comment to Mark was that while _swift_ may require* rings named [account, container, object[-N]], _swift-get-nodes_ does not and maybe there is someone that I don't know about takes advantage of that for some reason I don't know about (e.g. to run swift-get-nodes on an old ring file) ... so I would be hesitant about changing the name checking in _swift_get_nodes_ from a warning to a fail.

If there is consensus from others that we should force the naming convention then I'll learn from that and reconsider my hesitancy.

* I noticed that swift.proxy.server.Application does in fact accept account and container ring objects as constructor args which then override the default 'named' ring files. I have no reason to think anyone uses that, but its there."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-06-04 09:33:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-04 10:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Having spoken with Paul Luse about storage policy's use of ring names, he told me the object ring MUST be named object-index.

If people agree, I could add code to check if the specified ring matches '.*-\d+$' and if it does print a warning that it looks like it has a policy but is not named 'object-'.  Clearly a hack, but otherwise the policy index would be ignored and nobody would know why."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2015-06-05 02:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

I'm going to echo Alistair's comment. In the server code (ie what's deployed to prod), the rings have a certain name, and they must be that. However, swift-get-nodes doesn't need to enforce that. The warning messages are good.

Also, I'd echo the use case of "I've got a ring file in my home dir and want to see what's happening with it, not what's in /etc/swift/". Or "I've got an old ring file in /etc/swift that I want to explore".'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-06-05 12:44:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(3 comments)

So I think the options are:

(a) remove the call to hash_cleanup_listdir in _finalize_put,
create a method that calls hash_cleanup_listdir in a tpool, call that from DiskFileWriter.commit() and also from delete() and write_metadata()

or (less churn):

(b) leave the call to hash_cleanup_listdir in _finalize_put but make it conditional on a flag that ECDiskFileWriter.put() can set when calling _finalize_put()

(b) looks like this: http://paste.openstack.org/show/212481/

Either way I'd like to add some unit tests to verify the cleanup is done (or ensure they are there already) but I have run out of time today so will suggest something tomorrow."}, {'account_id': 13104, 'date': '2015-05-01 04:27:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13104, 'date': '2015-05-01 04:38:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

@Minwoo - I think you were close in earlier version, just need to make cleanup be non-optional (positional) arg in _finalize_put. (My bad for suggesting cleanup=True to begin with).

There are place where you'll see keyword args added to functions - that can be good practice where there are many call sites (so lots of code churn to add new arg to all call sites) or where some code outside of swift core may be using an interface. But here _finalize_put is only used in the module (and the _ at the start should warn anyone off calling it from outside) so I think Pete is correct to point out the better style."}, {'account_id': 13104, 'date': '2015-06-02 19:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 13104, 'date': '2015-06-02 19:59:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
The hash_cleanup_listdir function should only be called when necessary.

Introduced a conditional that will specify to _finalize_put() whether
the put() method is being called within the context of ECDiskFileWriter.

Included some unit tests that will test the number of calls to
hash_cleanup_listdir() during put(), commit(), and delete()
operations.

Change-Id: I287b2648591fdbf686898dc9047beda80a64da0c

(1 comment)

Hi Christopher, thanks for the patch. Typically, when people update this, they tend to update it for the three types of OSs.

I don't have the time to look into RHEL7 right now and am using py2.7.

My suggestion (unless you want to figure it out for all these OSs) is to perhaps change 'Install prerequisites' to 'Install prerequisites for python 2.7'. Since it isn't clear that the existing instructions work for 3.4, might as well clarify and find out later if that is true or not :-)

Then before (or after?) 'Install these on all distros', add a new 'Using python 3.4:' with some verbiage about if you want to use python 3.4 instead (or in addition to?, not sure) python 2.7, for fedora 21, sudo yum install python3-devel.

That way, we have a place to gather information about using py3.4.

Or do something else that you think will make it clear that you are only updating it for fedora 21."}, {'account_id': 10250, 'date': '2015-05-28 20:58:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hey Ruby, thanks for the review.  I really don't have time to test out all of the different OS's either.  I decided to take a crack at RHEL7 though.  It turns out that gcc is required to be installed for both RHEL7 and Fedora.  Python3 is provided in the RH Software Collections Library repo, but unfortunately what's there is 3.3, not 3.4.  As a result, the dev would have to do something like pull down 3.4 RPMs from a different source or build from source, which would require more changes to the doc.  Either way, this ended up being more work than I had time for.  Unfortunately this means that the current instructions won't work for RHEL7 either before or after this patch (though this patch does take a step in the right direction by adding gcc to the required patches).

I don't think it would be a good idea to have different sections for different version of python since this might imply to the dev that one or the other can be used.  Since both tox and the gate run the unit tests under both py27 & py34 this is not the case: both have to be present.

The end result of all of this is that I left gcc in the combined Fedora/RHEL section and moved python3-devel into a Fedora specific section."}, {'account_id': 10250, 'date': '2015-05-28 21:16:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-28 21:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Hi Chris, thanks for looking into RHEL7.

It is true though that you only need python 2.7 or python 3.4 in your dev environment to be able to do something. You only need both if you want to be able to run the unit tests locally. For instance, I only do development with python 2.7 and leave it for Jenkins to point out the 3.4 issues.

So personally, I think it is fine to explicitly mention (and/or have two different sections). As long as whatever we document is clear enough :-)'}, {'account_id': 5805, 'date': '2015-05-28 23:32:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Add additional required RPMs to dev instructions

Changed dev quick start instructions to include installing gcc and
python3-devel as these are required to be present on (at least)
Fedora 21 server.

Change-Id: I576231cc3ecfda6407279b0326dbe54a408a64e0

subject: Add support for image deactivate and reactivate

ValidationError: u'deactivated' is not one of [u'queued', u'saving', u'active', u'killed', u'deleted', u'pending_delete']

Thoughts ?

commit_message:
Add support for image deactivate and reactivate

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Glance-deactivate-image
Adding the api support for these commands.
Deactivate and reactivate image action is done by admin tenant.

- Added admin folder to image tests
- Added support for admin image classes for v1 and v2
- Added config deactivate_image , this feature is not running on
  icehouse
- Added a testcase for image deactivate.

Depends-On: Ia1d3d811bd57d3de16d397cfab341e8d0f17cb69
Change-Id: I7880f0e2646ce8660e035ebaa19a60f5bf271b64

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-14 04:59:09.000000000', 'message': "Don't raise exception on resize of 0 disk flavors

An exception should not be raised if someone uses a flavor with
a 0 disk size during a resize.

Change-Id: I183740c974c2ba7e0608c28c05fa28a34a5e1966
Fixes-Bug: #1443697
"}, {'created': '2015-04-14 05:01:02.000000000', 'message': "VMware: Don't raise exception on resize of 0 disk

commit_message:
VMware: Don't raise exception on resize of 0 disk

An exception should not be raised if someone resizes and instance
to a flavor with a zero disk size.

Change-Id: I183740c974c2ba7e0608c28c05fa28a34a5e1966
Fixes-Bug: #1443697

checking the order in update l2gateway

checking the correct order of device and interfaces
while updating l2gateway for kilo code base.

Change-Id: I9b6d0e86c6577929230d58e7403fbefab167f36b
'}, {'created': '2015-03-06 14:06:46.000000000', 'message': 'Domain layer for Artifact Repository

Introduces a layered domain model for Artifact Repository designed
similar to the domain model of v2 Images: a number of proxies for
Artifact Objects, their Repositories and collections split into layers
by appropriate functional aspect.

The following layers are added:
 * Database Repository layer - encapsulates DB APIs;
 * Dependencies Layer - encapsulates dependecy management (artifact ids
   are mapped to the actual Artifact References and back);
 * Location Layer - encapsulates store interaction for Blobs (similar to
   location layer of Images API);
 * Updater layer - wraps the collection-based properties of Artifacts
   for proper updates by JSONPatch calls.

Artifact-specific layers are added into "artifacts" subdirectory of
domain package. A gateway which creates layered proxy is added as well.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository

Co-Authored-By: Mike Fedosin <mfedosin@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Inessa Vasilevskaya <ivasilevskaya@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexander Tivelkov <ativelkov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I9b6d0e86c6577929230d58e7403fbefab167f36b

   are mapped to the actual Artifact References and back);
 * Location Layer - encapsulates store interaction for Blobs (similar to
   location layer of Images API);
 * Updater layer - wraps the collection-based properties of Artifacts
   for proper updates by JSONPatch calls.

Artifact-specific layers are added into "artifacts" subdirectory of
domain package. A gateway which creates layered proxy is added as well.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository

Co-Authored-By: Mike Fedosin <mfedosin@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Inessa Vasilevskaya <ivasilevskaya@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexander Tivelkov <ativelkov@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Domain layer for Artifact Repository

Introduces a layered domain model for Artifact Repository designed
similar to the domain model of v2 Images: a number of proxies for
Artifact Objects, their Repositories and collections split into layers
by appropriate functional aspect.

The following layers are added:
 * Database Repository layer - encapsulates DB APIs;
 * Dependencies Layer - encapsulates dependecy management (artifact ids
   are mapped to the actual Artifact References and back);
 * Location Layer - encapsulates store interaction for Blobs (similar to
   location layer of Images API);
 * Updater layer - wraps the collection-based properties of Artifacts
   for proper updates by JSONPatch calls.

Artifact-specific layers are added into "artifacts" subdirectory of
domain package. A gateway which creates layered proxy is added as well.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository

FastTrack

Co-Authored-By: Mike Fedosin <mfedosin@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Inessa Vasilevskaya <ivasilevskaya@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexander Tivelkov <ativelkov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I9b6d0e86c6577929230d58e7403fbefab167f36b
