(4 comments)

Looks really good! I just added a couple of question inline. 

I also noticed that the document yet doesn't discuss how encryption would be enabled or at what level? Is this a storage policy setting or account/container header? What's the thought so far?"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2015-02-20 19:59:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11330, 'date': '2015-02-20 20:52:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thiago, re: how encryption would be enabled or at what level?

Our design was a setting in the cluster configuration, whether encryption is supported  and on or off, and then per-container settable by the user.  (User could only turn encryption on, but not off for existing container.)
Every object newly stored to an encrypted container is then encrypted on PUT.

In discussions with Sam, I had understood he wanted all-or-nothing, one setting for the whole cluster.

As the current design allows incremental deployment, I would let the cluster operator set a default for newly created accounts and containers.  If that default is off and the user wants it, he specifies encryption on with a header upon creating the account or container.  Again, once an account/container has the encryption option on, it should not be possible for the user to turn this off again (to keep the implementation simpler).'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2015-02-20 21:15:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

FWIW, I like the suggestion from Christian. I think encryption should be set at the container level, I think it would work better for third-party storage policies. just my 2 cents...'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2015-02-20 21:34:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'm not a big fan of the one-way ratchet for encryption. I just know that if we do it that way, I'm going to get a support ticket from a user who turned encryption on and now *demands* that it be turned back off because ${reasons}."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2015-02-20 21:37:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I don't see that adding any extra complexity, BTW. On GET, we already have to check to see if the object needs decryption because the object might pre-date the crypto middleware. On PUT, if we're doing anything other than "always encrypt", we already have to check to see if this object should be encrypted or not. Letting the user toggle the crypto-desired state back and forth doesn't really affect much.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-02-23 09:40:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)

Re: how is encryption enabled? Great question - a specific answer has been deferred, deliberately, to keymaster implementation - See section 2.2, line 128. The keymaster is responsible for deciding if any particular resource should be encrypted. That seemed to me a reasonable separation of concerns, and allows for different approaches to be encapsulated in different keymaster implementations and/or configurations.

Much of this patch to the spec is about adding sufficient support for flexible application of encryption: cluster-wide, per container, per-account...whatever the keymaster chooses, plus supporting upgrade from no-crypto to crypto. 

Critically, we need to allow for co-existence of encrypted and unencrypted objects in accounts and container if we are to support upgrade - even if the post-upgrade crypto-policy is to encrypt everything. The approach we propose is flexible enough to allow changes (as Sam says - there's not really any penalty with this approach to allowing crypto to be turned on then off on a container if the keymaster chooses to do so).

A keymaster implementation could choose to encrypt everything. It could base a decision on container policy (but it is not bound to). It could base a decision on account. The keymaster could allow client requests to set crypto policy on accounts/containers (via client headers that the keymaster might transform to sysmeta and store on containers). Alternatively the keymaster could apply crypto policy and not support client originated headers. All keymaster-implementation dependent."}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2015-03-02 21:11:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Code-Review

(1 comment)

I have been reading deeper into the details about the ETAG and I still have questions about who we will accomplish everything that is needed.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2015-03-02 21:39:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I would like to add support for a "key_id" so that one object could be mapped to more than one key, if the keymaster requires that.  The need arises because some encrypted data can be updated at different times than other data.  For a discussion of this, see https://trello.com/c/INSyyfpy/31-may-need-to-add-support-for-fetching-a-different-key-for-header-data-updated-on-a-post'}, {'account_id': 12193, 'date': '2015-05-11 10:10:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Alistair, Janie, Great work!

One question:
If decripter, keymaster and encripter were configured in pipeline, would the cluster handle only encrypted data (account, container and object)?

I'm not sure whether customers who require this function might need non-encrypted clusters. Do you have info about that kind of requirements?"}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2015-05-11 14:29:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Hello Hisashi,
If decripter, keymaster and encripter are configured in the pipeline, then the default behavior is to encrypt all newly created items (a/c/o), but still handle requests against any existing objects which were not encrypted (they remain unencrypted).  However, we are building in an "encryption override" flag that can be set by your keymaster to support having new objects that do not get encrypted.

Do you think that this will support the expected client needs?  We are open to ideas.'}, {'account_id': 12193, 'date': '2015-05-12 02:51:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

Hello Janie, Thanks for the explanation. When I read this spec first time, a concern "how to enable this function? What is the relationship b/w storage policies?" so I asked the question. I found that the answer for my concern was written in "Enforce a single immutable cipher choice per container". 

From flexible configuration point of view, I think it is better to have this function on storage policy (with Daisuke's proposal).

This spec is great but I would like to discuss about following points at summit so I put -1.

* Scale limitation
  If a cluster is configured with this function, Keymaster has to handle all objects which are stored in swift.
* Flexible configuration
  Swift in large clound environment might be built on various storage products. And some storage products may have data-at-rest encryption. In this case it is better to offload the encryption to the storage products.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-05-12 15:38:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

@Hisashi - thanks for your comments. The reasons for not binding cipher choice to container policy are discussed in the 'alternatives' section. 

That does not mean that cipher choice (including no encryption) cannot be made on a per-container basis, it just means that we are not assuming, nor requiring, that the cipher choice is *immutable* for a container because that is challenging to implement and inflexible.

In practice, a keymaster implementation may well choose to encrypt or not encrypt on a per-container basis, and can use the override flag Janie mentioned to indicate 'not encrypted' to the encrypter/decrypter. The keymaster *may* choose to base its choice on the container storage policy, but it is not required to do so, and it is able to change its choice of cipher during the lifetime of a container if it needs to.

So I think the approach we are proposing is more flexible than binding the cipher choice to storage policy.

Re your questions:
1. Scale limitation
Our spec does not *require* the keymaster to generate a key for every object. It may well be that a keymaster implementation will choose to do that, and the keymaster will then need to scale accordingly, but the spec allows for keymasters that use the same key for all objects in the same container for example, or chooses not to encrypt some objects.

2. Flexible configuration
If an operator wants do encryption at the storage subsystem level then this spec does not prevent that. That could be easily achieved by having the keymaster NOT generate keys for containers whose policy maps to certain storage subsystems.

In general, the degree of flexibility is determined by the keymaster implementation and we are deliberately not prescribing that implementation. We will of course benefit from a good reference implementation!"}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-05-13 13:42:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2015-05-13 14:50:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:01:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

@Janie and Alistair, spec is looking very good. It is very cool to see the progress that's been made since the hackathon.

One suggestion I would make is to clearly call out how a swift cluster could have data that is encrypted and not encrypted. From following the discussions on the comments above it seems that this would be possible by implementing different keymasters, but I think this is a question that would occur frequently, so I would just spell that out in the doc.
Another point to make is that it seems we are planning to support one key per object (as opposed to per container), I remember there were some discussions regarding the scalability of that approach and again I understand that this is up to the keymaster implementation, but I think it would be good to mention something here too, especially since the trivial keymaster being implemented is providing a key per object."}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2015-05-14 02:17:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2015-05-14 02:20:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

commit_message:
Updates to encryption spec

This patch updates the spec with changes discussed at the
San Francisco hackathon, Feb 2015:
* User metadata names will not be encrypted.
* Detail on storing crypto related metadata for each
  resource.
* Encrypted etags will be sent at end of MIME multipart body.
* Keymaster may set a request environ variable to indicate that
encryption or decryption is not to be applied to a particular
request.

Co-Authored-By: Janie Richling <jrichli@us.ibm.com>

Change-Id: I2b7a77e6161650aaf2219e7ca92068e19831da9a

commit_message:
Add InvalidIpForSubnetClient exception

A new Neutron exception type, InvalidIpForSubnetClient, is added by
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/121767/ . Need to let Neutron client to
identify this new exception type.

Change-Id: Ib4f0d7af3807f96463c82d1d2a1e53b56081facc
Partial-Bug: 1369871

commit_message:
Revocation engine refactoring

Rewritten RevokeTree.is_revoked method to be more readable
and use less dynamic objects.
Recursion is used.

Implements bp revoke-tree-refactoring

Change-Id: I77fea330ee64f42c80ac7010a0c4dc4b8cbdfb07

Change-Id: I553b4d6daeb78d495cda09894582a3d885b5d1b5
'}]
commit_message:
Break Pinger class to functions

As the class served only for storing parameters that can be passed as
actual function parameters, there is no reason for class.

Change-Id: I553b4d6daeb78d495cda09894582a3d885b5d1b5

commit_message:
Add a comment on _check_update_has_security_groups

Despite of its name, _check_update_has_security_groups can
handle create requests as well.  There are plugins actually
using it for create.  eg. ml2, vmware

Change-Id: I3c26ad0ac00b12ce24096bfc27606797af2d9098

Hi Doug!

We do this to make sure the tag is in the master branch so that git history looks correct. This is a consequence of how the releases are cut on the proposed branch.

It's a null merge - so it's not actually merging any content. Gerrit is showing you the content that the null merge is not merging - I know, not very useful.

We're going to regenerate this - please merge it."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2015-06-09 13:56:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Merge tag '2015.1.0'

This is a null-merge of the 2015.1.0 release tag back into the master
branch so that the 2015.1.0 tag will appear in the git commit history of
the master branch. It contains no actual changes to the master branch,
regardless of how our code review system's UI represents it. Please
ask in #openstack-infra if you have any questions, and otherwise try
to merge this as quickly as possible to avoid later conflicts on the
master branch.

Change-Id: Iba4587072d48836ee0d5cf7bf9b176bd0c2d6545

commit_message:
LBaaS v2: Fix listing pool members

The command `neutron lbaas-member-list POOLID` should list members that
belong to a given pool. Instead, it lists all members for all pools.
This patch corrects this behavior.

Change-Id: Ida80e17831865924a0e114417371faa437cce2ba
Closes-Bug: #1454986

If the resource[:auth] is gone, how will https://review.openstack.org/180369 work? How will the providers pass in the config_file and config_file_section to the openstack provider?  Add new parameters to the request method?'}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-06 14:43:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Maybe they just don't pass anything?
They could just set up the environment with what they need.
Actually more I think about it more it makes sense for each provider to keep that in its scope."}, {'account_id': 9983, 'date': '2015-05-06 14:57:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Maybe they just don't pass anything? They could just set up the environment with what they need. Actually more I think about it more it makes sense for each provider to keep that in its scope.

I'm not sure what you mean.  Do you mean the providers will parse the config file and convert the parameters to environment variables?  Then the config file parsing code I wrote will need to be moved to util, and will just parse the file and set environment variables.

In general, I don't like passing things around as environment variables.  For passwords/tokens, this provides additional security from someone using ps to snoop the command line arguments, which I believe the old provider used.
The problem with environment variables is that they have global scope, and so are like passing around global variables.  That means you have to be very careful about removing them after use.

For example - let's say that you are installing both glance and cinder on the same machine, and let's say that glance.conf and cinder.conf are configured with different authentication.  If puppet-glance runs first, it will set all of its authentication environment variables.  If glance is not very careful to remove all of them, some of them will be in effect when puppet-cinder runs, and runs the risk of using incorrect auth.

Is there a way in puppet/ruby to set only the env for an executed command so that the env will apply only to the executed command and not to the whole puppet process?"}, {'account_id': 9983, 'date': '2015-05-06 21:33:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Note that OSC now has its own config file:  http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/configuration.html#configuration-files

I don't know if ruby has a built-in mechanism to pass env per command, but the old icehouse keystone.rb provider did just that with the "withenv" command.'}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-07 01:13:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I meant to not use the provider instance to pass any information.

Data must be passed to providers through type interface using params and properties.

Also, using ENV is already the default main approach of Openstack and therefore related Puppet modules for setting values, keystonerc being the same. Security wise, ENV variables are not visible in ps commands.
At contrary commands spawned with arguments --os-token=<blab> are visible to ps.

Yes good idea to control the context of a command method in providers using has_commands method for example.'}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-07 07:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-07 07:33:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

(2 comments)

I think this mostly looks good so far, except for the tests. I'll be able to get a better idea once there is a puppet-keystone patch using this.

I'm curious how the Auth module will be used by the other modules.

I think you might have an easier time with load path issues if everything in Auth simply lived in Puppet::Provider::Openstack."}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-13 23:48:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

(2 comments)

> I'll be able to get a better idea once there is a puppet-keystone patch using this.

You can test using https://review.openstack.org/#/c/181299/3
it's implementing it. 

> I'm curious how the Auth module will be used by the other modules.

Should be same as keystone one

> I think you might have an easier time with load path issues if everything in Auth simply lived in Puppet::Provider::Openstack.

Auth is a module used by openstack providers sub classes not the super class Puppet::Provider:Openstack.
By extending Auth into sub-classes such as Puppet::Provider:Keystone, the latter gets class methods, at the sub class lever, not the super. Since it's good practice to have modules self contained, I used puppetx. But I suppose the module could be sitting together in the puppet/provider/openstack.rb file.
Something like that, if it makes sense

module Puppet::Provider::Auth
...
end


class Puppet::Provider::Openstack < Puppet::Provider
...
end


Thank you for the feedback"}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-14 05:54:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-14 06:05:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Verified+1

(7 comments)

I haven't tested this yet, will be able to do so in a little bit.

Most of the comments I made are nits I can live with. The -1 is because 1) I disagree with merging environment variables and rc variables together, I think this will make debugging very difficult, and 2) I'm not sure how the new API module is being used, maybe you could explain or maybe https://review.openstack.org/#/c/181299 needs some more work.

This seems to be failing the functional tests which should be working now, maybe a rebase against master would be able to kick that off?"}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-19 02:27:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 26:

(7 comments)

> 1) I disagree with merging environment variables and rc variables together, I think this will make debugging very difficult

We don't use command line type of arguments such as --os-password, because this is a security risk.
So we're using withenv to pass an environment context to execute commands

>  2) I'm not sure how the new API module is being used, maybe you could explain or maybe https://review.openstack.org/#/c/181299 needs some more work.

The (identity) API class, needs move to keystone module were it belongs.
 
The idea behind is to set the identity API version on a per provider basis (thus the instance variable at class level):  

@identity_api = Puppet::Provider::Keystone.new('2')

This is used in the auth module, for example, to set OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION before executing OSC request:  

env.merge!(@identity_api.env) if @identity_api

> This seems to be failing the functional tests which should be working now, maybe a rebase against master would be able to kick that off?

Will do.

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-19 02:37:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26:

Is something wrong with the work flow? (From comments on patch 26?)

First we have an Environment we inherit OS variables from.
We extract them and store them in 'env'.
Then we also take the RC's OS variables and add them to 'env'.
The operation is run using withenv using 'env' context.

Is this not respecting the order of precedence that was defined?"}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-21 20:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9983, 'date': '2015-05-21 21:19:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

No matter where I define OS_TOKEN/OS_URL, it will override everything else.  If OS_TOKEN/OS_URL is defined in rc, it will override any/all other authentication.  If OS_TOKEN/OS_URL is defined anywhere, it will always be used instead of OS_USERNAME/OS_PASSWORD.

If this is ok with everyone, and is understood by operators, then I have no problem with it.  It just seems odd to me, but maybe it's just me."}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-22 01:15:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Code-Review-1

Agreed with Richard

We can to better and move the withen along the core request.
Working onto it.'}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-26 12:53:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 31.'}, {'account_id': 6525, 'date': '2015-05-26 13:08:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32: Patch Set 31 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-26 13:28:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32: Verified-1

>> 1) I disagree with merging environment variables and rc variables together, I think this will make debugging very difficult
> We don't use command line type of arguments such as --os-password, because this is a security risk. So we're using withenv to pass an environment context to execute commands

That's not what I meant. I mean that we should either get credentials ALL from the environment or ALL from the openrc or ALL from the conf file. We shouldn't merge credentials from an openrc into existing variables from the environment because if a user partially sets some of the variables in one group, and the rest are drawn from another group, it will get very confusing. For example, if the user typo'd and accidentally set OS_USENAME=admin in the environment and then had an openrc that set OS_USERNAME=test with a different password, it will try to use the admin password from the environment and test's password from the openrc and fail to authenticate. It's hard to diagnose this kind of error. So I don't think credentials should be taken from two groups, I think if not all the credentials are found in the environment then it should seek all of them from the openrc, not try to pick which ones from each group it can find."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-27 01:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 33: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-06 05:49:46.000000000', 'message': 'Predefined source of authentication information

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. The environment ENV[<OS_*]
  2. A RC file located by convention in current user homedir: ~/openstackrc
  3. Configuration file like keystone.conf or glance.conf (managed by providers,
     for now)

  User/Tenant/Token credentials can be passed but have to come from above list.

  As discussed [1], this removes purposefully the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to an instance of the resource.

  Note: The openstackrc data is now directly expended in the environment.

  Review for puppet-keystone to follow suit.

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755

'}, {'created': '2015-05-09 02:29:58.000000000', 'message': 'Predefined source of authentication information

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. The environment ENV[<OS_*]
  2. A RC file located by convention in current user homedir: ~/openrc
  3. Configuration file like keystone.conf or glance.conf (managed by providers,
     for now)

  User/Tenant/Token credentials can be passed but have to come from above list.

  The resource provider can use auth_override_hash to create a blank
  environment hash, then use withenv authentication_env(hash) to execute
  authenticate_request with custom or override parameters.

  As discussed [1], this removes purposefully the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to an instance of the resource.

  Note: The rc file data is now directly expanded in the environment.

  Review for puppet-keystone to follow suit.

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
Implements: blueprint auth-consolidation
'}, {'created': '2015-05-10 21:17:31.000000000', 'message': "Predefined source of authentication information

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. A RC file located by convention in current user homedir: ~/openrc
  2. Configuration file like keystone.conf or glance.conf (managed by providers,
     for now)
  3. The environment ENV['OS_*']
  4. An override from the resource provider.
  The numbers define the precedence.  For example, parameters specified in
  the application config file override parameters specified in the RC file.
  Parameters in the environment override both the app config and the RC.
  The override parameters override everything else.

  User/Tenant/Token credentials can be passed but have to come from above list.

  The resource provider can use auth_override_hash to create a blank
  environment hash, then use withenv authentication_env(hash) to execute
  authenticate_request with custom or override parameters.

  The Keystone authentication parameters are passed to the openstack command
  in the environment.  The withenv method is used to guarantee that the
  global environment is not polluted by each command invocation.

  As discussed [1], this removes purposefully the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to an instance of the resource.

  Note: The rc file data is now directly expanded in the environment.

  Review for puppet-keystone to follow suit.

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
Implements: blueprint auth-consolidation

  4. An override from the resource provider.
  The numbers define the precedence.  For example, parameters specified in
  the application config file override parameters specified in the RC file.
  Parameters in the environment override both the app config and the RC.
  The override parameters override everything else.

  User/Tenant/Token credentials can be passed but have to come from above list.

  The resource provider can use auth_override_hash to create a blank
  environment hash, then use withenv authentication_env(hash) to execute
  authenticate_request with custom or override parameters.

  The Keystone authentication parameters are passed to the openstack command
  in the environment.  The withenv method is used to guarantee that the
  global environment is not polluted by each command invocation.

  As discussed [1], this removes purposefully the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to an instance of the resource.

  Note: The rc file data is now directly expanded in the environment.

  Review for puppet-keystone to follow suit.

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
Implements: blueprint auth-consolidation

"}, {'created': '2015-05-18 05:22:42.000000000', 'message': "Refined source of authentication information

"}, {'created': '2015-05-27 05:02:17.000000000', 'message': "Refined authentication sources

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. The environment variables (ENV['OS_*'])
  2. If not enough, credentials available from the environment RC file
     to be used. Default RC file must be in current user homedir: ~/openrc

  - Adds module Puppet::Provider::Openstack::Auth providing class methods for
  providers instead of relying on superclass inheritance.
  As discussed [1], this purposefully removes the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to Puppet resources instances.

  - Wraps credentials information with object:
    Puppet::Provider::Openstack::Credentials

  - The credentials information is used in a withenv block

  Review for puppet-keystone needs to be merged at same time:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/181299/

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
Implements: blueprint auth-consolidation

  - The credentials information is used in a withenv block

  Review for puppet-keystone needs to be merged at same time:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/181299/

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
Implements: blueprint auth-restructure
"}, {'created': '2015-05-27 23:45:05.000000000', 'message': "Restructures authentication for resource providers

  2. If not enough, credentials available from the environment RC file

commit_message:
Restructures authentication for resource providers

  Workflow to find credentials details from:
  1. The environment variables (ENV['OS_*'])
  2. If not enough, credentials available from the environment RC file
     to be used. Default RC file must be in current user homedir: ~/openrc

  - Adds module Puppet::Provider::Openstack::Auth providing class methods for
  providers instead of relying on superclass inheritance.
  As discussed [1], this purposefully removes the possibility to pass authenti-
  cation details as parameters to Puppet resources instances.

  - Wraps credentials information with object:
    Puppet::Provider::Openstack::Credentials

  - The credentials information is used in a withenv block

  Review for puppet-keystone needs to be merged at same time:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/181299/

  [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063352.html

Change-Id: If628f4ad95f3aac3392475d4ea6857fb858f8755
Implements: blueprint auth-restructure

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-04 02:00:29.000000000', 'message': "Fix _quota_reserve test setup for incompatible type checking

The db.quota_reserve() method expects to get project_quotas and
user_quotas as dicts that map resource types to limits which are ints.

The _quota_reserve test setup method was just mapping the resource type
to the Quota sqlalchemy dict-like object that was coming back from
db.quota_create. Since db._calculate_overquota compares the delta (int)
to the user_quotas/project_quotas value, which was a Quota object, and
py34 doesn't allow incompatible type checks like that, this fails with
py34.

This fixes the _quota_reserve test setup method to map the resource type
to the hard_limit like the actual DB APIs do in the normal nova.quota
flows.  It also has to adjust the setup method to avoid going over-quota
immediately due to the limit and usage being the same (which is why we
add a buffer to the i value for the limit).

Closes-Bug: #1461665

Change-Id: I9f5f537eff58fe83caa7bff2fb0800ce9f7272fa
"}]
commit_message:
Fix _quota_reserve test setup for incompatible type checking

The db.quota_reserve() method expects to get project_quotas and
user_quotas as dicts that map resource types to limits which are ints.

The _quota_reserve test setup method was just mapping the resource type
to the Quota sqlalchemy dict-like object that was coming back from
db.quota_create. Since db._calculate_overquota compares the delta (int)
to the user_quotas/project_quotas value, which was a Quota object, and
py34 doesn't allow incompatible type checks like that, this fails with
py34.

This fixes the _quota_reserve test setup method to map the resource type
to the hard_limit like the actual DB APIs do in the normal nova.quota
flows.  It also has to adjust the setup method to avoid going over-quota
immediately due to the limit and usage being the same (which is why we
add a buffer to the i value for the limit).

Closes-Bug: #1461665

Change-Id: I9f5f537eff58fe83caa7bff2fb0800ce9f7272fa

commit_message:
devstack/settings.odl: syntax error

When running devstack, the following syntax error comes out

> /opt/stack/networking-odl/devstack/settings.odl: line 42: ODL_KARAF_LOG_BASE: screen-karaf.log: syntax error: invalid arithmetic operator (error token is ".log")

Change-Id: Ibd2ee38825986163920e721c6a1580fe49d1bf6f
Closes-Bug: #1463549

[{'created': '2015-06-09 20:49:55.000000000', 'message': 'devstack: unzip -u may wait for user input

When there is an existing opendaylight package expanded,
unzip -u may wait for user input without any input.
For automation, it should overwrite without prompting.
So -o (overwrite existing files without prompting) should be
used for zunip.

Change-Id: Ic85ba531797a4f394bb8e47222bd97dc9300f65d
Closes-Bug: #1463558
'}]
commit_message:
devstack: unzip -u may wait for user input

When there is an existing opendaylight package expanded,
unzip -u may wait for user input without any input.
For automation, it should overwrite without prompting.
So -o (overwrite existing files without prompting) should be
used for zunip.

Change-Id: Ic85ba531797a4f394bb8e47222bd97dc9300f65d
Closes-Bug: #1463558

commit_message:
devstack: OFFLINE=True is ignored

Even if OFFLINE=True, plugin.sh tries to access to the internet.
It shouldn't download any from the internet when OFFLINE=True.
As a bonus, it doesn't update opendaylight karaf package when
unnecessary.

Closes-Bug: #1463529
Change-Id: I38ead6e9c8738ed6979f07fedaeb0bf88d5f3e86

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-09 15:36:10.000000000', 'message': 'Modify GetResourceErrorStatus exception

Variable "fault" was not used in exception message. It produced unclear
error messages, like:
   Resource <Server: rally_novaserver_aKO6sw5xHdOPZbEC> has ERROR status:

The end of such messages looks unfinished.

Proposed change removes this variable from exception message at all.

Change-Id: Ic27ace0fdc6eea2ee8d437fc2a0efc10d0b8e960
'}]
commit_message:
Modify GetResourceErrorStatus exception

Variable "fault" was not used in exception message. It produced unclear
error messages, like:
   Resource <Server: rally_novaserver_aKO6sw5xHdOPZbEC> has ERROR status:

The end of such messages looks unfinished.

Proposed change removes this variable from exception message at all.

Change-Id: Ic27ace0fdc6eea2ee8d437fc2a0efc10d0b8e960

commit_message:
Make subcommands accept flavor name.

This change makes following subcommands accept flavor name.

- create
- cluster-create
- cluster-delete
- resize-instance

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1463274
Change-Id: I8e22460b9038ee5cd85727fbe1403f88298caa09

commit_message:
Model and migration for cisco providernet extension driver

This commit adds model changes and alembic migrations scripts for
the Cisco Nexus providernet extension driver.

Change-Id: If0a85e6d64e1dc13eaa7ad12d57b70cc0d044f4e
Partially-implements: blueprint cisco-nexus-providernet-extension-driver

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14024, 'date': '2015-03-05 13:14:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

(1 comment)

Currently this patch allows a script per-agent as this is defined in 'l3_agent.ini'.

Most of the time the this script will be used to check connectivity to a gateway (which will be common).

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-17 12:23:25.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for Keepalived health check script.

Currently we have no way of conditioning an HA router's
state with a custom events.
This is needed in some scenarios that require tracking a
specific entity (i.e. pinging a host's interface) or event
(i.e. a process that is no longer running).

This patch adds the ablitiy to hook user-defined scripts
that will be executed every interval (currently 2 sec).

These script's exit code is used by keepalived to either
change the VR to FAULT state (script failed) or to BACKUP
state (script successful).

The script file is defined in 'l3_agent.ini' under the new
parameter 'ha_health_check_script_path'. the file
specified in that parameter value will be used by keepalived
as a 'track_script' to be ran every 'interval' seconds.

Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171

Closes-Bug: #1365461
Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171
"}, {'created': '2015-02-17 12:27:31.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for Keepalived health check script.

Currently we have no way of conditioning an HA router's
state with a custom events.
This is needed in some scenarios that require tracking a
specific entity (i.e. pinging a host's interface) or event
(i.e. a process that is no longer running).

This patch adds the ablitiy to hook user-defined scripts
that will be executed every interval (currently 2 sec).

These script's exit code is used by keepalived to either
change the VR to FAULT state (script failed) or to BACKUP
state (script successful).

The script file is defined in 'l3_agent.ini' under the new
parameter 'ha_health_check_script_path'. the file
specified in that parameter value will be used by keepalived
as a 'track_script' to be ran every 'interval' seconds.

The scripts allow the user to cause VRRP fail-over once
an event has/hasn't occurred for 2 consecutive checks in a row.

Closes-Bug: #1365461
Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171

"}, {'created': '2015-02-18 06:59:35.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for Keepalived health check script.

Currently we have no way of conditioning an HA router's
state with a custom events.
This is needed in some scenarios that require tracking a
specific entity (i.e. pinging a host's interface) or event
(i.e. a process that is no longer running).

This patch adds the ablitiy to hook user-defined scripts
that will be executed every interval (currently 2 sec).

These script's exit code is used by keepalived to either
change the VR to FAULT state (script returned '0') or 
to BACKUP state (script returned value other then '0').

The script file is defined in 'l3_agent.ini' under the new
parameter 'ha_health_check_script_path'. the file
specified in that parameter value will be used by keepalived
as a 'track_script' to be ran every 'interval' seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1365461
DocImpact:
The 'l3_agent.ini' config file can take a parameter
'ha_health_check_script_path' which should contain a 
full path to a bash script that behaves as detailed 
in the commit message.
Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171

"}, {'created': '2015-02-18 07:52:15.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for Keepalived health check script.

Currently we have no way of conditioning an HA router's
state with a custom events.
This is needed in some scenarios that require tracking a
specific entity (i.e. pinging a host's interface) or event
(i.e. a process that is no longer running).

This patch adds the ablitiy to hook user-defined scripts
that will be executed every interval (currently 2 sec).

These script's exit code is used by keepalived to either
change the VR to FAULT state (script exited with
value other then '0' - fail) or to BACKUP state (script
exited with '0' - success).

The script file is defined in 'l3_agent.ini' under the new
parameter 'ha_health_check_script_path'. the file
specified in that parameter value will be used by keepalived
as a 'track_script' to be ran every 'interval' seconds.

DocImpact:
Added a new parameter to 'l3_agent.ini' named
'ha_health_check_script_path' that can accept a full path
of a bash script. The script behavior should match the
details in this commit message above.

Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171
"}, {'created': '2015-02-19 06:35:51.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for Keepalived health check script.

Currently we have no way of conditioning an HA router's
state with a custom events.
This is needed in some scenarios that require tracking a
specific entity (i.e. pinging a host's interface) or event
(i.e. a process that is no longer running).

This patch adds the ablitiy to hook user-defined scripts
that will be executed every interval (currently 2 sec).

These script's exit code is used by keepalived to
change the VR to FAULT state (script exited with
value other then '0' - fail)

If the VR is currently in FAULT state and the script
exited with code '0' (success) then the VR will move to
BACKUP. If the VR is MASTER and the script succeeds the
VR will remain MASTER.

The script file is defined in 'l3_agent.ini' under the new
parameter 'ha_health_check_script_path'. the file
specified in that parameter value will be used by keepalived
as a 'track_script' to be ran every 'interval' seconds.

DocImpact:
Added a new parameter to 'l3_agent.ini' named
'ha_health_check_script_path' that can accept a full path
of a bash script. The script behavior should match the
details in this commit message above.

Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171

"}, {'created': '2015-02-22 11:52:04.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for Keepalived health check script

Currently we have no way of conditioning an HA router's
state with a custom events.
This is needed in some scenarios that require tracking a
specific entity (i.e. pinging a host's interface) or event
(i.e. a process that is no longer running).

This patch adds the ablitiy to hook user-defined scripts
that will be executed every interval (currently 2 sec).

These script's exit code is used by keepalived to
change the VR to FAULT state (script exited with
value other then '0' - fail)

If the VR is currently in FAULT state and the script
exited with code '0' (success) then the VR will move to
BACKUP. If the VR is MASTER and the script succeeds the
VR will remain MASTER.

The script file is defined in 'l3_agent.ini' under the new
parameter 'ha_health_check_script_path'. the file
specified in that parameter value will be used by keepalived
as a 'track_script' to be ran every 'interval' seconds.

DocImpact:
Added a new parameter to 'l3_agent.ini' named
'ha_health_check_script_path' that can accept a full path
of a bash script. The script behavior should match the
details in this commit message above.

Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171

commit_message:
Adding support for Keepalived health check script

Currently we have no way of conditioning an HA router's
state with a custom events.
This is needed in some scenarios that require tracking a
specific entity (i.e. pinging a host's interface) or event
(i.e. a process that is no longer running).

This patch adds the ablitiy to hook user-defined scripts
that will be executed every interval (currently 2 sec).

These script's exit code is used by keepalived to
change the VR to FAULT state (script exited with
value other then '0' - fail)

If the VR is currently in FAULT state and the script
exited with code '0' (success) then the VR will move to
BACKUP. If the VR is MASTER and the script succeeds the
VR will remain MASTER.

The script file is defined in 'l3_agent.ini' under the new
parameter 'ha_health_check_script_path'. the file
specified in that parameter value will be used by keepalived
as a 'track_script' to be ran according to the new
'ha_health_check_script_interval' parameter in
'l3_agent.ini'. This parameter has a default value of
5 seconds.

DocImpact:
Added a new parameter to 'l3_agent.ini' named
'ha_health_check_script_path' that can accept a full path
of a bash script. The script behavior should match the
details in this commit message above.
Added a new parameter to 'l3_agent.ini' named
'ha_health_check_script_interval' which will determine
the VRRP health check interval in seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1365461

Change-Id: I43b285e164f346b7b7f2ab99bc3272e2527cf171

commit_message:
Test IP allocation in two SLAAC subnets

Test creates two stateless IPv6 subnets and check that each IP in
these subnets is SLAAC and calculated from MAC address.
DDT support was added according to agreement with Marc and Mathew

Closes-Bug: 1358709
Change-Id: Id6476923d527830123a8a3a650e24fb59ad15dde

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 14216, 'date': '2015-05-02 02:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Anuta NCX mechanism driver

This driver acts as a proxy for plugin that runs inside the NCX server.
This driver simply redirects the network, subnet and port action payload to NCX server using NCX RestAPI.

Change-Id: I62d8ba3db0215a8746c5d34c198a9d06aad7d9ce
Implements: NCX mechanism driver

commit_message:
Add service group as a firewall customized service

This patch introduces reference implementation,
currently firewall rule can refer multiple service groups to allow the
user flexibilty to define their own groups and use them without impacting
the other users.

More info can be found at service group wiki
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/FWaaS/FWaaS-ServiceGroup
Implements: blueprint fwaas-customized-service for customized service
Authored-by: badveli vishnuvardhan <badveli_vishnuus@yahoo.com>

Change-Id: I18f69917027f2c5ba3f00fbacb1c8a242c8cf06f

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-06 07:13:13.000000000', 'message': 'To give proper reason during delete-port with VIP associated

When an VIP is associated with particular subnet and when an port is
deleted, 500 internal server error is thrown. This fix will give
proper error message.

Closes-Bug: #1430394
Change-Id: I28bdb7f3bf4219ec9856d8a89d73b1bdfce8fb38
'}]
commit_message:
To give proper reason during delete-port with VIP associated

When an VIP is associated with particular subnet and when an port is
deleted, 500 internal server error is thrown. This fix will give
proper error message.

Closes-Bug: #1430394
Change-Id: I28bdb7f3bf4219ec9856d8a89d73b1bdfce8fb38

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-30 20:26:17.000000000', 'message': 'WIP delay fip namespace cleanup/destroy

The agent_gateway_port and fip-ns are shared resources
across ext-networds and routers for a given agent.  While
debugging intermittent failures on the dvr experimental
job, traces indicate there may be a race condition between
when these shared resources are beeing added and deleted.

This patch does 2 things to debug and resolve the race
condition:
1. Delays destroying the objects via fullsync
2. Validates destroying the namespace by scanning for
remaining ports.

This patch is very much a WIP and is mostly being used
to isolate the race condition above.

Related-bug: #1415522

Change-Id: Iade09e4d3ae329e5c9d3c70ac9802b262b9f727f

Change-Id: Iade09e4d3ae329e5c9d3c70ac9802b262b9f727f
'}, {'created': '2015-03-03 22:37:00.000000000', 'message': 'WIP delay fip namespace cleanup/destroy

The agent_gateway_port and fip-ns are shared resources
across ext-networks and routers for a given agent.  While
debugging intermittent failures on the dvr experimental
job, traces indicate there may be a race condition between
when these shared resources are beeing added and deleted.

This patch does the following to debug and resolve the race
condition:
1. Delays destroying the objects via fullsync for FIP
delete or dissassociate.  Router delete is the only
other time when the fip namespace will possibly be destroyed.
2. Validates destroying the namespace by checking the
fip_ns object subscribe list.  This list is used by
any router which uses the fip_ns object.

This patch is very much a WIP and is mostly being used
to isolate the race condition above.

Related-bug: #1415522

Change-Id: Iade09e4d3ae329e5c9d3c70ac9802b262b9f727f

debugging intermittent failures on the dvr experimental

This patch does the following to debug and resolve the race

1. Delays destroying the objects via fullsync for FIP

other time when the fip namespace will possibly be destroyed.

commit_message:
delay fip namespace cleanup/destroy

The agent_gateway_port and fip-ns are shared resources
across ext-networks and routers for a given agent.  While
debugging intermittent failures on the dvr experimental
job, traces indicate there may be a race condition between
when these shared resources are beeing added and deleted.

This patch does the following to debug and resolve the race
condition:
1. Delays destroying the objects via fullsync for FIP
delete or dissassociate.  Router delete is the only
other time when the fip namespace will possibly be destroyed.
This should reduce the churn of port and ns creation and
deletion.
2. Validates destroying the namespace by checking the
fip_ns object subscribe list.  This list is used by
any router which uses the fip_ns object.

Related-bug: #1415522

Change-Id: Iade09e4d3ae329e5c9d3c70ac9802b262b9f727f

This change defines TcNatDriver: driver to manage tc-based (stateless)
nat and neutron.agent.linux.tc_lib module. This module provides low
level drivers to manage ingress/egress nat filters in tc.

Stateless nat doesn't support to reach natted ports/vms from internal
networks using their floating ips because stateless nat is not able to
differentiate natted/non-natted traffics (it always rewrites natted
ports/vms egress traffics). A follow-up change will define an hybrid nat
driver to use stateless nat for north/south traffic and stateful nat for
east/west traffic.

Related-Bug: #1334926

commit_message:
Define TcNatDriver stateless nat driver

This change defines TcNatDriver: driver to manage tc-based (stateless)
nat and neutron.agent.linux.tc_lib module. This module provides low
level drivers to manage ingress/egress nat filters in tc.

Stateless nat doesn't support to reach natted ports/vms from internal
networks using their floating ips because stateless nat is not able to
differentiate natted/non-natted traffics (it always rewrites natted
ports/vms egress traffics). A follow-up change will define an hybrid nat
driver to use stateless nat for north/south traffic and stateful nat for
east/west traffic.

Related-Bug: #1334926
Partially-Implements: blueprint stateless-floatingips
Change-Id: Id2e8c084381c8552e7f8641724ca083aaa23cb01

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-09 17:13:22.000000000', 'message': 'Stop processing testr artifacts in post_test_hook

A recent change to openstack-infra/devstack-gate [1] allows artifact

commit_message:
Update post_test_hook to use run-tox.sh

Proposed modifications to project-config's run-tox.sh script are
intended to allow reuse by non-unit test jobs.  This change updates
neutron's post_test_hook.sh script to use run-tox.sh to reuse the
testr artifact processing that it defines.

Change-Id: I8fff14c02c35e34efef4bdc523f7fea60391cfa1
Depends-On: Ia69f0bef031b33265d508e6a47cc8fb294cb4830

commit_message:
Fix vlan segementation id out of range of config_file bug

When creating vlan network, vlan id is not in vlan range of config
file, neutron server will create success.

Checking vlan segementation id with neutron config file,
then raise an exception.

Change-Id: Ib9d9faa9b010e75d2be0ceca41704c6b41fe72eb
Closes-Bug: #1449526

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for v2.1 cells

This patch removes db layer hard-code permission checks for v2.1 cells,
also add back-compatible checks for v2 cells

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part
DocImpact
Change-Id: Icdfd065c1fbcc87f71f82a21a577cf6ad97da716

commit_message:
Escape the description param from heat template

The heat template allows user to define custom parameters,
the fields are then converted to input fields. The description
param maps to the help_text attribute of the field.

Since the value comes from the user, the value must be escaped
before rendering.

Co-Authored-By: Lin Hua Cheng <os.lcheng@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I79d540a8363b2507c4bccdc0cc38e283962919d2
Closes-bug: #1453074

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-08 10:30:40.000000000', 'message': "Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volume container

The current configuration of LVM for cinder-volume has udev_sync=0.
This means that udev is not creating the devices that appear in /dev.
The device files created reference specific device numbers, and these
persist between reboots. When the host is rebooted there is no
guarantee that device numbers allocated to the logical volumes will
match those defined in the device files. This can be observed by
comparing the output of 'dmsetup info' and 'ls -l /dev/mapper'.

LVM's use of udev was disabled in an attempt to protect the host from
the potential that uevents generated would be processed by all
containers on the host. In practise this should not be an issue because
there are not other containers running on a cinder host.

This commit adjusts the lvm.conf file created so that udev is used. It
also adds a mount entry to create a devtmpfs on /dev. Finally
'udevadm trigger' is run to add the devices under /dev/mapper.

(cherry picked from commit 389b0f0dd886388fefae0cece2844c35da28e405)

Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0
"}]
commit_message:
Enable udev for lvm in cinder-volume container

The current configuration of LVM for cinder-volume has udev_sync=0.
This means that udev is not creating the devices that appear in /dev.
The device files created reference specific device numbers, and these
persist between reboots. When the host is rebooted there is no
guarantee that device numbers allocated to the logical volumes will
match those defined in the device files. This can be observed by
comparing the output of 'dmsetup info' and 'ls -l /dev/mapper'.

LVM's use of udev was disabled in an attempt to protect the host from
the potential that uevents generated would be processed by all
containers on the host. In practise this should not be an issue because
there are not other containers running on a cinder host.

This commit adjusts the lvm.conf file created so that udev is used. It
also adds a mount entry to create a devtmpfs on /dev. Finally
'udevadm trigger' is run to add the devices under /dev/mapper.

(cherry picked from commit 389b0f0dd886388fefae0cece2844c35da28e405)

Closes-Bug: #1436999
Change-Id: I9ab35cf4438a369563f8c08870c1acfd0cc394b0

commit_message:
Fix $this usage in horizon.tables.js

In horizon.tables.js there are a couple of places where
$(this) is called multiple times in the same function. This
isn't optimal and is corrected by this patch.

Change-Id: I7c644c3dbf96c2958ec351024d7f37a30448c44e
Closes-Bug: 1463501

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-20 18:25:20.000000000', 'message': 'Port exception_to_str() to Python 3

On Python 3, exception messages are unicode strings. There is no need to
decode them.

Skip the test on the "ignore" error handler on Python 3, it's specific
to Python 2.

Change-Id: Ieec9e1e1f7a0fc901271fd74eca357fe1cf6a975
'}]
commit_message:
Port exception_to_str() to Python 3

On Python 3, exception messages are unicode strings. There is no need to
decode them.

Skip the test on the "ignore" error handler on Python 3, it's specific
to Python 2.

Change-Id: Ieec9e1e1f7a0fc901271fd74eca357fe1cf6a975

commit_message:
Escape the description param from heat template

The heat template allows user to define custom parameters,
the fields are then converted to input fields. The description
param maps to the help_text attribute of the field.

Since the value comes from the user, the value must be escaped
before rendering.

Change-Id: I79d540a8363b2507c4bccdc0cc38e283962919d2
Closes-bug: #1453074
(cherry picked from commit ecbf4d2bb878b6b6037ee54f195182e46297e85d)

commit_message:
import error by l3_odl

tox -e py27 fails as follows.
This is because importing common_db_mixin from db_base_plugin_v2 was removed,
by the change set of ece8cc2e9aae1610a325d0c206e38da3da9a0a1a,
by the change id of I1eac61c258541bca80e14be4b7c75519a014ffae

The log from here

  /networking-odl $ tox -e py27
  py27 create: /networking-odl/.tox/py27
  py27 installdeps: -r/networking-odl/test-requirements.txt

  py27 develop-inst: /networking-odl
  py27 runtests: PYTHONHASHSEED='3892857836'
  py27 runtests: commands[0] | bash tools/pretty_tox.sh
  WARNING:test command found but not installed in testenv
    cmd: /bin/bash
    env: /networking-odl/.tox/py27
  Maybe forgot to specify a dependency?
  running testr
  No handlers could be found for logger "neutron.quota"
  Non-zero exit code (2) from test listing.
  error: testr failed (3)
  running=OS_STDOUT_CAPTURE=${OS_STDOUT_CAPTURE:-1} \
  OS_STDERR_CAPTURE=${OS_STDERR_CAPTURE:-1} \
  OS_TEST_TIMEOUT=${OS_TEST_TIMEOUT:-60} \
  OS_LOG_CAPTURE=1 \
  ${PYTHON:-python} -m subunit.run discover -t ./ . --list
  --- import errors ---
  Failed to import test module: networking_odl.tests.unit.l3.test_l3_odl
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/networking-odl/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/unittest2/loader.py", line 445, in _find_test_path
      module = self._get_module_from_name(name)
    File "/networking-odl/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/unittest2/loader.py", line 384, in _get_module_from_name
      __import__(name)
    File "networking_odl/tests/unit/l3/test_l3_odl.py", line 22, in <module>
      from networking_odl.l3 import l3_odl
    File "networking_odl/l3/l3_odl.py", line 40, in <module>
      db_base_plugin_v2.common_db_mixin.CommonDbMixin,
  AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'common_db_mixin'
  The test run didn't actually run any tests
  ERROR: InvocationError: '/bin/bash tools/pretty_tox.sh '
  ___________________________________ summary ____________________________________
  ERROR:   py27: commands failed

Closes-Bug: #1463544
Change-Id: Ifd6316420b743358c6f568cb925357f61223c92d

commit_message:
Include links to developer workflow documentation

Newcomers aren't always sure how to get started with our tools or
workflow. Lucky for them, we have documented these things. Unlucky for
them, they have no idea the docs exist.

Give them some links.

Change-Id: I6fce6fbccb8a9fe16b48845790b4cac05317ebac

commit_message:
Make 'echo' work in the 'venv' environment

Our documentation uses the example of:
    tox -evenv -- echo 'done'

Which fails with the error:
    WARNING:test command found but not installed in testenv
      cmd: /usr/bin/echo
      env: /home/john/openstack/ironic/.tox/venv
    Maybe forgot to specify a dependency?

This fixes that issue.

Change-Id: I9beeea1887ed6abfe3e319598cd687b6c6229bac

commit_message:
Make 'echo' work in the 'venv' environment

Our documentation uses the example of:
    tox -evenv -- echo 'done'

Which fails with the error:
    WARNING:test command found but not installed in testenv
      cmd: /usr/bin/echo
      env: /home/john/openstack/ironic/.tox/venv
    Maybe forgot to specify a dependency?

This fixes that issue.

Change-Id: Iec7d24f72f1c8eec90a5c4a5d6ff099f698fd7b5

the change requires a bug report and mention of it in the commit message'}, {'account_id': 6348, 'date': '2015-05-14 06:56:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2015-05-14 06:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

This is related to loading from plugins. auth_uri is different to auth_url even though the naming is bad. 

See: http://www.jamielennox.net/blog/2015/02/23/v3-authentication-with-auth-token-middleware/'}, {'account_id': 6348, 'date': '2015-05-14 07:43:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Jamie

Thanks, I also see some projects use identity_url, what's difference between auth_url?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-14 07:45:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

identity_uri is the full v2 url that you use when authenticating with the admin_* credentials from config. 

auth_url is typically defined by the plugin and is plugin specific. So when using a v2 plugin it's a v2 url, a v3 plugin a v3 url."}, {'account_id': 6348, 'date': '2015-06-10 00:14:17.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Change auth_url to identity_uri

Auth_url is deprecated in the document, replace it with
identity_uri, also add auth_rui configuration.

Closes-Bug: #1454972
Change-Id: Id4ceb9bc617d02ee4380d0d910da6f16979a8579

[{'created': '2015-06-04 14:51:35.000000000', 'message': 'Add Service Providers handling to AccessInfo

Today, keystone tokens might carry a list of service providers alongside
the service catalog. This patch adds the support for the AccessInfo
object to return this list and also to access the URL attributes from
each service provider present in the list.

Change-Id: I7f5ed8c5cb64482eb2d8cf98a8eba33f483eb88d
Closes-Bug: 1459702

commit_message:
Encapsulate Service Providers in AccessInfo

This patch adds the support for the AccessInfo object to return the
list of Service Providers encapsulated in a class that provides methods
to access URL attributes from each service provider present in the list.

Change-Id: I7f5ed8c5cb64482eb2d8cf98a8eba33f483eb88d
Closes-Bug: 1459702

commit_message:
Wake-On-Lan (WOL) power driver

This blueprint adds support for Wake-On-Lan (WOL) power interface
in Ironic.

Change-Id: I7b2f32b2fb8cfda6e42a0bba01a6655f4184e683

[{'created': '2015-06-04 20:47:04.000000000', 'message': 'Prevent multiple form submission on table row actions

This disables any table row actions that do a form submit after an
action is taken and the form is being submitted. It also changes the
cursor to make it clear an action is taking place.

Closes-Bug: #1433849
Change-Id: I004f0ae43e5201eba30ff38a34be680416407fbc
(cherry picked from commit ea2f6b35da70d7a9d3f441553dac0f88f6ef9218)
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent multiple form submission on table row actions

This disables any table row actions that do a form submit after an
action is taken and the form is being submitted. It also changes the
cursor to make it clear an action is taking place.

Closes-Bug: #1433849
Change-Id: I004f0ae43e5201eba30ff38a34be680416407fbc
(cherry picked from commit ea2f6b35da70d7a9d3f441553dac0f88f6ef9218)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

[{'created': '2014-12-24 09:23:08.000000000', 'message': 'Support parent_id when creating project

Since hierarchical multitenancy is now supported [1], this should be
supported in openstackclient also.

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/hierarchical-multitenancy

Change-Id: Ic0a517216737cad0daa434805f313e87bf73ea9b
Closes-bug: #1405369
'}]
commit_message:
Support parent_id when creating project

Since hierarchical multitenancy is now supported [1], this should be
supported in openstackclient also.

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/hierarchical-multitenancy

Change-Id: Ic0a517216737cad0daa434805f313e87bf73ea9b
Closes-bug: #1405369

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

commit_message:
--insecure ignores --os_cacert and OS_CACERT

Specifying --insecure should ignore any cert settings and
attempt to connect insecurely.

Change-Id: I59caaaf9cab5246857c524273e6140d5e0505bfe
Closes-bug: 1447784

(3 comments)

Thanks for the feedback, I've addressed some of your comments (and will address more soon).

Stack is (unfortunately?) the noun heat uses to refer to sets of resources it provisions, and I can't think of a reasonable replacement either.

(10 comments)

Still digesting this parts at a time...

Command objects: 'stack' is very generic and overloaded in the OpenStack ecosystem.  Are we comfortable that this is the only use of it as a resource/object name across all projects?  Or should it be qualified?  We do have 'group' as 'security group' as distinct, so there is precedent, but this isn't a 'first-to-file' situation, it needs to make sense from a user's standpoint.

Command verbs: (BTW, this is one area that I'm very stubborn, OSC has a _consistent_ command set.)  a) 'update' should be 'set'; b) abandon seems like a combination save/delete?; c) adopt seems like create from a file?

Options:  The common --template-* options are an exclusive group but the --environment-file and --adopt-file take a file or URL.  I'd like to make these more consistent, maybe by having --template, --environment and --adopt (adopt/create) and --file (abandon/save).

Tests:  I know we've talked about that, just keeping it on the radar.

Style Nits: in help strings I'd prefer no terminating periods.  I know it is a 'Python thing' but they are sentence fragments, and we don't (shouldn't) have them anywhere else and they are not consistently present here either."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2014-08-29 21:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

> Command objects: 'stack' is very generic and overloaded in the OpenStack ecosystem. Are we comfortable that this is the only use of it as a resource/object name across all projects? Or should it be qualified? We do have 'group' as 'security group' as distinct, so there is precedent, but this isn't a 'first-to-file' situation, it needs to make sense from a user's standpoint.

The only other usage of "stack" I'm aware of is to refer to an OpenStack deployment, which would only be used by OS developers and operators. I'm not aware of any usage of "stack" by users, and it does describe quite well what heat is creating.

> Command verbs: (BTW, this is one area that I'm very stubborn, OSC has a _consistent_ command set.) a) 'update' should be 'set'; b) abandon seems like a combination save/delete?; c) adopt seems like create from a file?

To me, 'set' sounds like an atomic operation, whereas a stack update builds and executes a workflow to transform the stack until it matches the updated template.
I appreciate the need for consistency; this will be my one attempt to convince that a new verb is needed ;)

As for abandon/adopt see my inline comments.'}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2014-09-02 14:29:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

What do you feel would be a good replacement for the "stack" noun in this case?

Unfortunately because of wanting to avoid project names "heat stack" is out (would be my first choice) but we could do "orchestration stack". Downside there being "openstack orchestration stack" is a bit wordy.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2014-09-03 19:42:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(17 comments)'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2014-09-04 03:02:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)

Steve, Ryan, thanks for the explanations.

* I think 'stack' is probably ok, we have other occurrences where a bare word is used in one place (Identity v3 'policy') and in a compound word elsewhere (Network 'firewall policy', and something new and similar in congress' api).  I wanted to be sure there wasn't a simple and easy answer otherwise.

* I still think abandon/adopt are special-cases of create/destroy, as in both cases a stack is being created and destroyed, the differences are in how resources are handled, correct?  Can we experiment with some alternatives in the wiki?  I like doing it there because we have revision history and it's easy to compare to other commands.

* Update does sound like a case for a special verb.  I'm not sure I like 'update' though as it is used as a synonym for 'set' in the project CLIs.  I like 'build' but that is close to 'create' so I think 'execute' might be better.  This is why I have the verbs listed along with the description of the actions users should expect.  When we figure this one out please add it to that list.  https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OpenStackClient/Commands#Actions

Thanks again guys"}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2014-10-22 14:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(17 comments)

Perhaps "stack rebuild" could replace the existing "stack update", but I'd be worried about user confusion since update is a very user-facing term, so users coming to openstack CLI would look for (and not find) an update command. I think the danger of users confusing update/set is probably pretty low for Heat users, since they will have already seen update if they've read about/used heat at all.'}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2014-10-22 14:15:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-22 15:41:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified-1

Dean, the problem I have with 'execute' is that it implies that a heat template is a list of instructions, which it isn't because it is declarative.

To me, 'update' is shorthand for 'Please update the real stack to match what I have declared in this template'"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2014-10-23 21:00:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Steve, yeah, 'execute' isn't so good in that case, but 'update' and 'set' mean the same thing to me, actually I might even argue that set would be more declarative if it created objects that didn't already exist.  But we don't do that part for simple objects, maybe we should?

My need for consistency is high, maybe a summit conversation would help."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2014-10-23 21:24:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Also keep in mind that 'update' might do any of the following:

- add resources
- delete resources
- replace existing resources
- modify existing resources in-place

As for abandon/adopt, there is probably a good case for these being special-cases of create/destroy, so something like:

  create --adopt-data <adopt data file>
  destroy --abandon-data-path <file where abandon data will be saved>"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2014-10-23 21:45:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Re abandon/adopt:  That solution works for me.  If there is a sensible option name that works in both cases I'd prefer that.

Re the first part:  the object in question is a 'stack' not individual resources.  Changing the state of the stack as a whole is what the user intends to do, whatever that involves under the hood.

Heh, I just realized that both the strength and weakness in my position can be exposed by comparing a 'stack' to a 'server', in that they both aggregate some number of other things under the hood and treat them as a unit.  And then look at the list of verbs associated with servers.  <shakes head>  'server resize' could be 'server set --flavor' for example, and it isn't.  Yet.

In my mind, update == set, and I still don't see why this should be different."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2014-10-23 22:02:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Also, the verb 'update' goes fairly deeply into the heat REST API. When a stack update is started, doing a stack show will include the following in the response:

  stack_status: UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS
  stack_status_reason: Stack UPDATE started

Eventually the stack_status will go to UPDATE_COMPLETE or UPDATE_FAILED.

Here is the full list of stack action verbs:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat/tree/heat/engine/stack.py#n66"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2014-10-23 22:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

hmm, since we have so many stack actions maybe they do need to all be under one top-level verb, like:

  stack execute --update
  stack execute --suspend
  stack execute --resume
  stack execute --snapshot
  stack execute --restore
  stack execute --check'}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2014-10-29 16:00:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

+1 for having abandon/adopt as special destroy/create cases. IMO, snapshot/restore is a more descriptive/understandable than abandon/adopt.

While options for each action would be more consistent, I'd consider it a step back for usability, since people would expect things like "destroy" to be the verb, not "execute --destroy" or "execute --suspend".'}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2014-10-29 17:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2014-10-29 17:32:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2014-10-29 17:55:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

a few more comments, but it's close (i think)"}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2014-10-29 18:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-29 19:37:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Verified-1

- check-osc-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/86/111786/11/check/check-osc-dsvm-functional/d8768d7 : SUCCESS in 19m 21s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-10-29 23:20:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Re: abandon, the current semantics of the API are hopelessly broken (see bug 1353670) and we disabled it by default until such time as it gets fixed. What I'm proposing to do there is have a two-stage abandon: first abandon then destroy. So I don't think those two should have the same verb (although it may make sense to just leave it altogether for now until the API is sorted).

I guess you could consider an update as a 'set' of the *target* template and parameters (though not of the stack itself). I don't love that terminology, but I don't hate it either."}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2014-12-31 00:45:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2015-06-09 23:40:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-2

this should be added to a heat project (heatclient or some other repo), are of the mind that going forward any new support for OSC will be in the form of a plugin/extension. OSC will *not* host the code, but provide guidance and a base package for other teams to use.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2015-06-09 23:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

No work in about 8 months and it should be owned by heat and treated as an extension'}]

commit_message:
Redo auth plugins

There are a number of changes here to better align OSC with how the
other clients are expecting to use the keystoneclient auth plugins.

Firstly I think it is a bad idea to Combine all the options from every
available plugin into the --help. There are plugins recently for example
for federation that have a bunch of possible options that are going to
polute this space with options that are not relevant for most people.

Instead of this define a default plugin that handles the options that
were initially available to OSC. Additional options were added in a
recent change however they have not yet been in a release. If we want to
extend the available options for OSC then those options can be added to
the default plugin.

Change-Id: I759cfb2e3989c1abd5cd49826eb136a60427239e

messages:
[{'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2014-09-23 16:42:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2014-09-23 16:42:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 8736, 'date': '2014-09-23 17:47:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I like this idea, but maybe some other approach. I'm not sure all your requirements, but presumably you will have most environment variables set already.  An example of what you can do with the current CLI:

    (.venv)terry ~/python-openstackclient os token issue -f shell --prefix 'export OS_'
    export OS_expires="2014-09-23T21:32:17Z"
    export OS_id="ffxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"
    export OS_project_id="3247a56cc30b4a0b9e073b99bec868fd"
    export OS_user_id="6eb3f85a9ed54fe7915f3c4dc2390193"
    (.venv)terry ~/python-openstackclient 

Maybe an option to the token issue command?

Another possible approach:

    (.venv)terry ~/python-openstackclient unset OS_TOKEN
    (.venv)terry ~/python-openstackclient export OS_TOKEN=$(os token issue -f value -c id)
    (.venv)terry ~/python-openstackclient env | grep OS_TOK
    OS_TOKEN=4b84459ccxxf49f6aa8a80eb00e49113
    (.venv)terry ~/python-openstackclient'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-09-23 21:00:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-09-23 16:42:29.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Allow export and reuse of Token and Endpoint URLS

Add function which allows usage of OpenStack client
where token and catalog is obtained once, then reused for
subsequent commands.

By adding 'export auth' action, which has output
like 'export OS_TOKEN="..."; export OS_URL="..."'
so it can be sourced to current shell.

To handle multiple service-type endpoints
it uses OS_<type=COMPUTE,IDENTITY,...>_URL variables.

Example usage could be:
> source my_user_creds
> eval $(openstack export auth)  # uses auth_url+user+pass+...
> openstack network list  # uses token+endpoint_url
> openstack volume list  # uses token+endpoint_url
> ...

Change-Id: I2959fe68aef57434c87c96a03e350e359f2e2dd0
'}]
commit_message:
[WIP] Allow export and reuse of Token and Endpoint URLS

Add function which allows usage of OpenStack client
where token and catalog is obtained once, then reused for
subsequent commands.

By adding 'export auth' action, which has output
like 'export OS_TOKEN="..."; export OS_URL="..."'
so it can be sourced to current shell.

To handle multiple service-type endpoints
it uses OS_<type=COMPUTE,IDENTITY,...>_URL variables.

Example usage could be:
> source my_user_creds
> eval $(openstack export auth)  # uses auth_url+user+pass+...
> openstack network list  # uses token+endpoint_url
> openstack volume list  # uses token+endpoint_url
> ...

Change-Id: I2959fe68aef57434c87c96a03e350e359f2e2dd0

commit_message:
Refactor awkward logic in setup_dhcp_port

I noticed this logic as I was reviewing another patch set [1].  I
didn't like removing subnet ids from dhcp_enabled_subnet_ids and I
wasn't too keen on the ips_need_removal semantics that were kind of
forced by the existing structure of the code.  I hope you find this
alternative much clearer.  I like straight-forward code with less
indentation that doesn't use awkward booleans like ips_needs_removal.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/157697/6

Change-Id: I8bd3d6924a855ea08f8096e66bd3bfbb165a4da3
